At the sour tasting, Part B, thanks beerandbeyond, pours an hazy brown with a small head, aroma of dried fruits, figs, dates, wood, vanilla and cherry, flavor of figs, wood, vinegar acidity, cherry, warming, full bodied, great

Bottled. Pours brown with a small brown head. Smells sweet barry malty. Tastes sour, fruity and smoky malty with a similar finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from 2005. Dark amber/brown beer with a small brownish head. Vinous, fruity aroma, woody, plums, figs, raisins, sourish. Woody flavor, vinous, fruity, figs, raisins, yeast notes, sourish, plums, wheat, moderate hop notes, sweetish. Maybe it has lost some body during the years, but the flavors are all you can ask for. Nice vinous finish with figs and some wood.

33cl bottle, 2010 vintage.
Pours a cloudy dark red with an offwhite head.
Smells vinous, with balsamic, red berries, tartness.
Tastes fruity-sweet, with a fair amount of sour and tartness, and lots of acidity. Laced with an interesting spicy finish, that comes along with cherry, apple, and a bit of an alcoholic burn.
Medium bodied, soft-but-present carbonation, oily texture.
Finishes dry.
A pretty amazing and interesting beer.

One of the best beers Ive had when fresh or only a few months old but this 2008 bottle was part of a forgotten stash. Dark almost reddish brown with a huge tan head that fizzled quickly leaving nice thin lacing. Sweet aroma of dark fruit, caramel and toffee followed by vinegary, woody, earthy & alcohol- huge alcohol notes. Thin texture, gritty and tart all around with some spice notes and a dry finish.
Beer has turned and the tartness couldnt be denied. The taste reminded me of Liefmans Goudenband backed up by a wallop of alcohol.

This sucker is merepoix  with a sherry/rice wine vinegar mix and a dry tart raspberry in the back, all on the nose.  The flavor is similar but so sharp and crisp all the way through.  The taste go from intense to soothing with a slight toffee/popcorn feel in the middle and a top of the palate big boy sourness to finish.  Easy, approachable mouthfeel makes this feel like a kicked up version of monks Flemish sour.  Thanks de dolle.  2010 12 oz.

2010 Bottle; Finally. Poured into a DAchouffe tulip; its dark golden / amber with a very nice fine bubbled khaki head that retains very well ; with some average sticky lacing. So far, so good. The nose is dark fruits, berries, some vinousness, and some sour notes, really. I admit; Im sick ;) - The flavor profile reveals an extremely nice flavor profile; this is what I was expecting and it did Not disappoint in any way. An initial cream, more berries, plums, sour, mild lactic, earthy oak and vinousness from the barrel treatment, a hint of vanilla, some light lemon peel....... and it continues with some grass from the hop notes, bready malts, and some light spice, actually, some more belgian notes from the yeast and sugars, i suppose. It drinks superbly, with an ABV that is masked at this level perhaps as good as any brew I can remember sampling.  I need.... more.

330 ml bottle bought @ Etre Gourmet. 2010 vintage. Pours slightly hazy reddish brown with an off-white head that leaves no trace while dissipating. Smell is sweet and tiny sour with caramel, wood, vanilla, candi sugar, plums, dates, cherries, blackberries, sherry-like alcohol and hints of dark bread and spices. Taste is sweet, bitter, sour, slightly spicy and tiny metallic with dark bread, caramel, blackberries, plums, cherries, lemon zest, grape zest, brown sugar, wood and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is slightly tart and full bodied. Finish is sweet, sour and tart with plums, sour cherries, dates, wood and dark bread. Wow! A great beer thats very different to the original Oerbier. Never experienced barrel aging making such a prominent improvement before.
2012 bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  I get a tart sweet cherry aroma with some sweaty, bready, and yeast notes.  Palate is incredibly light considering the abv.  Taste is sour, finishing dry.

This is among the best beers Ive ever tasted. Its strong yes, but not overly alcoholic. The taste is a versatile mix of sour notes and a deep laying, dark sweetness. Very complex indeed and frankly just awesome.

2010 bottle.  Pours dark ruby and burgundy with a thick brown head.  Nose is dark and sour fruits, roasted nuts, tree bark and soil.  Flavor is sour and sweet on the front with a great sour finish.  Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with a long rich aftertaste.  Amazing.

27/12/2011 La Tana (330ml bottle, 2008 vintage). Rosso ciliegia, simile a una Rodenbach, con schiuma spumosa, morbida, abbondante e persistente. Aroma magnifico, si riconoscono frutti rossi, caramello, note acide, acetiche, lattiche, quindi balsamiche. In bocca è di una complessità spaventosa, dolce allattacco, quindi evolve in acido, con note legnose e acetiche e un finale balsamico finissimo, di una pulizia ed eleganza inaudita. Corpo medio, buona carbonazione. Pazzesca.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2014 A really great beer that flexes between a solid flanders red with ample tartness and a sort of stronger malty belgian amber.  Really good stuff, and drinks amazingly well for 13% ABV.

2008 bottle.


A - Pours a dark brown, with ruby highlights and a fluffy khaki head that recedes to a web.

S - green apples, fig, caramel, yeast, currants, vanilla, and oak.

T - More of the smell, with an emphasis on the dark fruit and malts. Mild acidity and light alcohol round out the taste.

M/D - Tannic and dry, with light frothy carbonation. Drinkability is outstanding when its at serving temperature, I could sip a few bottles if it wasnt 13%... 

Another fine Belgian beer and brewery that gets no distribution in Texas.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-07-2010

0.33l bottle from Etregourmet webshop. Finally I get to try this one! It pours a nice looking deep ruby-brown body with a medium sized sidesticking and almost creamy beige head. The aroma has a woody touch over it with all these small subtle nuances like; acidic berries, candy, chocolate paper, paper, black currants, caramel and sweet malts. It has a lovely creamy and rich texture in the mouth and the carbonation level is average. I was not expecting this to be all sour, sweet, woody, fruity and yeasty. Quite the complex little thing this one. The first thing hitting the good old buds is a berry sourness often found in gooseberries, cherries and red currants. Then it goes all candy-sweet and fruity before it ends light yeasty and woody-tart with tones of vinious oak. Not at all what I expected! Much more vinious than I ever could have imagined. This became quite a little surprise that I enjoyed on a nice evening. 20.01.2012

Pours a dark amber color with a fizzy off-white head.  A strong aroma of cherry with a mild tartness to the nose.  Hints of vinegar, but they are offset by a nice caramel/malt sweetness.  A touch of oak and red wine, too.  Not overly sour on the palate, but pleasantly tart.  Hints of lemon peel to go along with the cherries and balsamic vinegar notes.  Sweet maltiness with a mild oak contribution.  A bit stronger wine/grape character on the flavor than the nose would indicate. There is also a mild grass and earth note.

07 bottle. This was awesome that I split a bottle of this. Thanks. Pours hazy dark brown. Aroma was unexpectedly sour. I just Oerbier last night and this was much different than that. The aroma had a great balance of sour, dark fruit and malt. Taste was the same, excellent sourness along with the malt. I cant wait to see another bottle that I can buy.

Aroma of complex fruits: apricot, white grape, caramel, and hints of funk.  Pours like a coke with a big head and heavily carbonated.  Taste is very tart champagne, caramel, funk and delicious fruit.  Very intense and no sign of the alcohol.
What about ... De Dolle beers are all fantastic! If you see a bow tie on the neck of the bottle buy it!!!

Bottle 33 cl, Bierkoning. Pours clear deep red amber brown with a nice tanned head leaving lace. Aroma is sour, sweet, spicy, apricots, honey, fruity, malty, bready and tropical fruits. Flavor is fruity, vinous, sour, floral, acidy, pungent, bitter, tart, oak barrel; excellent. Wonder where the 13% is hiding? Finishes longlived sour tart and fruity.

33 cl bottle. 2009 Vintage.
Originally rated on 20100726. (7+4+7+4+16)
Pours beautiful, clear ruby red color with large foamy head. Very compelling aroma of sour cherries, dark and ripe fruits, belgian yeast, barnyard notes, hints of oak, some spices and raspberries. Flavor of ripe fruits, lemon and orange, cherries, raspberry, rowan berry notes, yeast, earth, some spice notes and rose hip at the end. Dry and sour palate with a long, fruity aftertaste. Has definitely matured to its advantage, surprisingly fruity and rich in berries. A slow drinking beer with hopes of neverending pour. Majestic.
4458

Special Reserva 07 pours a dark murky reddish brown color with a fizzy one finger head.  No lacing and the head died a quick death. 

The smell on this beer just blew me away.  Its rich, deep, and complex.  Its like a mix between a beer and a wine.  Up front is the aroma of ripe cherries.  What comes in next is a beautiful aroma of oak, slight vinegar, and a nice yeasty earthiness.  Im sure as this beer aged a little bit the vinegar like aroma has died down.  Which is fine because what really got me here was the deep oak aroma.  Just awesome.

The taste is also great but not might be as deep or rich as the smell was.  Still great though.  The tartness was just right for me.  Not overwhelming at all.  Not like a fresh version of this brew would be.  The oak is once again the star here.  It just sits on the tongue.  Ripe cherries, leather, and malt round out the taste.  A wonderful mixture.  Like I said above, felt like a mix between a red wine and a beer.  As for the 13% abv.  I never once even thought about it.  It never gets in the way or hits you.

Mouthfeel is also spot on for me.  Light to medium bodied, a ton of carbonation, and a dry finish.  Couldnt ask for much more.

Bottle I got as an extra from a trade. It poured a dark red and hazy liquid with a small head. Sour, sweet and fruity smell with lots of apple fruits. Similar taste with a nice mix of sour, sweet and bitter. Very nice and complex beer!
2002 bottle shared by Marcus! was a great brew day. beers circa 1999-2002. pours brown with a small white head. Aroma is date and the flavor sweet yet bitter to finish.

11.2 oz 2010 Vintage.  Pours a reddish/amber with minimal tannish ring of head, some small tight lacing.  Aroma is vinous, oaky, dark fruits, plums/raisins, apples, acidic/vinegar, cherries, some underlying sweet malty, fruitness, and a bit of alcohol/heat.  Taste is acetic/vinegar, oaky in a flanders-esque manner upfront. Some fruits and malty character in mid range, especially tart cherries and apples. On the backend, more woody barrel character, sour/tartness, finishes somewhat lingering sourness and fairly dry with some slight heat. Mouthfeel is smooth, somewhat thin, delicate carbonation, prickly tart/sourness. Excellent and super easy to imbibe for 13 ABV. This should be revisited with more age, bitches.

2010 bottle: poured amber hued with lots of carbonation. Smelled incredibly metallic. Tasted of sour apple and mildly of cherries. This beer is light on the palate, especially for 13%. Got one of the last bottles at the bar, and Im glad I did.
2009, 33cl bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are malt, fruits, yeast citrus and lots of lactose acid.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, ripe fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, rich dark fruit (notably plums, cherries, & grapes), raisons, some caramel, and spice; Finish is dry & slightly tart/sour; The alcohol is well hidden; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, nice vinous qualities - this stuff is excellent.

33cl bottle. 2010 vintage. Deep amber colour with small beige head. Aroma is caramel malts, tart cherries, some tart fruits as well as some alcohol. Flavour is red fruits, some quite dry wooden notes, tartness as well as some mild alcoholic notes. Nice acidity/sweetness balance. Soft, smooth and complex. Reminds me of the Rodenbach Vintage. You can bet this is the closest you can get to the RV starting from Oerbier as a base. You definitely taste the belgian yeast/dark fruits/sweetness of the Oerbier, but aside from that its very RV-like. Definitely an outstanding brew! Amazing.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 2010 Vintage, opened 3/15/2012. 
A: Deep red-brown body.  Moderate sized cream colored head.  Settles do a fairly thick skim.  Good lacing.

S: Vinous notes, leather, cherries, tartness, oak, caramel.

T: Red wine, caramel, raisins, leather, mild oak.

M: Medium full bodied, moderate carbonation, nice tartness, smooth.

O: A phenomenal beer.  Aged versions pick up some madeira/port like qualities (which are nice), but fresh this a beast that really takes on some red wine character.

2006 Vintage, opened 1/13/2012. 

A: Murky, red-brown body. Thin off-white skim. A few stray bubbles left on the sides of the glass.

S: Cherries, caramel, leather, lactic tartness, raisins, and red wine.

T: Tart cherries, sweet caramel malts, a nice tartness, and a fine madeira-like quality. Mild oxidation has treated this beer well.

M: Silky smooth mouthfeel, gentle carbonation, nice tartness in the finish. A little boozy, but I wont complain.

O: Aged De Dolle is a wonderful thing.
8/4/8/5/17

11.2oz 2010 bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep brown/ruby with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, red wine, oak, brown sugar, and light hops.  Flavor about the same with a lot of dark fruit and grapes and Belgian beer qualities.  Smooth texture.  A good beer.

Bottle. 2008 vintage enjoyed 2012-01-10. Hazy, amber liquid with light to medium off-white head. Aroma of lacto, belgian yeast, caramel, sweet malt adnd nice sourness. Taste is medium sour, dry and light bitter with malty backbone and lacto. Medium bodied with creamy mouthfeel and good carbonation. Really nice and sour. Malty and balanced. Really good.

Bottle, 2010, brought back by a friend from Brussels :)
Faint nose. Sweet and sour smell (foretelling the taste I imagine) smelling attractive like sweet fruit candy our dried fruits but sometimes I get a mental image of a pool of urine in a damp back-alley leading to an estaminet (which slightly has a similar olfactory profile... sour & sweet... woody... etc).
Tastes like a Flemish Red. I dont have much experience with that style but first that comes to mind is Rodenbach, though this is much easier to attack, for the unaccustomed. First impression is that the taste reminds me of a weird mix of cider and barley wine. The initial taste on the tongue of the former and the complexity of the latter. I prefer that second part of the taste "experience" if you will, so I like the after taste left on the palate which has that complexity and barley wine-ness.
Not used to it, admittedly, but a nice refresher in Flemish Red (again, thats what it seems like to this beginner in the style...). Recommended as an all-around well crafted beer and to surprise friends with something quite different.

2009 bottle, suggestion by Ryan at LP. Dark maroon color. Slight berry tastes mix well with the caramel and malts. Funky flavors knock the socks off the standard Oerbier. Dry finish with the high ABV hidden quite nicely.

11.2 oz. bottle, pours a cloudy amber brown with a small creamy ring of beige head. Aroma of red wine, oak, some vinous dark fruits and Belgian yeast - the vinous notes are way upfront. Flavour is intensely complex with beautiful notes of red wine, oak barrels, subtleties of caramel malts, Belgian yeast and dark fruits (cherries especially). Dry, vinous and with incredible depth - complex on the palate with no trace of the high ABV. Gorgeous beer.

Bottle 2008.......It pours dark brown with small creamy long lasting beige head.....The aroma is very sour, cherries and dark fruits....The flavor is very balanced ! :) nice! sour, cherries, caramel and other berries...... again very nice mouthfeel ! ....alcohol is well hidden..... :)

2002 Bottle. Big thanks to FooFaa for opening this one up at the Mad-Murren event at Als of Hampden. Poured into a tasting glass.
A - Pours dark amber with a light film of white head leaving no lacing down the glass at all. A bit under-welming to say the least.
S - Tart cherries dominate from first sip to the last. As it begins to warm, more and more caramel malts come thru. Quite a bit of tartness but it still maintains a very nice balance.
T - Lots of tart cherries up front carry thru the entire glass. They blend very nicely with the rich caramel malt sweetness. Finish is a delicious balance of tart cherries and sweetness. A nearly flawless balance of sweet and sour. One of the best dark ales I have ever had.
M - Medium-Heavy body and flavor with moderately low carbonation. Quite the tart cherrie feel with plenty of lingering tart/malt flavors in the finish.
D - Fairly high. I am not the biggest fan of this style but I still really liked the flavors in this one. I just cant see myself drinking more than one of these at a time as the flavors dominate

Bottle from 2006. Pours cloudy amber with a lingering white head. Aroma is caramel malts, dark fruits and spice. Flavor is oak, cab, caramel malts and a hint of sourness in the finish. Pretty good beer overall.
Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  (2006) It poured a dark hazy brown color with a small tan head. The aroma was of caramel, malts, walnuts, cloves, cinnamon, and some vanilla. The taste was pretty heavy, similar to a stout, but not overly heavy. A very good Belgian Strong Ale.

What the f... is this. Bottle 2009. Cocacolaish brown with sparkling carb, small thin head. Aroma sweet candysugar, dark fruits, spice. Taste unbelievable sensation. Both sweet and very sour. Candysugar, dark fruits and lots of sourness. This ale is not drinkable.

Flaske 0,33l delt med Rune på t Brugs Beertje 2 Mai 11. Brun. Lavt lyst farget skum. Syrlig fruktig aroma. Smaken behagelig syrlig med innslag av malt. Svakt sprudlende. Litt bunnfall. Merker lite til alkoholen.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2014 2009 vintage. Pours a hazy dark amber almost brown color with a bubbly white head that laces a little. Very nice aroma of dark sweet malts, light green apple, some funkiness, touch of sour cherries. Flavor is cherry, grape, light grainy malt, red wine like, hint of sourness. Medium bodied dry finish. Pretty tasty and alcohol very well hidden.

2008: Little head, brown. Heavy and sweet nose with oranges, cherries and some sour oxidation. Mediium body and some length. Taste of raisins, sourness cherries and raspberries. Not so heavy as expected and a bit weird.

330 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet (2010 bottle, 13% ABV).  Pours what almost appears as a dark purple in the glass with a reddish hue and a thin off-white head.  The aroma is of tart apple with hints of brown sugar and light oak.  The flavor is surprisingly on the tart side with apple cider vinegar rounded out with wood and red wine flavors.  Moderate warmth as to be expected.  This is a completely different beer than than the regular Oerbier.  While that fits the Belgian Strong Ale category better in a traditional sense this could easily compete amongst some of my favorite sour ales.  Very, very well done.

330 ml bottle with my usual Tasting Group in Athens. Dark amber/brown color with beige medium lasting head. Sweet malty and vinosu aroma with a cheery like sourness in the back. Flavor is very complex  but well balanced. Sweet malt, grapes, sour cherries, wood , very ripe fruit. ABV feels way less than 13% Liek a mixture of belgian stong wth flemish red. Great stuff !

Bottle thanks to someone, but I have no idea who! Pours a cloudy dark brown with a small grayish brown head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma is full of red wine notes with some sour red fruits and a bit of acid. Also a bit of backing grain, but only a hint. Flavor begins starts with sour red fruits and grows to include some acid with a bit of a dry red wine finish.

Reddish brown of color with an off white head. An aroma of  black currant, weak sour, red wine, sweet, weak caramel and raisins. A flavor of oak, red berries, black currant, sour notes, fresh and red wine.

Beer head is a light khaki to a off white. Smells like a sour beer and that first splash in your mouth is very sour. Once you get adjusted it is more subtle. This beer grew on me more towards the end of the bottle. Had taste of a nectary rose.

2007 bottle. Pours chesnut with a thick mousse like tan head and good lace. Complex aroma of musty cellar, oak, sour fruit. Flavor is a wine lovers dream, wonderfully complex with light brett sourness and a full wine like finish. Excellent beer.

A 2008 bottle from barley wine shared with Petrus. Mahogny colour, fizzy, small soon disappearing head. Wonderfull nose, sweet tones of madeira, plums, cherries, figs and alcohol. Sweet and sour tastes, tart, cherries, wine, but also sweetness from figs, honey, caramell all with  warming alcohol. Robust, wellbalanced, complex and full of flavours. Perfect a cold november day.
A little slice of heaven.  Brewed in 2010. Tart apple aromas with a distinct french Cabernet smell. Tart cassie, dark fruit, and a little mustiness.  Overall a fantastic Belgium strong ale.

2008 vintage. Nice mahogany brown pour with a disappearing head. Aroma is so oaky, vanilla, acetone, sweet berries, some rather sour notes. Some malt there as well really nice bread crust and caramel. Taste has a lot of alcohol, sour red wine characteristics, sour oak barrel impressions, some of the same vanilla and acetone qualities. Kinda spicy and yeasty components too. Some of the bread crust malts in there as well, but the oak dominates the taste a lot. Good beer, I guess the taste just doesnt match the nose, though. 9-4-7-4-16

 2010 vintage re-rate  Consumed rather fresh. Amazing reddish chestnut brown with a small slightly off white head. The aroma is really stunning: first off loads of ripe dark grapes, very clear black currant component, Pinot Noir qualities and even notes of English wine gums. Underlying oak notes. Amazingly vineous. Marvelous. Reminds me a lot of the aroma os De Struise Aardnon. The taste is beautifully vineous, too. But its more of a dark fruit rather than these fresh grapes and currants - it also has those, but strives towards figs. A slightly spicy yeast, combined with some Chardonnay-like refreshing tastes and a lightly tart edge from the barrel all adds up to brilliance. There is a slight astringency in the after taste, which holds it back for me to go 4.4-4.5, but the overall impression is exceptional. Much better than I recall.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of foppa78. Thanks again, Mat! Cloudy, brownish maroon appearance with a big, fluffy, tan head. Slight cherry/raspberry tart, caramel, slightly toasty malty, fairly complex aroma. Sour, fairly funky, cherry/berry, toasty caramel malty, tangy, barnyard, mild vinous flavor with a dry fruity finish. Tangy, berry aftertaste. No hint of the booze. The reason I drink beer is for the random occasions like this when Im blown away!
Cider and carnal in aroma. Dark brown with thin tan head. Flavor of sweet calmer balanced perfectly with an aceticcharacter. Very dry with a nice crisp, prickly palate. Excellent

Bottle, courtesy OldSock. Pour is ruby with a medium biege head, some retention and lacing. Aroma is oak, barnyard, cherry, dust, balsamic. Flavor is quite sour with cherry, barrel, and yeast notes. Palate is soft, medium body, low carbonation, long sour finish.
Bottle, 2008. Dark amber, quickly disappearing head. Lots of sourness over mild oak with some vinegar to smooth it out. Also get fruits and spices of some sort(s).

Aroma is huge winy alcoholic fruity grape madness. Some sour watermelon.
Flavour is quite sour with loads of grape and other fruits, some barrel and spice. Very intense and flavourfull, but not exactly my thing. This beer has a bit of an identity crisis imho.
Bottle, 2009 version. Hazy brownish pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of balmasic vinegar, spices, varnish, dark fruits and brett. Flavor is nice complex sour with oak and brett. Nice.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle shared with friends.  Hazy brown pour with no head.  Aroma is Christmas pudding, which also comes through in the initial flavour.  After that it moves on to a very fruity sourness.

33cl bottle courtesy of Kermis.
No head.  Clear amber pour.  Alcohol/sour aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 (30/08/2011) 2007 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: mahogany brown with a Bordeaux hue & tiny brown head, taste reminds me of a Flemish red ale, strong tartness, lots of wood, sour aftertaste, lots of tart fruits incl. cherries, malt, strongly vinous, slightly lactic, lots of ripe berries, full mouth feel, medium carbonation, incredibly different from the regular oerbier ///// Okay, being bad at re-reviewing beers, I didnt take any notes but I have tried most vintages of this wonderful brew now. 2002: too far gone sadly, too much oxidation, just dust, disintegrated malts, almost no barrel, Usually De Dolle beers age incredibly & I had high hopes but this one fell apart. 2004: yeah there is also too much damage in this one now 2005: oxidation taking over a bit too much but still solid, odd glue note 2006: really good still now in 2013. 2007: phenomenal in 2013 now, lots of barrel, hugely vinous, lots of tart fruits, tannins, this is the max, upping from 4.6 to 4.8, rather harsh even in a grate way. Gave some to people to try & they couldnt believe that it was beer. 2010: hopefully this will develop still, the malts are too have here for me, too much sweetness. SNR 2010 was way too sweet fresh as well & look at it now!

The 2008 vintage. Murky, deep mahogany body wity a creamy, off-white rim. Sour and toasted notes with caramel and pickled prunes dominate the aroma. Flavors are acidic, sour, pickled, swee and toasted with a hint of chlorine. Medium body. Light astringent.

Bottle thanks to Dkachur pours dark amber with a frothy pillow of a head aromas are of dark fruits,balsamic and alittle cotton candy taste is full of dark fruits raisens,cherries,plums and a sour note of balsamic vinegar would love to cook this down for a sauce or glaze  this one lives up to its hype

Bottle. 2005 thanks to Papsoe. Pours dark brown with small light tan coloured head. Falls away very quickly leaving all  but the feintest hint of lacing. Aromas remind me very much of a dry sherry. Light acidity, some dark fruits and a hint of spice. I am also getting some honey and a little candle wax as it warms. Flavours are sweet and sour and once again and very sherry like. Soft carbonation which seems to work. Medium mouthfeel. Brilliant. Would love a couple more bottles.

2009 bottle from PG. Pours a thick amber deep in color and active with extremely fine mousse, white head. Lightly sour aroma and fruitiness indicates something of the taste, which follows big. Winelike acidity plus some sour lemon, spices and apricot-sour fruits, a winsome hint of sweetness balancing this strange elephant of a beautiful beer. Feel is prickly then sour then sweet-sour, and you do feel this one.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2016 Bottle at home,  vintage 2008.
Slight hazy dark amber with a small off-white head, quickly gone. Aroma heavy sour (red wine, balsamic vinegar, chocolate, bread, dark fruits, cask, spices, complex with several layers). Flavor moderate to heavy fruity, sour and alcohol. Full body, light carbonated and a long finish.So good and exciting. To be tasted again.
Bottle at Koelschip, vintage 2010. Fantastic again.

Tasted on 7/27/11 from a 330mL bottle obtained in a trade, vintage 2008.  Pours cloudy dark amber with an average off-white head that slowly recedes to uneven lace with a thick collar.  The nose is tart with red wine and balsamic vinegar, chocolate, and bread malt, dark fruit, dried fig, along with a touch of spices, vanilla, earth, overall, very complex.  The flavor is just as complex with the raisin and dried fig with chocolate and caramel up front, moving to the malty bread, vinegar, spices, tart notes, vanilla, and alcohol heat, finishing everything off.  The body is full with light carbonation and a super long finish with tart vinegar, some bitterness, and ripe, dried fruits, along with a good dose of alcoholic heat.

2009 bottle shared by Levi.  Light hazy apricot pour, medium carbonation and an aroma of slightly sour lemon.  Flavor is light woody fruit, a little citrus and finished a little dry.  Well done beer, the 13% ABV is hidden very well.

Bottle of the 2002 Special Reserva at Kulminator. Dark murky brown in colour with a small head. Aroma is reminiscent of a fine cognac and a little flowery with a slight sour note. Taste is of sour cherries, dates, prunes with a hint of chocolate and raisins. Quite unlike any other beer I have tried but rather delicious.

330ml bottle 2008 vintage thanks to savyy1982.

Appearance : Deep clear amber with small white head that is short lived.

Aroma : Massive lactic sourness with rich dark fruits. Notes of cherries, light vinegar. Light sweet notes. Light oak. Very complex.

Taste : Taste surprisingly more balanced than anticipated. Lactic sourness but balanced with lots of fruits and oak. Light sweetness on finish. Sour finish with quite a lot of alcohol. Light vinegar.

Palate : Quite fizzy but not aggressive.  

Overall : Very rich taste. Nice balance between sourness, oak and fruits. Even notes of chocolate can be found. Reminds me a bit of Earthmonk but not as good IMHO. Very interesting even if its not really my style. Great complexity, great sourness. Lots of stuff going on, rather well balanced even if a bit too boozy. Great stuff.

2008. Pours a murky burgandy redish brown with a wisp of head. Nose is sweet dark fruit mixed with vinegared sourness. Initially it is a bit disappointing to taste, but on the tongue it reveals its true self. The sugary sweetness quickly gives way to a tart, though pleasant finish, with a good deal of oak. Lovely full body. A hint of wine like tannins and the finish sits for some time. Alcohol is very well hidden for 13%. Truly beer as art, a very delicate flanders red with a great balance and many little tricks up its sleeve.
Had this beer as Special Oerbier Reserva 2008. Dont really like it. Color is ok, but there a little sourness in the smell and a lot in the aftertaste. Not what I like.

Poured from 330 ml bottle.  Pours brown with a thin beige head.   Aroma is slightly tart fruit, similar to red wine with a hint of Belgian yeast.  Taste follows the nose with a slightly sour note, some dried fruits and vine qualities.  Very dry.  A great beer.

330 ml bottle. 2008 version. Rated @ 25.6.2011.
Pours a deep brown colour with a thick off-white head. Aroma of strong, sour, sweet fruits such as cherries and heavy caramel malts. Flavour of strong, sour, dried fruits, heavy malts, citrus, stinging spices and oak. Full bodied with a thick mouthfeel and a long, sour, dry, fruity, red wine like finish. Beery red wine, just awesome.

2009 bottle. Pours a pitch dark brown with a small off white head. Wow, aroma is incredible. Complex, starts off quite sour, blackberries, chocolate, vanilla, dried fruits. Full and well carbonated palate, no hint of the alcohol. Flavour is sour and sweet, with wine tones, berries, and cherries. Seems to have no relation whatsoever to the regular Oerbier. A truly  great complex beer.

Vintage 2009. Hazy dark reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, sour, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is medium sweet and rather acidic. Dry and rather acidic finish with warming alcohol. 240611

Kerstbierfestival 2007 
Malzig-säuerlich wechselnder Antrunk, hopfig-säuerlich werdend. Im Mittelteil etwas alkoholisch, wenn auch gut versteckt. Die Bitterkeit wird von einer leichten Säuerlichkeit unterstützt, prickelnd säuerlicher Nachgeschmack. 	 
Test vom 20.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: -,11,11,12,-,11 - 11,17

Absolutely delicious.  Smells sours as hell, acidic but nice.  Pours red and frothy and gorgeous.  But the taste is even better, sour and mildly sweet, with a tiny bit of funk underlining an oaky, lingering tart finish.  The alcohol is invisible;  Ive honestly never before drank a beer this strong with this little of an alcohol feel.  Amazing sour.

Green apple and blue cheese.  This beer smells like a sour and pours like a, well, dark cider but whatever, then it just overwhelms with aged cheese, vanilla, citrus peel, everything.  Extremely complex. 2009 bottle.

330ml bottle, vintage 2009, 13% abv, shared with Finn at t Bruges Beertje. Brown-red body, hazy off-white head. Aroma of dried fruits. Dried fruit in flavour, too, but this time with a twist of acidity that lingers down the throat. Full bodied. Perfect as the last drink at the bar (Brugge, 02.05.2011).

UPDATED: APR 16, 2014 2008 Bottle.  The most complex beer I have ever had.  You can barely tell that this came from the base beer.  Sour/bretty taste with dark fruits and cherry flavor.  13%???  The alcohol is not present at all.  Just delicous sour/wild ale flavors with a strong ale background.  Amazing.

Bottle of 08 vintage. Pours a deep ruby red color with a small beige head. Aroma is of dark fruits, funk, dark cherry, oak and vinous notes. Flavor is very vinous, with alot of red wine notes, along with a decent tartness, some dark cherry, faint chocolate, oak, dark fruit, caramel and funk. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a fantastic brew, I love the vinous and tart notes. This reminds me a little of Mikkellers Santas Little Helper 09 Barrel Aged, with out the spice.

2008 bottle.  Nose reminds of a wild beer, metal and sharp, sour acidity.  Dark ruby pour with a lot of carbonation and a noisy beige head, but no gush.  Taste is - wow - super sour and acidic, tangy electric metal and light barnyard funk, intense Granny Smith apple with light cherry and wood, a little filmy and... whoa, there come the onrushing sour cherries.  Touch of papery oxidation on the bottom, but its complementary.  Berries and the lightest wisp of lemon, aftertaste is dry wood.  Full body, dry throughout and well-attenuated, alcohol very gentle, though.  Intensely flavorful but easy-drinking, not a harsh Cantillon or even Girardin; sort of Bruinish but acidity pushing toward something else.  A huge surprise coming off the regular Oerbier, and one of the best sours Im likely to ever have. [4.7, had aroma at 7 but had to up it to 9 to round out the overall score]

Pours a dark redish brown with a tiny brown head. Aroma is tart, funky yeast, chocolate, ripe fruits, caramel, wood and green apples. Taste add some red winish notes, raisin, some acid, caramel, wood, apples, belgian sweetness, tart and funk.

Bottle pour gives slightly cloudy brown with beautiful large yellow head.  Aroma sour with a little light fruit.  Taste was unexpectedly sour with sour lemon, cherry and funk.  Great rich and thick palate.  I didnt taste the alcohol at all which is surprising given the 13% ABV,  I sure felt it though.  Finish sour with a little sweetness creeping in.  Not what I expected after really enjoying the regular Oerbier.  This is one sour and tart beer.

330 mL bottle, 2008 vintage.  Pours crimson brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is fairly sour with lots of acidic cherry, red grape, and some oak notes.  Restrained tart acidity in the flavor, with notes of cherry and red grape, hinting at cocoa and soy, with a slight dusty oxidation quality.  Little bit of rum, even.  Lots to enjoy here.

11.2 oz. brown bottle thanks to rudolf. 2009. A reddish amber beer with a nice head in a tulip. The aroma is simply wonderful. I was not expecting this. Fruity, floral almost like roses and has a nice sourness like lemons. It smells like there is Brett in here. The taste is tart, lemony and a fizzy mouthfeel that prickles the tongue. The yeast seems to add its own bitterness. The one thing that sticks out is the hidden 13% ABV. This is dangerously smooth. I really want to know if there is "wild yeasts" in here cause it seems like it. I always here people say that a certain beer blew them away. That rarely happens to me. Well this beer did that. Ultra smooth, dangerously drinkable, lots of complex flavors going on, perfect sourness. This is a special beer and now the hunt is on for me to acquire as many as I can. If there is a beer that should be stocked in your cellar, this is it. Seek it out if you have not tried it. One of the best beers Ive had.
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2012 Dark brown pour, very carbonated, this is te most amazing sour beer Ive ever had, alcohol very well hidden

Bottle 06 vintage split with linh at Teresas. Pours a deep hazy mahogany body with a reddish tint with thin off-white lacing and crazy, active carbonation. Aroma is dark fruits, tart and Belgian yeast. Mouthfeel is bubbly carbonated with notes of sour tartness, some fruits, yeast, and sweet Belgian candy. +13%???? Wow.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Bottle picked up at Capones a few months back. Thanks to Matt, as always. Served in my trusty Cantillon tulip.

Pours a murky mahogany with a good off-white head. Forms up and is pretty bubbly at about 1.5 fingers. After that, it dies down and leaves a nice cap and a lot of lacing on the edges of the glass. The nose has some notes of bright sherry and semi-tart cherry. Mild acidity is present in the nose. Its showing some signs of oxidation, though mostly in a good way. The flavor lives up to the nose. Not too much complexity, but the light acetic touch balances the cherry and light malt notes very well. The sherry in the background is quite pleasant. Mouthfeel is medium and quite creamy. Low carbonation and not hint whatsoever that this is 13%. Holy crap, I cant believe that after looking up. Good job, De Dolle.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-14-2011
330 ml bottle a red brown colored beer with a white head aroma caramel spicy fruits and some sourness flavor caramel spicy fruits lemon berries oak and a sour finish

2008 vintage,bevuta al kulminator.
certo non è proprio una passeggiata,ma quando la si annusa la mente comincia a viaggiare...... ricca  allolfatto ma soprattutto al palato,lascia il palato estasiato.....
Anyada 2008. Cervesa massa jove, necessita envellir uns quants anys més per integrar bé el carbònic i mostrar totes les seves virtuts. Gran cervesa de guarda.

330ml bottle acquired at Olbutiken.

Pours medium brown, light tan highlights, a nice light head very nice intial carbonation but fades way to quickly...Aroma is super strong, as soon as the cap is off you are hit with strong sour notes, a typical oud bruin aroma. Oak underneath everything, light vinegar on the back...The taste is more a barrel aged sour to me, reminds me of consecreation more than an oud bruin. Having said that probably the best oud bruin Ive had. Its too plain though, just sour wood from start to finish, no depth...The feel is nice and easy to drink.

An easy to drink 13% oud bruin that is on the plain side, but worth trying.

(33 cl bottle from Bartof Café) Pours clear dark ruby with frothy but shortlived off white head that leaves thick traces of lace along the sides. Aroma is quite powerful and surprising. Sharp, turpentine and fruity - what seems to be strawberry or cherry. Taste is sour - like aromatic vinegar - with a faint impression of hobs on the palate. Full-bodied, low-carbonated silky texture with a strongly astringent finish. Alocohol is well covered as others have noticed. You dont notice the 13% until you get up. Well brewed but not really my kind of beer.

2009 vintage. 11.2 oz bottle.

It pours an amazing translucent red, deep and crimson. The head is frothy and off-white with some great lacing.

The smell is amazing. It is full-on with some surprising hops but mainly a rich, sweet fruit decadence. There is a ton of pineapple and citrus with some maraschino cherry.

The flavor is utter dominance. It is sour, but not mouth-puckering. This one defies logic though. At 13% it isnt sweet at all, it is sour, but not over powering, and above all there is no hinting of alcohol what-so-ever. It has apricots, apples, cherries, raspberries, and pears. IT is a fruity, rich, malty, but tart and sour beast.

Just a beast.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-06-2011 06:39:46

(bottle, 2009) pours a slightly hazy ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of balsamic vinegar, green apples, wood, lactic acid, brown sugar and juicy chocolate cake, lots going on, but a little too oxidised for my taste. flavour is about the same, with a medium sourness and hints of citrus fruits, red grapes and light alcohol. medium to heavy-bodied with lively carbonation.
Bottle from Bierkompass. Reddish brown color with nice thick white head. Aroma, red fruit, wood, raisins. Taste, cherries, honey, bourbon, wood. Very nice complex beer.

Bouteille de 33 cl, édition 2008. Arômes très complexes de fruits confits, de vinaigre balsamique et de vin rouge. Légère touche de brettanomyces. Magnifique robe rousse foncée et limpide, belle mousse beige qui tient bien et effervescence moyenne. Très complexe et vineuse en bouche, la bière montre une présence dacide acétique parfaitement équilibrée par un corpulent malt rappelant le sucre dorge et les fruits mûrs. Légère touche boisée et tannique. Lalcool est très bien dissimulé pour une bière aussi forte et napporte quune douce sensation de chaleur en finale. Du grand art !
DrAft at double windsor. Smells and tastes if berry, pine, cake and hops with a maltu backnone. This beer.  Is awsome. Strong. But drinkable,

2008 vintage.500ml.Pours a deep brown with a red hue and a white to off red head that lingers.Nose is raisin,oak,and cherry.Spectacular nose.Taste is sour and tart cherry,heavy oak,bitter hops and toasty charred malts.This beer is amazing and Ive walked by it hundreds of times before reading an article about it last night and rushing to buy one today!Simply amazing.

33 cl bottle vintage 2008, pours deep reddish with a minimal head, aroma of cherry, yeast, acetone, malt and wood, taste is fruit/cherry, wood, malt and yeast, very smooth, very long finish, fairly tart but nicely balanced overall, super beer.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2012 2008 bottle at Mes Tasting. Clear, ruby-brown pour with a small head. Sour nose, some cherry and raspberry, light sugars. Wonderful flavor, not too sour, some yeast, more cherries along with oranges, and an overall vinous quality. Medium to full in body, quite warming, with moderate carbonation. Almost stining alcohol on the finish, mild caramel and toffee sweetness, mild lip-puckering tartness, some earthy bitterness. Excellent. (4.3)Bottle from 2008 at Bruces Housewarming Party Tasting, London. Pours foggy, light brown with a soft, off-white head. Lots of tangy fruits in the nose, mild tartness, raspberry. Big sweet flavor with light booze, tangy wood, some bitter earth, tart fruits, especially berries. Full bodied with average carbonation. Warm finish with mild tang, tart and ripe strawberries, some dry wood. Nice tangy wood and tart fruits throughout. Lovely. (4.2)

Muddy brown pour from bottle.  Off white head.  Aroma is flowers and kinda sweet.  Taste is plums, hard candy and light booze.  Sweet and kinda tart at the same time.  Finish is green apples and slightly sour.  Wow!!  Complex and excellent!!

Bottle. 11.2 oz. (2006) Pours a deep, marbled, hazy brown. High, textured, beige head with specks of spice. Lovely, gratuitous sedimentations. Beautiful lacing. Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, raisins, walnuts, clove, pepper, cinnamon, and vanilla. Firm, yet unbelievably smooth body. Mouthfeel is heavy, almost like a stout, but not too heavy, with slight warming. Finishes powerfully, with a bit of tart. Outstanding in every aspect. One of the best Belgian strong ales I have ever tasted. Highly recommended.

330ml bottle from jb84, shared with jsprime. 2009 vintage. pours light reddish orange with a small off white head. massive, aged flemish red. sour and balanced and drinkable and13%. this is the type of brew thats hard to imagine and hard to explain but if you love huge complex funky sour ales itll be right up your alley. awesome stuff!

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 1/III/2012 - 33cl bottle @ Klaas place - 2008 vintage (2012-xxx) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Note: This is a re-rate. For those concerned, the original rating is below this one. I guess back than I was completely taken aghast by the sourness of this brew, something that was not anticipated. 
Clear red to rust brown beer, creamy light beige head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: sour Rodenbach to even bretta aroma, maraschino cherries, milk chocolate, for those who know it: "Mon Cherie" candy. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: pretty sour start, red currants, tobacco, sour cherries, lots of spiced, through all this flavour violence,  the alcohol comes through warming and sweetening things up quite a bit, turning into something almost vinous, red wine. Aftertaste: still holds the sour bretta touch, but also some caramel and a certain woody dry bitterness. Not bad, not bad at all! Pretty funny that apparently I referred to Rodenbach in both ratings, which I otherwise rarely do.

15/01/2011 - 33cl bottle @ home (2011-21) 
Dark brown beer with red glare, beige stable head. Aroma: sour apple, Rodenbach (so lactobacil infected), orange peel. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: sour apple, lactobacils, berries, smoke and wood. Aftertaste: sour, mocha and some coffee hints, warming alcohol in the back of the throat, tangy bitter-sour is long lasting. 13% ABV, but what for? It lacks the full body of a 13% ABV.
Ar: 5, Ap: 5, T: 5, P: 4, O: 10, Total: 2.9
Bottle. Pours muddy brown. Nose and taste of plum, raisin, oak, tart ripe dark fruit skins, yeast, nuts, sherry, caramel, grape and toffee. Pleasant tartness. Lots of vinous notes.

Pours a deep redbrown with a large tanned head that steadily disappears to leave a foam ring and not a trace of lacings. Lots of yeast left in the bottle. Great aroma with such complexity. Its cherry, spices, mulled wine, sherry, wood, almonds and lots more of subtle nuances. The flavours is a little more straightforward, with light cherries, wood, tartness and tannins. Mouthfeel is tingling and a little astringent. Slight alcohol burn. Unique beer.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 2008 vintage. 
Aroma:  The nose is big and bold with lots of dried fruit, dates, spices, and sweet malts.  Absolutely delightful and a good portent of things to come. 
Appearance: It pours a very dark brown with a slight haze and ruddiness.  You cant see through it.  The head starts off large and tan with lots of effervescence but fades quickly to a thin tan ring around the edge of glass.  Certainly not too bad for something at 13% ABV.
Taste: Surprisingly light and fruity on the tongue with a nice touch of tartness.  The dark fruits are there but along with some cranberry as well.  The alcohol is very well hidden until it hits the back of your throat.  Then it provides a nice warming sensation all the way down.
Palate: Light to medium body with an abundance of carbonation leading to a short to medium, tart berry finish.  This one borders on some fine wine flavors in the finish as well.
Overall: Unique and different.  Clearly a difficult one to brew but they have pulled it off very successfully.

330ml 2008 bottle, bought in Chicago (thanks Funky Brewster).
Pours amber with creamy tan head.  Fresh aroma, fruity, .  Crispy, bubbly palate.  Tart and sour tast, slightly sweet, hard to note the high level of alcohol.  Notes of fruits, earth, oak.

2009 bottle. Orange to amber brown colour. Finger thick white head that dissipated rather quickly. Aroma of sour apples, fruits, wine and oak. Fairly well carbonated with a crisp mouth feel. Sour and tart with a taste of oak, yeast, cherries and a underlying bitterness. Alcohol Is extremely well hidden. This is definitely a world class beer great job.
Bottle, 2007 vintage. Brown pour with some tan head. Aroma is sour, nutty malts, and light spice, dark fruits, and a bit of etoh. Tart fruit, oak, and some light spice flavors. Light warming for 13%

Vintage 2008, I had it in december 2010. The color is red mahogany, and the head is creamy and lasting. The aroma is sourish with notes of fruit, wood, yeast, caramel, raisin and I find the same notes in the the sourish, dry and slightly sweet flavour.

2007 bottle...pours a deep amber-brown color with a thick and creamy tan head...nice retention and lacing.  aroma is mildly sour and funky with some leathery notes...faint earthy, wheaty notes too.  flavor is also funky and slightly leathery...bordeaux comes through with hints of sour dark fruit...hints of woodiness too...ever so slight spicyness that i cant quite pinpoint to a flavor.  moutfeel is lively with a lingering earthy, fruity, sour finish that dries out perfectly.  awesome!

11.2oz btl 2009 vintage. Pour a reddish tinged clear light copper hue with a frothy white head. Tart fruity alle aroma. Great crisp champagne like mouthfeel. Tart and fruity, cider and cherry, crisp and drinkable. 13% totally hidden. Definitely want to sit on a bottle and see where it goes. Impressive, most impressive.

2009 bottle.  33cl.  Pours a hazy, orange brown with a frothy, off white head.  Nose of apples, Belgian yeast, light paint thinner, ripe pears.  Flavor is sweet, fruity, candy sugar, light pepper, malty, apples, pears.  Full bodied, sweet finish.  I was thoroughly impressed.  Tons of fruit flavors.

Pours orange/brown with a towering orange head. It took a few minutes for it to settle down before sipping. the aroma is decidedly tart with cherries, oak, and a little funk. The flavor is tart with lots of cherry flavor and some oak but with a sweet, sugary, kind of strange earthy finish. Some blood orange in there as well. The alcohol is not very noticeable at all. I would have liked this to pack more of a sour punch and less sweet.

Bottle thanks to Boutip! 2007 vintage. Cherry red pour, nice off white foam. Very winey, tons of cherries, sour notes. Taste is so sour, a real cherry bomb, with lots of alcohol warmth and that nice belgian feeling. Mouthfeel is heavy, decent carbonation, pretty awesome.

Clear medium brownish a creamy off white head. Roasted grain sour green apple cassis caramel  vanilla and oak aroma and taste with a tart finish and lingering herbal tea notes. Amazingly creamy palate. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2014 Dark brown colour, beige foam. Medium carbonation. Very complex aroma of caramel, roasted malts, dark fruit with a vinous sour aftertaste. Hints of oak. Light sweet with sour notes (red fruit). Full body. Very well made!

Bottle. Dark brown, hazy, small and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty aroma, fruity and sour with some sweetness and alcohol. Body is medium, fruity and dryish sour flavor with some alcohol. Finish is average, dryish with alcohol. Body is only medium, so 13% alcohol is too much despite of sourness (and "Special Reserva" on the front label).

Waw, great perfect complex sour aroma. The flavour is astonishing. Starts sour, a hint of sweetness and then a warm sence of alcohol overwhelms you. About as close as you can get to a perfect brew. Loved it every step of the way. (Bottle 33cl)

Pours out a dark cherrywood color, with a light tan head that lasted the entire drink. Aroma is sweet of tart cherries and figs, with a touch of clove and spice. A light sour funk to the aroma as well. Taste is full of tart cherries, barnyard funk, light spice, and oak flavors. Wine-like finish that is fairly dry. Very nice beer and I loved it to be honest. Would certainly buy again but for $9.99 a bottle this stuff wasnt cheep. Regardless, very nice brew and well done.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2011 Special Oerbier Reserva on punertavan ruskea olut. Sen tuoksu on marjaisen hapan, kypsän hedelmäinen, rusinainen, juustoinen, toffeinen ja viinimäinen. Maussa on happamuutta, kypsää hedelmäisyyttä, hiivaa, rusinoita ja marjoja. Kuiva ja raaan persikkainen. Tässä on melko paljon hiilihappoja.
Bottle shared at the Coffee District.  With nearly 800 ratings, Im not bringing anything new to the table....

2009 vintage. Pours dark brown with a small light brown head. Aroma is very fresh with sour cherries, vinous and packed with oak.  The lactic acid gives it a whole new dimension. The mouthfeel is just wonderful and comforting. The alcohol (with some alcoholburn at the end) is omnipresent, but in no way disturbing. A piece of (t)art.
Mörka bär, syrlig, lite källarsmak (och doft) Stor smak av röda bär och plommon. Vinös och en mycket fyllig och trevlig öl

Muddy brown with orange highlights.  Sour cherry, sweet tarts, apricot and molasses.  Medium bodied with full rich lingering flavor.  Tart apple, cherry, and brown sugar.  Wonderful sour finish with just a faint hint of bret.  Outstanding beer.

Bottle, courtesy of Phredrik. Mahogany brown pour, modest cream head. Aroma is very thick with a lot of sweetness, sweet berries, heavy-duty oak, wine, port, rum, vanilla, ethanol and some very faint hops. Taste is also quite thick and very sweet with massive amounts of oak and sweet grapes. Very big body, low carbonation, long duration. All in all extremely wine-like and heavy-duty.

Copper red colour. Aroma reminds me of oak barrels - spicy and pain grillé. Flavour is amazingly complex with cherries and other red fruits before a long, tart finish. This is between beer and wine. So good and great with food (I tried with lamb.) I could drink this every day!

Bottle. 2007 version bottled in 2008. Pours a murky brown with a red tinged color with a tan head that coasters on top. Sour fruit notes in the nose with some acetone aromas. Light mouthfeel. Sour dark fruit taste like cherry and plum. Some latent bitternes as well. Acetone in the taste but not overpowering. Surprised this is a 13% beer! The off type bitterness in the taste is a little off putting for me but other than that I am enjoying this one.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 2009 Bottle, from Beer Planet, Brussels. Pours a rusty red-brown body with a medium white top. Aroma is wooden tart flavors; cherries, red currants, wine yeast and dark malts. Taste follows; a dry, sour composition of oak, cherries, port tones and sour estery notes. This is much more in the landscape of an "oud bruin" than both the category and the original Oerbier would indicate. The very high alcohol level is extremely well hidden; this does really not feel any stronger than 8-9 % ABV, tops. A nice beer that heads a bit too much towards the sour category than to my own taste, but a very sturdy piece of brewing craft nevertheless.

08.  Aroma is thin sour notes, faded cloves, and a whiff of sweet malt.  Taste is a wonderful tart sweetness over a chewy raisin malt.  The tart character in the taste far exceeds what youd expect from the aroma.  Somewhat of a tart/sour tingle through the finish but the beer is extremely clean in the bottom 1/2 and the alcohol is minimal to not noticeable.  Candied sugars come out more as the beer warms.  Really unique and wonderful beer.

2008 Vintage. Reddish brown with a thin tan head. Vinous aromas, dark fruits, chocolate liqueur, and candied fruits (orange). Full body, nice carbonation, soft, chewy, some sour cherries, balsamic, medium tartness, that finishes on a bitter chocolate note. Beautifully balanced, really long aftertaste. Alcohol really well hidden, you really dont feel the 13% at first. you do feel it by the end of the bottle... A real treat.

Hazy amber color and beige frothy head. Aroma is fresh with red apples and a bit yeast and oak. Taste is sour and dry, a bit stale and with a champagne character. Some lingonberries. Sneaky boozyness. Very nice sour/bitter finish that teases your taste buds. Fizzy carbonation. Love it.

Bottle. (Vintage 2008)

Dark amber  with a small white foam. Nice sour aroma of cherries, oak, fruits, malt. The same in the vinous taste. Excellent beer, I want an other bottle.

Mahogany pour biege coloured small head mild carbonation aroma tart vinous cherry dark fruit alcohol sugar flavour cherry very tart cider apple brown sugar not a good flavour to me finish sour tart not for my palate liking.

"Brewed in 2007."  A pricey bottle, but I have greatly been looking forward to this one for a while.  Has a bizarre tangerine orangish brown color thats murkey as all hell.  Nice off-white, light tan head.  I put this bad boy in the freezer and got it near frozen to open it, considering every single de dolle bottle I have ever opened has gushed all over the joint.  So, I will resume the rating when the beer cools way down.  The aroma is dominated by brett, some ripe cherries lemons, yeast, and oak.  Quite nice.  The flavor is sharply acidic upfront with lots of lactic and pedio working in the finish--cheesy finish.  A real mouth puckering punch.  Some cherry and woody notes as well.  Medium to full body with medium to minimal carbonation.  Overall: a really unique and aggressive sour that any sour fan should try.  Really unique and bold.

Bottled vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */
Clear ruby color, small steady beige head. Nose has pepper, caramel and Jägermeister. Crisp carbonation. Strong alcohol, Dolle yeast, caramel, dark malts, black pepper. Portwineous. Probably improves with the age.
7/23/10.  HUGE thanks to fata2683 for this puppy!  Big sour cherry and vinegar aroma which transfers huge into the flavor, but with a nice roasty finish.  Awesome stuff!  Thanks, Keith!

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 2005 vintage shared by nbutler at atlas on 6/17/10.

burgundy burnt brownish red colored pour with a sizable tan head which leaves a ton of foam on the glass. 

very malty aroma... notes of mineral/slate, cherry-like fruitiness, tartness, raisins and brown sugar in the background.

it tastes like it has seen a barrel... and soured... it shows raisins, vanilla, wood, slate, yeast, brown sugar and maltiness in the flavor.

soft airy mouth feel from the volumous carbonation... yet it is crisp from the tartness and mineral dryness. 8/4/8/3/15/3.8

08 bottle from nick on 5/20/12.
very vinous and tart....like it was made to be a sour....odd. 8/4/7/3/15

2006 Bottle - thanks hopscotch.  Pours a deep, leathery brown.  Thin head is quickly gone.  Nose is lively with sour notes, vinous fruits, malty, and tart.  Oak, cherries, vinous fruit, and malty before some lingering sours and tartness.  Blends together quite well as it nears room temp.  Very nice.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2015 Tried the 2004 at De Dolle and 2006 back at home.  Both excellent.  You can really taste the Rodenbach yeast. Complex and wine like. Quite carbonated. Serving: Bottle

Pours a hazy deep amber/ruby.  Heavily sweetened aroma initially followed by the tang of the traditional sour.  Tart, but very clean throughout; finish is very light.  Oak-y.  Dried apricot.  Palate is unbelievably clean.  Not my preferred style, butt can definitely appreciate it.

Bottle, dark amber color with good tight bubbly foam, aroma of balsamic, caramel,
fatty cheese, flavors of red wine, sour, leathery astringent finish
Bottle from 2009. Slightly hazy brown with lasting tan head. Aroma is malt, wood, tart, fruit. Flavour is malt, caramel, wood, tart, fruit, sour. Doesnt taste like 13%.

2005 bottle from TheEpeeist -- many thanks!  Pours brown with an oatmeal  colored head that leaves gorgeous lacing.  Earthy and very calcified.  This went brilliantly with seafood.  Wonderful yeast, distant licorice, vanilla, and sour oak round out the flavor.  Great stuff.

2008 vintage bottle.

Pours dark mahogny with a beige head.

Vinous aroma with some sweet malt, chocolate, vanilla and mint.

Taste of plums, chocolate and some wine. A bit to sweet for me, a tip is not to serve it to cold.

Medium yellowish beige head. Barely translucent red body. Subtle wooden yoghurty cherry barnyard aroma with sweetish malty notes. Dry-sweet intense wooden cherry barnyard taste. Mid-bodied. Astringent mouthfeel. Dry-astringent wooden cherry aftertaste with metallic notes. Nice, but a bit too harsh. (0.33l bottle shared with gr0ve.)

2007 bottle from Sams, Durham. Lively dark red pour, brimming with carbonation and some mild sediment on the business end. Head is slightly beige, almost like a coffee stain on paper. Nose is so delightful, with the dry Bordeaux complementing the basic dark fruit and sour notes of the beer wonderfully. Nice mouthfeel, lively but not so carbonated that the flavors elude you. Theres more of the wood in the flavor, which gives the beer an additional dimension to go along with the must, a hint of sherry, some aging dark fruit, and a dollop of distilled funk. Hard to believe its 13%. Nothing aggressive, demonstrative, or unbalanced, just a superbly complex beer that Id love to stockpile.

2008 bottle from Beer Planet, Brussells. Dark brown pour with a reddish sheen, beige head. Rich aromas of raisins, chocolate, vanilla, rose petals, quite sour, oak, wood, very vinous. Superb nose. Flavours of dried fruit, licorice, chocolate, light sherry notes, wild cherries and some sourness. Sweet/sour alcohol caress on the palate. Warm, soothing alcohol in the finish. Excellent.

Notes: 2008 Bottle from t Brugs Beertje

Woody with a slight citrus/lactic edge and a bit of walnut and syrup aroma.  Deep amber-brown in color with a light brown head.  The taste is seemingly ever-changing; starting woody then becoming sweet with a bit of walnut and syrup then slightly sour with a nice bit of hops in the finish...like the experimental wonka gum of beer.  Really smooth, interesting and all around good!

"brewed in 2006"
sour citrus peels, dried fruit, and the omnipresent de dolle metallic tinge / licorice.
dirty medium-light brown with smallish fizzy beige head.
puckering tart flavor, following by fruity sweetness and metallic bitterness.
medium body, somewhat effervescent, with long sweet-sour finish, again with hint of aluminum.

2008 version. 11.2oz bottle served in a Boulevard Tank 7 tulip. Bottle conditioned. Poured a reddish gold with two fingers of off white head. Lots of carbonation. Tart and fruity aroma with some cherries. Lighter side of medium bodied, effervescent. Nice and tart with more fruit in the flavor, just a bit of alcohol heat that took my rating down a bit. Some sweetness in the finish. Also a bit of carmelized sugar as it warmed. Beautiful beer, I only wish I had bought another bottle to stash away.

Pours a murky brown with hints of red and a tan head. Nose of honey, grapes some sourness and woody undertones. Flavor is sour, with vinegar mixed in. Sweet grapes as well with a dry but sour/bitter lingering finish.

Bottle.

A - Very dark reddish brown color with a slightly smaller than average foamy off white head that reduces fast and leaves a nice thin layer of lacing.

S - Strong aroma of tart cherry and balsamic and red wine vinegar, with the emphasis on the wine vinegar smell. Has some gueuze like aroma. Acidic aroma is the strongest, but it isnt overpowering.

T - A lot of grape, apple cherry flavor with tart being the main aspect of the fruit, but it isnt extraordinarily tart (especially given the style). Like the aroma, red wine vinegar provides a fair amount of the taste. Some tannic taste and somewhat like a sweet red wine. Fairly vinous and the ABV is well hidden.

M - Medium body with a bit above average carbonation. Somewhat tingly and a drying finish.

D - Good balance between tart/acidic and sweet, especially given the style. Very enjoyable taste and the ABV is very well hidden. Quite easy to drink.

Notes: Brewed in 2008. Well balanced beer that isnt overly tart/acidic but definitely has those aspects. Overall, an enjoyable beer to drink.

21-MAY-2010, bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
2007 version. Very exited to try this. 
I open the bottle, and very slowly it runs out of the bottle. I pour into my Mikkeller glasses:), but it continues to spill out of the bottle even though the bottle is no longer full. Bottle fermentation - yeah!
Lovely redwine and brown sugar nose(!).
Taste is fantastic and complex. Redwine, oak, cherries, malty with bread-like notes, fresh, and even overripe apples. what more? its beyond me to describe...
...and then the fresh crisp acidity. This is categorised as "Belgian Strong Ale", but is that really correct with the sourness?
Anyway one of the best beers I have had.

Whoa to the alcohol on this one -- its as close as De Dolle or anyone else will get to making wine.  Oaking shows through, souring the fruit on the nose.  Also aromas of cherry jam, sugar, sourdough.  A little bit astringent on the palate.  Alcohol creates a cooling, rather than a hot, effect.  Finish has fruit and dusty flavors.

Been wanting to try this for a while.  2006 vintage.  Pours a murky brown with a small khaki head which dissipates rather quickly.  Sour and funky aroma with some oak and fruit present, as well.  Taste is tart with some woodiness which fades to lemon zest in the finish.  Very subtle alcohol presence in the finish as well.  This is a very interesting beer, and i enjoyed drinking it greatly.

2005 Vintage
Dark brown body with a thin white head.
Dark caramel aroma; some acetic sharpness along with raisins and other dark dried fruits.
Goes from sweet to tangy, then the sourness creeps in for the finish.

Pours a dark red with white head.  Aroma is vinegar, cherry and spices.  Taste tracks along the aroma with the cherry adding a nice tartness to the brew.  Excellent mouthfeel, very smooth and refreshing.  Alcohol is hidden well.

Second time Ive tried this -- had one over Christmas with darn1207 but neglected to rate.  This time its a 2008 bottle from the Ponce de Leon Greens in Atlanta.  Pours amber red brown with massive pillowy head.  Head settles to about an inch rendering a really attractive glass.  A bit of sour cherry on the nose, and a bit more with the first sip.  Sour, yet balanced.  Nice carbonation.  Head settles to about an 1/8 inch.  I recall from last time the impossibility of 13%, which is reaffirmed -- seems not nearly as strong and is quite drinkable.  Bit sweeter, with flavors of green apple and banana as it warms.  Great mouthfeel.  I love this beer.

Bottle...  Poured deep amber, almost brown.  Smooth, well balanced lactic tartness and sourness.  Creamy fruit notes, oak, malt sweetness, and dark, toasted tones as well.  Dark cherries and vinegar like sourness.

Bottle of the 2005 at the Rosso release at Captain Lawrence.  Pours a hazy milky brown with a thin beige head.  Gorgeous thick caramel on the nose.  So pretty.  Tastes like a Charleston Chew, piled high with sweet vanilla.  Lightly tart finish.  Wow this was wonderful.

Wow, now thats a great beer!  08 bottle.  Pours a cloudy slightly amber brown with off white head, some lacing.  Aroma of ripe cherries, dried fruits, almost wine like, oak, and some roasted malt.  Flavor matches well and makes for a very enjoyable brew.  Finishes dry and warm.  Nice sipper and thoroughly enjoyed!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2011 11.2 oz. bottle from South Bay Drugs.  2008 vintage.  Pours a muddy brown color with some chunky visible sediment and a big rocky beige head that settles into a nice cap on the beer.  Aroma of dry tart cherries, oak, sour yeast, vinegar, with citrus acidity.  Flavor of oak, tart cherries, balsamic vinegarette, wild yeast, sour and tart fruits, citric acid, and plenty of alcohol.  Lingering tart, alcoholic finish.  Medium-bodied, with above average carbonation and a sour, woody, lemon juice mouthfeel.  Very unusual beer.
0.33l 2008 - Fizzy brown liquid with light tan head.  Woody, yeasty nose, sour cherry palate, tastes better than it smells.  Roasted notes on finish, and hides the 13% without being too sweet.

2006 bottle - Ive had this sitting in my cellar for about a year and decided to open in and treat myself to a beer from one of my favorite breweries. Pours really deep mahogany with a small, bubbly khaki head. Smells like dry red wine with lots of oak. Its pretty tart and has just a bit of citrus acidity. The taste is equally complex, with balsamic vinegar, lots of oak, and dark fruit, especially black cherries. Theres lemon and grapefruit on the finish, and I swear I can taste some bretty, earhty yeast in there. Lots of velvety carbonation makes the medium body extremely smooth, and the 13% is nowhere to be found. A remarkable beer thats totally a sipper, but one I wouldnt mind having a couple times a year.

Flaske årgang 2004: Brun klar øl med et tyndt skumhoved. Fantastisk sur duft, hvor cantillon fadene tydeligt træder igennem ovenpå den klassiske dolle gær og en fin maltsødme. Smagen er i en anden himmel. motherf**cking fantastisk. Let sur men stadig en fin sødme, jamen det bliver bare bedre og bedre. De 13% smages ikke. Fantastisk øl.

2005 bottle thanks to theEpeeist.  poured brownish amber with a beige head that sits atop the brew for the life of the beer.  aroma was very nice with wine, cherries, caramel, grains, oak???, raisins, and grapes.  flavor was great with a dry wine type flavor, oak, cherry, prunes and other dark fruits.  body was medium-heavy with low-medium carbonation.  this is holding up rather well and will probably continue to do so.

Amber with an off-white head.  Surprisingly not a lot of head.  Peppery, funky nose with a hint of body odor but not in a bad way.  Very tart, very funky.  Pretty fruity and a little bit sweet but still dry and crisp.  A most excellent beer.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 new batch of 2009
almost no head !
colour was dark brown to red , and clear
smell was pretty sour almost like a geuze , hints of bubblegum (?) something sweet at least but not like any kind of sugar or honey
slightly alcoholic and a bit of citruspeel bittenres smell , reminded me a bit of a barley wine 
taste was : anis , slighlty sour compared to how sour it smelled ! some spices like u find in glühwein , candy sirup ( just a bit ) and malty+hopy
very good and surprisingly beer 

2007 aged version @ kulminator 
head: thin , creamy 
colour: red/brown to black 
smell: dairy, sour, lambic, skunky, corky 
taste: grapes, granny smith, corky, port like, blue berrys, dry end 
appearance: 4/5
aroma: 9/10 
taste: 8/10 
palate: 2/5 
overall: 16/20

Garrsh De Dolle... this is one of those that gets better with every sip until the last one--then you feel bad for not having another bottle, then you feel bad for not buying a case and aging them a little longer. Perfect sour factor, totally unique beer--the barrel aging is magically subtle unlike so many brutally oaked American beers. NAT & STRAF!

Thanks to savvy982 for the share. Drank this while watching the gold medal hockey game. Pours a muddy brown with orange highlights. Aroma is extremely floral and sharp. Plums, candi sugar, sour candy, and grape skin on the nose. The flavor is a cross between a Flemish brown and a good quad. Fruity and tart. Plum, pineapple, floral, grape, oak, apples, cranberries and other flavors. Fantastically complex.
2007 edition. Bottle, shared with Rudolf & Frylock. deeper copper pour. huge aroma of cherry Spree candy & Belgian funk. Flavors of Spree & sweetarts. Liquid candy. Delicious

Big thanks to Jedwards for this beer, awesome. I had been wanting to try this for awhile and Ive never seen it on the shelves in Colorado. Dark amber-brown-bruin, flanders on steroids. That is exactly how I would describe this beer. It smells nice, sour, a little glue and band-aids. the taste is a little sour and malty, really like a strong flanders red or oud bruin (what do I know). My only complaint would be the abv.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-28-2010 04:42:02

Vintage 2006. Pours brown with a little red tinge and a decent sized off-white head that quickly fades into nothingness. Aroma is of dark fruits, tartness, oak - smells a lot like a Abbey Dubbel with more alcohol and tartness in the background. Taste is of initial sour vinegar with a tart fruit background that transitions into a dry heavy aftertaste. This hides the alcohol very well and is quite interesting, but not as good as I thought it would be, the bottle may have gone bad.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2010 Vintage 2008. Pours a dark reddish brown with a very thin off-white head (gone in seconds). Aroma: raisin, subtle wood & earth notes, prune, alcohol, sour & sweet... slightly musty too. Taste: prune, wood, sour, slightly sweet... all with a wine like character. Very lively in the mouth... but smooth. After taste is tart with a alcohol warmth. Great body. 13% ABV is very well hidden... I could smell it but not taste it. Overall excellent: complex but very well balanced.  I want a bottle for the cellar now. De Dolle Brouwers are the best!

Aged a few months in casks of lambic, apparently in Cantillon (stop me if Im  wrong).

Wonderful taste ! Contains the woodness and the acidity of a Gueuze plus prune flavors. ,Very complex and rich beer. Unctuous, strong, delicious

Cherry and apple nose. Cloudy brown, thick beige head. Tart cherry and pecan flavor, with cider vinegar accents. Slight mustiness. Alcohol content magnified. Ive heard people rave about this beer, but Im not impressed. If I wanted a lot of alcohol in a kriek, Id just add vodka to some Lindemans.

Nice amber/brown pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is nice dark brown sugar, and dates. A sour cherry like flavor with a tart after taste and a little warmth. A bit foamy but full bodied. Not really what I had hoped this would be.
Vintage 2008. Dark brown with a low head. Aroma of de dolle yeast, citrus, wood, earth, sugar, alcohol. Citric flavours almost sour with notes of caramel, lemon and wood. Quite special ...

Special Reserve 2006.  Pours hazy copper color with thin off-white head.  Clean malty nose with a hint of grapes and Bret.  Sourness right up front, finishes clean then it drys your mouth a bit.  Malt is a minor flavor component but provides enough support to balance sourness.  No clue this was 13%, very well hidden.  This was a great surprise as I was not aware this was a sour ale.   Really well done, well balanced and just the right amount of sour bite.  Wish I could have more of this.

Very interesting beer.  Pours a chocolate brown color with a decent head.  Nice lacing around the glass.  Has an aroma of vinegar and hint of cherries and caramel.  Very sour taste with a dry finish.  A sour ale.  I would say this beer is interesting, and definitely the best sour ale I have had.  It is even better than Duchesee de Bourgogne.  Really grows on you.

2008 Bottle. Very dark brown colour. A bit of a small head, but holds longer then expected. Sweet-sour smell with some cherish, but something weird inside also. A bit like "superglue" aroma inside, like its not natural. Tasting was like a shock in my mouth, very sour cherish/oak taste. Way to sour for my taste. And the sourness holds for a very long time. I really dont understand the hype around this beer. Cause the taste is "special"? :)

Bottle 2008 from plovmand. Thanks a lot! 
Wow, this is good stuff! 
It pours a dark mahogany colour with tan head that quickly disappears. A pleasant sour - balsamic vinegar, oak, prunes and raisin aroma hits the nose. 
The flavour is a bit sour and balsamic at first but then the oak, prunes and raisins takes over and what a fantastic smooth aged port like after taste!
Waiter 1 more please..

2008 bottle. Pours a dark bourgundy red with a nice beige color head.
Aroma of dark fruits, cherries, liquor, oak, wine and spices.  Flavors is wow very complex, lots of macerated dark sour cherries, very oaky and old wine, notes of whiskey, yeast and spices.  Low carbonation, very sour and bitter, creamy, very long lasting sour cherry wine in mouth.  Very complex, some different tastes as you drink.  Not easy to drink, a very heavy and warm beer.  Drink this one very slowly, very powerfull flavors.  What a fantastic brew.  Cant drink that everyday, but I want more.
Its a great winter beer, before I drink this, I was cold, now I finished I am very warm, nice.

2006 bottle. Pours dark brown with white head, aroma is oak, funk, and musty earth.  Taste is chocolate hints with funky dark fruit with some oak.  Aged extremely well, awesome and complex, would love to have again.
2008. Sour. Brown ale. Tangy. Rich caramel taste. Cherry dominates.  Im getting a lot of complexity in this brown/sour. Outstanding.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: The aroma is sour and tangy and resembles a lambic or kriek. Appearance was murky and a dark brown color with a little red transparency. It did create a thick layer of fluffy foam but glad it went down in a couple of minutes. The flavor is extremely tart and sour with a touch of sweetness; however, I have reason to believe this is because of an old bottle, but there are still some minor signs of what used to be of this ale. Such flavors to be found are traces of cigar tobacco, plum, dried apple, and a medicine like syrup taste. To bad I wasnt able to taste the wood barrel since it has been drowned out by the taste of dead yeast and a huge loss of CO2.

Poured reddish brown with a light tan head. Moderatley carbonated almost like a soda when poured directly into itself. Nose is oak, sour cherry, vanilla, and whiskey. Taste is similar with a red wine tinge, and added Belgian yeast, as well as a dry finish (much like red wine). A delicious beer, must cellar another. Thanks De Dolle!
UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 Bottle. Pours rusty brown. Great pungent nose, sour oak & cherries. Smoked caskwood, great acidity. Drinkable, drinkable, drinkable. Very good beer.

2008 vintage; 330 ml bottle; clear reddish brown with thin light tan head settling to a creamy film; dark fruits, vanilla, whiskey, oak and very sweet on the nose; warm and fuzzy oaky sour notes; wow, sticky, sweet and strong; very oaky and dry; maybe a tad too much for me at first, but grows on me as it warms; lovely creamy texture with lots of spice, yeast, red wine, sugary fruits; would be interested in checking out an aged vintage
