Aroma was nice typical Belgian, very malty with dark fruit.  Taste, however, was VERY sour.  I’m not a fan of sour ales at all, so I didn’t enjoy this.  Very tart, sour, and acidic.  Not what I expected.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 All four vintages tasted in a vertical, many thanks to ucrusty.  Bright amber brown pour with red tint.  05 was darker than the others.  Yellow/tan head.  Not as gushy as some other De Dolles Ive had.  02 showed some oxidation, but the others were great.  Big oaky barnyard, leather, some cherry pits.  Vinegar.  Very good, though I think I prefer the regular Oerbier.  Maybe Im oaked out. RERATE: Damn, not sure what I was thinking in the earlier review.  Drinking the 2007 now and its amazing.  Dark, muddy pour with beautiful yellow-beige thick head.  Just as described above, but pretty amazing that this big flavor hides such a huge abv.  Fantastic.

Pours a hazy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is sour, cherries, sugars, yeasts, and some earthy wood. Flavor is oak, sourness, cherry, yeasts, candi sugars. Nice carbonation, tingly mouthfeel not overly sweet and subtle yet pleasant flavors are present in this one. Good brew.

Bottle 33 cl, Brewed 2007. Pours a deep clear brown with a light off white head. Nose tippicaly Dolle....a bit vinoes though. I very sour taste with strong notes of vinigar and lemon...actually i dont like it...it tastes infected. The aftertaste is not there....disappointed

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 33 cl, brewed in 2007, bottled 2008. Opaque chocolate brown with a large head that settles to three-quarter inches of lasting cream, leaving nice frosty lace. Aromas of soured light fruit and cider vinegar, musty leather, and dark fruit. Flavor is dominated by vinegar and tart cherry, with almost a hint of raisin and brown sugar. Medium body is smooth and creamy, with an acetic acid tingle and dryness.

Pours deep chestnut brown. Aroma is sour apples, dark fruit and typical Belgian yeast, in great form. Flavor is tart with vinegar, red wine, cherry, and oak. A lingering acidic finish is nice, and gives way to lots of rich cheese. Where is that 13%???? This is awesome.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2010 2004 Bottle via sloth.  I figger that he keeps on sending me all these funky Belgian thingys and I inundate him with stouts and crap from my travels. Pours a brown tinges with ruby and has a greenish tan head that settles to ring the tulip well.  Nose is of heavily caramelled malts and wet oak with a hint of apples. Body is light to medium and quick.  Tartness swiftly breaks to two distinct levels on the the tounge and merge for a sour apple finish.  Not really my cup of tea but i did enjoyed the 180 nose to body twist.  
2010:  Bottle at the second beer tasting night.  Gentle dark fruit nose, whispers of brandy too.  Pleasant sourness fully replaces hop aspect. 
tingly throughout.  Still.  No head.  This was much better the second time around and rose .3

Brewed 2006, Darker blond coloured beer with a large off-white head and some light carbonation. Strong light sour sweet malty and roasted aroma. Full creamy light sour palate. Finish is bitter sour malty, roasted caramel touched. Very nice balanced. Superb.

2005 Bottle - my #1500 rating: Poured a deep dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is strong with dark fruits, woods, and wine characteristic. Taste is nice fruit with a wood bite, finish is dry with a caramel twist. I’m glad I waited for a memorable time to drink this one. This aged perfect in my mind, can’t wait to try versus a fresher one.

Edition 2007.
Dark brown, amber colored brew. Fruity, wine-like, bourbon aroma. Flavor is yoghurt, wine/bourbon, fruity and sour. Some oak and yeast. Nice.

2006 bottle:  Pour is a dark ruby/brown with a light fizzy head.  Aroma is of dark sweet fruit, alcohol, and a sour character.  Flavor is damn good with cherries, oak, malt, apples, and alcohol.  Carbonation seems just about right.  Alcohol is prevelent but not over-powering.  The body is surprisingly light due to the addition of belgian sugar.  Real good brew.  Would buy again.

Pours a hazy reddish brown with a big off white head. Some dark fruit, cherries, tart green apples in the aroma as well as some spice. Big complex flavor of dark fruit and sour apple balanced with a malty sweetness and a hint of oak. A touch of tartness in the finish.  Another fine brew from De Dolle.

Vintage 2005.  Thanks to Puzzl ( and everybody else that gave me all the vintages) for this! Dark garnet pour with fizzy tan head.   Tart aroma.  Full bodied and very complex.  Nice and acidic flavor.  Green apples upfront,  grape on the finish. notable hints of oak, yeast, and caramel, Very dry

Bottle. Pours deep ruby with a beige head. Yeasty and vinous aroma with red grapes and green apple. Flavor has a bit of sourness and is quite dry. More apples and yeast. Nice, but I like the original Oerbier better.

(2007 version) Deep dark red brown colored with medium sized light brown head. Vinous aroma with chocolate, spices and yeast also present. Mild glue distracts here. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also vinous with biting lemony yeast, same glue here. Aftertaste dries with yeast. Slight disappointment.

Bottle.   Pours a hazy reddish-brown color with a decent soapy white head.   Aroma is vinegar, light malts, grapefruit.   Flavor is oak, vinegar, some wine like notes, tart grspefruit.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished tart and very refreshing.   Excellent beer!   I could easily drink this all day every day!

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2013 2006 bottle sampled summer 08.
The cap pops with small burst of foam and the beer pours a beautiful red-brown with a nice head. Strong malty aroma with ample sour vinegar and wood. Lovely and hugely complex flavor, very woody, malt vinegar, tannic red wine, acidic grapefruit juice and pith, incredible depth and complexity of flavor and a finish with mouth-puckering tannins that go on and on and on. Very little evidence in the mouthfeel of the 13%, I would have thought more like 8-9%! Terrific strong, somewhat-sour beer that really comes into its own as it approaches room temperature. 9/4/8/4/17=4.2

2006 bottle tasted Sept 2013. Pretty much as described above. Rich aroma of vinegar and wood, hints of cherry. Flavors as before, a bit of cheese. Heat comes super-late, as in minutes after the sip. Id put the taste above the aroma this time, and the beer ends up in the 4.0-4.2 range again. I dont see the need for 13% here. 8/4/9/4/15=4.0. Ill split the difference.

Aroma of cherries, plum, green apple, and red wine.  Extremely complex.  This is a powerhouse of flavor.  Very tart/astringent.  Large off white head with good lacing.  Very murky body with small particles floating.  It is hard to see the particle because the beer is so murky.  Dark brown in color.  Medium to full body.  Dry texture with decent carbonation.  Enjoy very slowly the warmer the better.

2006. Pours a murky dark bronze with a wonderful, pillowy beige head. Aroma is incredibly enticing. Tart cherries at the front, followed by vanilla and nutmeg, a bit of grapefruit, grapes, caramel and just a bit of oak. Taste is tart cherries (brett), balanced with bready, doughy, sweet caramel malts. A bit of tart (unripe) strawberry. This is strikingly like what I imagine a blend of SB Abt 12 and Duchesse sour red would be like. This one would cellar incredibly well, and while wonderfully different now, would be incredible if given time to mellow.

2007. Pours deep brown with a creamy yet disappearing tan head. Stron vinous and peppery aroma, fruity, caramel. Very vinous, vinegary, fruity, with a very light body and no traces of 13%. Seems to me a spontaneous brew. Don’t know if it were as expected to be, but above all I’ve enjoyed it.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 ~RBSG 08~

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish hue, thick foamy head, white lacing on the glass. Tart aroma, funky cherries, some roasted malts, sweet nute, chocolate. Very sweet and sour at the same time. Grapes, currant, oak, brown sugar, light caramel, and some clove, albeit distant. Very smooth. Nice bitter finish, balanced well. Alcohol is absent. 

Rerate: my favorite sour. omg

Bottle. [thank you, KimJohansen]
Vintage 2004
My 3.400th rating!!
Enjoyed at cellar temperature. Pours a striking deep red with a slight haziness. On top sits a fine, frothy yellowish-beige head. Incredible aroma: Apples, strawberries, sherry, caramel, light liquorice, vanilla, coriander, oak, thyme and a doughy character. Low carbonation, wonderful frothy mouthfeel. Flavour is heavy, lots of viniousness, good, fresh strawberries and a definite oaky sourness at the back of my mouth. Damn! It is so easy to drink! The oak really settles in the aftertaste, mixing in some liquorice, warmth, caramel and just a long, lingering, warming tartness. Another Dolle masterpiece.

Wow!  This is definitely one of the stronger and more complex aromas Ive experienced throughout my beer ratings.  Sour apple, lemon, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla, oak, and light bread crumbs.  Interesting brew, tart with a sweeter fruitiness and toffee in the background with a slightly metallic finish.  An interesting experiment for sure.  Well crafted, although personally I would prefer the sourness to be toned down a bit.  It would allow some of the other complexities of this beer to shine.

Bouteille de 330 ml acheté chez Julio’s Liquors (Westborough, MA). Arôme: Odeur de mélasse fruitée et de chêne. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée rougâtre avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un moyen col beige crémeux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de petits fruits foncés avec une pointe de vanille. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût fruité. (Rating #1852)

2006 bottle.

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark mahogany-hued body with a wispy, off-white head.

Smell: Fruity, vinous aroma with notes of cherries, sherry, malt vinegar, and old wood.

Taste: A touch of sweet maple with a juicy, tart, and sour taste of black cherries and grape jam. Sip of sherry vinegar. Some rampant alcohol, some woodiness. Dry, nearly puckering finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-low carbonation. Slight oiliness to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Good enough for one visit, I suppose, but it ultimately seemed a bit overrated and subsequently overpriced.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2011 33cl, Vintage 2010, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, very heavy, yet balanced, hazy, good head, the best of the Dolle Brouwers, top class!, yet expensive, drink chilled

2007 bottle at Kulminator.
Its a beauty! A reddish brown beer with a creamy long lasting beige head. 
Aroma is pretty sour with dark fruits and cherries. 
Flavour is the same with caramel and some berries.
Great mouthfeel.

Two bottles courtesy of fishingnet and tpd975. Pours brownish amber copper with tan head. The aroma is full with loads of wild yeast fighting it out creating tartness and sour rotting lemons, notes of wood and faint vanilla. I also get some grapes and cherries too. The taste has a quick pulse of sweetness that quickly fades away leaving behind tartness and mild sourness. It seems the sour rotting fruit grows momentarily before extreme tartness takes over. The tartness finally lets up a bit in the finish as I can get vague fruitiness around the edges. Zero sense of the ABV (was this an NA brew?).

Hazy brown pour with a small tan head.  Aroma was vinegar and heavy oak.  Flavor was up front cobwebs and dust, plenty of oak and vanilla and a pronounced candy flavor that really stood out and made this unique from other sour style beers.  Finished with a mild to medium acidity,  very complex.  I really liked this one.

Bottle, 2006 vintage. Pours a cloudy brown with a small tan head. Aroma is banana, yeast, bit of molasses, hint of wood and vanilla. Taste starts a bit sour, with some dark malt in there as well, moving to a more pronounced, biting acidity and tartness on the finish, with a lingering dark vinous quality. Mouthfeel is just enough crispness to complement the acidity, while maintaining a nice creaminess. Very interesting beer from a fearlessly inventive brewery.

[’06 Bottle] Pours murky dark amber-brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is cherry, banana, yeast, vinous red wine character, wood, a bit of brown sugar and a hint of alcohol. Taste is lightly sour up front with very subdued bitterness, more red wine and barrel very present and some yeast. Not nearly as fruity as the aroma. Medium mouthfeel, smooth, with a long dry red wine finish. A very nice beer--although I am partial to wine barrel aging.

2006 version. Murky orange/ reddish beer with a dense beige head. Fruity, light tart aroma with a dusty note. Lovely fruity / tart flavor with a very nice cherry note and some yeastyness. Dry, light earthy finish.

2005 Version.  Had at Delerium Cafe in Brussels on 6/22.  Initially wouldn’t sell the bottle because it was off menu.  Pours dark amber with a medium tan head. Aroma of wine, winter spice, dark fruits, vanilla.  taste has a stong vineous quality that settles as the beer warms.  Hides the alcohol extremely well, only appearing on the finish. This beer is right up my alley, complex and delicious.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a one finger light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of cherrie pie, tons of funky wild yeast, oak, and a hint of vinegar. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and a moderate amount of acidity. The alcohol is very well hidden. Very good.

2006 bottle courtesy of tpd975 & fishingnet.
Pours light brown/caramel. Aroma is light oak, few sediments. Taste yeasty with some barnyard/cheese notes, light tartness. I noticed some spices, maybe a little peppery. Overall it is a very enjoyable beer, hadr to notice the 13%

12oz bottle. Out of the bottle this looks like it could jump to the top of my list. Awesome dark mahogany color with a dense tan head. Huge nose of cinammon, sour funk, fruit and smoked gruyere. Big tart sourness up front, with spicey clove and cinnamon notes. The is the lighter side of a huge BSA. You definitely can feel the alcohol but at 13% thats not suprising. Its about as well hidden as you can reasonably expect. Vanilla, Caramel, Wood and Cheese notes come out as the beer warms. This is an incredible beer and I definitely have to age one now because I suspect in 5 years this beer will be absolutely astonishing. One of my new top beers. A masterpiece.

Bottle.  2006 Vintage.  It pours a dark ruddy amber in color with a small lacey head.  The aroma is tart, woddy, and bit citrusy.  I am starting to expect more of a Flanders Ale than a Strong.  The flavor almonst identically matches the aroma to a t.  As this beer warms, the flavors mellow quite a bit and becomes much more welcoming on the palate.  This is definitely a beer that grew on me.

Bottle needlessly hauled back from Stumbling Monk in Seattle (they were stocking it at Lucky Baldwins).  This is an unusual brew.  Vaguely reminiscent of a barrell-aged Vertical Epic 07.  Opens oddly, tartly - unripe burnt citrus peel.  The body somehow gets lighter - more like a thin trippel - but keeps its aged mellowness.  Finish is very aromatic and almost instant.  A beer that you have to have 3 times to love.

33cl bottle courtesy of Markwise. Pours a cloudy honey-caramel-yellow color with a thin tan head. Clearly visible particulates floating about. Aroma of ripe fruit, notes of merlot, oak, faint molasses. Taste is initially tart with hints of apple, pear, cheese (maybe smoked gouda?), and malty notes. Slightly bitter finish that is reminiscent of a sour flemmish ale. Very interesting and complex ale.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 [Bottle] I obliterated my first rating because I was a total noob at that point. I didnt want to open another bottle quite yet as Im going through the Pannepot, but I will fill this in with more descriptive notes once I have it in front of me. This is a freaking ridiculous beer.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2009 Bottle. Vintage 2005. Pours reddish brown with a dense off white head. Smells a little infected.. Aromas of vinegar, wood and berry fruit. Flavour is sour with notes of berries and vinegar tartness.

5-4-3-2-9 = 2,3


Bottle. Vintage 2008. Pours deep brown coloured with a very small off white head. Stinging sour aroma with notes of cherries, balsamic vinegar, wet wood, caramel, dark fruit and ammonia/salmiak. Tart flavour with notes of rubber, dried fruit, tannins, caramel and zest. Great stuff.

9-3-8-3-17 = 4

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2008 Bottle. Had the 2002 version in 2007 this is really something special something incomperably incredible in comparison.  A great vinous woodiness and sour funk.  Sweet and sour with the etoh in the background.  Some apple and a big warming thats well settled. AWESOME beer!!

Bottle 2006 courtesy of winter 07 secret santa. Good fruit nose along with some mild sour some wooden barrel  aromas. Deep red body with thin head. Sour mild spice notes were most prvelant but some sweet caramel sweetener to blanance it out. Rather smooth brew on the palate. Alcohol well hidden good brew.

06 Bottle Courtesy ucusty, pours deep mahogany with a thin tan head. The nose is full with dried summer fruits, caramel, sour cherries and red wine. The flavor is similar, but more sugars and tart fruit influence, and less port like wine, which was good as far as Im concerned. A woodsy, nutty finish, followed by considerable ABV heat. This reminds me of a strong Sour, especially when "drawn" in rather than poured into the mouth. The additional air gives a more mellow, nutty experience.

2005 Vintage Bottle, courtesy of pantanap. Thanks Kan, you rock man. Dark brown pour with transparent red edges. An initial beige microbubble head builds, then settles to elegant lacing for the remainder of the glass. Very nice aromatics going on; the Bordeaux barrels add a sweet vinous touch to this beer. Aroma is of tart raspberry and light acetic / vinegar tones above the oak wood, which is much restrained. Raisin fruitcake, plum and clove character of regular Oerbier are still there, but with a puckering dry red wine addition. Very good, but I think I like the two equally as much. Still very carbonated for having 3 years on it. No noticeable signs of oxidation, this could be bomb at 5 or 6 years.
An incredible beer. Dark, ruby red in appearance. Slightly tart, and carbonated with hints of oak in the background. This is a dleicious Belgian Flanders Red.

2006 vintage, bottled June 2007 and consumed June 2008.  Pours a gorgeous looking, clear, burgundy colored body.  A frothy, cream-colored head settles slowly to a thin blanket that lingers.  Semi-sticky flares and patches of lacing gradually dry out, holding fast to the glass walls.  The aroma is nothing short of world class.  The vinous scent shows notes of sour cherries, pinot noir, semi-sweet blackberries, funky oak, and a dry, bretty overtone.  Flavors include juicy, sweet-tart cherries, soft red wine aged in old, funky oak barrels, vanilla, and brett.  Finishes semi-dry and tannic.  Medium-plus bodied and moderate to softly carbonated, it even drinks almost like a red wine.  Reminds me of a blend of 2005 Bon Chien with regular Oerbier.  What a fantastic creation.  Definitely a bit young now, I will be aging as much of this as possible, as I can only see it getting better for years to come.

Bottle: pours a dark brownish-red with frothy white head, aroma of sour cherries and malt, taste is fairly sour but not overpowering, has a clean finish with just a hint of lingering sourness on the tongue.  Im a fan.

yeasty tan head with large bubbles. Hazy amber color. Aromas of strawberries, sour cherries, swwet malt, spice. A punch of sourness, sour stone fruits, complexities from the wine barrels mix with the beer flavors. A dry sour finish. A nice belgium.

Glass: Tulip
Purchased at: Circle Liquors, Pennington, NJ
Price: $6.99
Size:11.2 fl oz
ABV: 13%
Estimated Calories: 210 C
RateBeer Rating: 99

Aroma 8 out of 10
Intensity: Strong
Balance: Sharp
Impression: Nice

Malt Flavor: Grapes Cherries

Hops Flavor:Resin
Other:Fruit
Notes: Very much like a red wine. Not a fan.

Appearance 3 out of 5
Color: Black
Clarity: Cloudy
Head Retention: Poor
Notes: Nothing special to look at.

Flavor 8 out of 10
Intensity: Strong
Balance: Bitter
Impression: Off
Malt Flavor: grapes
Hops Flavor: HerbalResin
Other: cherries
Notes: For one of the best beers in New Jersey, Im sorely disappointed. Again, this thing sprayed all over, tastes not so great, and costs $7 for a 11.2 fl oz container.

Palate 3 out of 5
Mouthfeel
Sensation: Drying Warming
Body: Full
Carbonation: Faint
Finish
Length: Long
Intensity: Strong
Balance: Bitter
Notes: Not a bad finish, but getting there is hard to do. Alcohol not hidden well at all.

General Impression: 10 out of 20
Craftmanship: Interesting, but not to my taste.
Freshness: Stale
Personal Taste: Disliked
Notes: I wished so much that this had been better. It took 20 minutes to open due to the overcarbonation and potential yeast problem, then 5 minutes for cleanup, then drinking it was a bit of a chore, like drinking wine. Lots of better ways to spend $7.

[1136-20080229] 11.2floz. Mild generic grains aroma has a sour background hint. Clear, dark dark red brown body with a long-lasting super creamy dark off-white head. Sour mild malt is more noticeable in the flavour with sweet yeast. Medium-full body has both sweet and sour characteristics. Quite nicely made.
(Vintage 2006 @ Kulminator; Antwerp, BE; w/ jerc)

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2010 (Re-rate, bottle - 2009 vintage, at Ølbaren) Poured dark brown and almost clear. Head was small and white. Aroma contained sourness, berries and malts. Palate was medium bodied and warming with quite high carbonation. Flavours were sourness, malts, berries, sweetness, fruitiness and bitterness. Aftertaste contained sourness and berries.

Old rating, 2006 Vintage at Kulminator on 2008: 7-3-7-3-15=3.6

This poured an amber to dark brown appearance with a moderate sized head. The aroma is sour cherries, nutmeg, apples, and vinegar. The flavor is quite sour with some granny smith apples, cherries, lemons, and a healthy does of vinegar. Some caramel presence as well. It has a woody character to it. Overall an awesome beer!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 2006 bottle.  Pours a hazy deep amber brown with a dense one-finger head that shows great retention and lacing.  Initial smell is a blast of sour cherry tartness with a solid underlying malt sweetness.  Also got a whiff of cola and a bit of the oak.  Taste starts with a very temporary malt sweetness that almost immediately gives way to a big sour citrus taste dominated by lemons and oranges.  The finish is big on sour cherries and lingers for a long time.  Mouthfeel is extremely crisp and the 13% ABV is masked extremely well.  Strong carbonation just zips the tongue with the sour tanginess.  As far as sours go (not my favorites), this one is extremely drinkable.  For lovers of sours, this one is highly recommended.

2006 bottle.  Muddy brown with orange hints and a beige head.  Aroma is sweet candy sugar, dark fruit, and some tart fruit.  Flavor is more dominated by tart / ripe fruit, the sugary nature is less apparent.  Overally, I like this mix of dark sweet belgian beer with slightly sour fruit.  Good and original.

2006 bottle: Pours a dark caramel, rust brown with a small but lingering tan head. Intense cracker aroma from 2 feet away. Up close smells much more of sour fruit falling off the pit its so ripe, Belgian yeast, and some spicy malts. Wow, that one will make you pucker. Very strong overripe and sour sour fruit (sour cherries). Also some excellent caramel qualities. Highly acidic body leads to a very tart, lingering citrus finish. No hint of the 13% ABV

Big thanks for the trade on this one. Bottle 2006 pours out a hazy brow with some red. Topped with a very small tan head. A great aroma of sour cherry and some other maybe pit fruit. Tast is sour with a littler bitter puker. Some sweetness very tasty.

Pours a beautiful red rusty caramel color with an average head, and average lacing and slightly under carbonated. Smells extremely sour with hints of fruit. First taste is extremely bitter and sour hints of green apples come through.  The 13% ABV is very well hidden.

2006 Bottle.  Purchased from Knightly Spirits.  This beer poured brown with an off-white head.  It had a bunch of sour bright fruit notes, with a sweet and sour finish.  Lively and fruity with alcohol and sugar, overall it was very good.

330 ml bottle with a big thank you to The_Epeeist foir sending this in a trade.  2005 edition.  Pours a very cloudy rust color with a massive off-white head that settled into a thin, creamy topping by mid-glass and left a thick sheet of lace with each sip.  Very pleasant aroma of sour cherries and tart green apples with notes of yeast and alcohol present as well.  The flavor is equally enjoyable with sour cherries and tart green apples.  A bit of sweet malt helps keep this from being excessively sour. The alcohol is extremely well hidden with no trace of it, even as the beer warms.  An excellent beer.

11.2oz bottle.  Brewed 2006, bottled June 07.  Pours a murky orange color with a generous off-white head.  Looks fairly carbonated.  Head recedes though never disappears.  Aroma is sweet candy, very light funk (reminds me of Jolly Pumpkin), light sour cherries, green apple, quite sweet.  Very nice aroma.  Taste is very fruity though kind of dry, fairly tart with a peppery, oaky finish.  The longer I drink this the better it becomes.  Ive had some success (and some failure) at aging JPs La Roja and when it is good it reminds me a lot of this.  This is just fantastic.

12oz bottle.  2006 vintage.  purchased at west lakeview.... pours a dark reddish brown with a creamly light brown head.... aroma of soft oak tartness.  light vanilla and sweeter malt..... awesome flavor of very mellow tartness coming by way of oak.  hugely creamy mouthfeel and i cant detect any of the 13% which is amazing.  highly drinkable and very much enjoyed.

Bottle shared at Dark Lord Day 08.  Pours a dark color with a thin white head.  Has very complex smells to it.  I cant completely make them all out.  I get dark fruit, oak, alcohol, and yeast.  Taste is very complex with fruits upfront, some malt, bready taste, and has a sour finish.  Nice brew.

2006.  Reddish amber color, clear, with a thick creamy head.  Zesty and slightly sour smelling.  Minty and woody, a little alcohol comes through.  Some vanilla and toffee in there, quite a subtle and complex nose.  Sour beer - pithy citrus, oak, a little salty.  Smooth clean and dry finish.  Hugely interesting.  Another great De Dolle beer.

Very nice beer.  Pours a dark amber brown with a minimal head and some lacing.  Smells like cherry/fruity oak.  Sour flavor with oakey fruit and a dry, slightly bitter finish.  This is my favorite from this brewer yet.

Ive talked with the "brouwers" a little and they show me that nice beer. Dark amber color under a small head. Aroma of the oak barrel, some sour cherry. Complex body with some sour taste, aroma of the wood barel. Dry finish.
Bottle. Pours dark amber with an off-white head. Sweet-tart cherry-grape toffee taste with a dry woody finish. A great little beer to sip. Seems like theres a bit of alcohol, but nothing nea 13%.

2006 Version - Dark brown with red highlights, thin foam coats the beer throughout and some lacing.  Strong cherry vinegar aroma.  Im not getting the complexity noted in other reviews.  Even after warming, Im getting harsh cherry vinegar notes with just a slight note of wood.  Really harsh vinegar, acetic acid flavors overwhelm the beer.  I dont remember the normal Oerbier being this overpowering.  Just not my thing.
2006 vintage, 330ml bottle. Pours cloudy copper in color with full foamy brown head. Aroma sweet, fruity and yeasty. Taste of tart cherries, sweet cherries and yeasty with dry finsih.

2006 version. Cloudy amber, brown, rust colored, thin wispy head. Aroma of malts, cask, pear with hints of cherry, vanilla, and others. Luscious malt complexities throughout, big acetic, sourish, vinous blast but that malt sweetness keeps it under control. Alcohol nowhere in the picture, not sure how that works at 13%. Could have a bit more body but screw it.l If you consider yourself a conisseuer of fine beer, especially belgiums, you are missing out if you havent had this.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2013 11.2 oz. 2006 bottle poured into a Trappist glass has a dark muddy brown color with a thick layer of tan head leaving a pillow on the surface. aroma of malt, grape skins, champagne, oak, some sour fruit, and cherry. taste is mid range in body but just fills the mouth from the frothing carbonation. sour twang with some grape skin acid drying out to finish sour with malted body and wood. quite full in flavor and the wood really gives it a nice core without being smoky at all. there is something to be said for the balance of wood, sweetness, and sour here as it was done perfectly and the alcohol is hardly noticeable until you go looking for it. a very good beer that without rate beer top lists i would have never found.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Re-rate 4/1/12: Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. 2008 bottle. Murky brown color.  Aroma of malt, cookies, dark fruits, oak and some bretty hints. Complex sourish-sweetish flavor with some malt, dark fruits, oak and some musty funk. Rounded mouthfeel. 7/3/8/4/16=3.8

Re-rate 12/7/11: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. 2008 bottle. Thanks beerandbeyond. Brown-colored with a beige head. Acidic aroma with lots of wood, a bit of brett, lots of fruits (some cherries and others), some malt and cookie notes. Sourish-sweetish flavor with oak, lactic notes, malt and fruits. Finishes dry. Full silky body. No alcohol flavor. Wonderful! 8/3/9/5/17=4.2

(3/4/08) Bottle at Kulminator in Antwerp. 2004 bottle. Dark reddish amber with a medium stable beige head and beautiful carbonation. Wonderful aroma of wood, malt, some caramel, some pleasant soft fruitiness and light spicy hints. Sweetish flavor with malt, some fruits (cherries, berries) and very nice oak sourness. Medium to full body. Really balanced with almost no alcohol presence. Very complex and quite amazing. 9/5/8/4/18=4.4

2005 vintage.  Pours a deep brown rusty orange with a medium beige head.  Aroma of sourness, oak, cherries, yeast and tangy citrus.  Taste of sour oak, cherries, tangy citrus with a warming alcohol presence.  Alcohol very well hidden.
Metalic notes on the nose, but after that, pure bliss.   Great sourness counter balanced by a great sweet flavor.   Just enought alcohol to do it justice.  Dont know why I waited so long to try it.

2004 bottle from dmac.  Pours deep red with some tan colored head.  Complex nose of oak, brett, tannins, cooked sugar, and a little bit of a citrus mix.  Decidedly sour and oaky, with a grapefruit finish.  Medium body.  High carbonation.  Dry, tart, tannic, finish.  Worth the wait for sure.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 2006 bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Pours a cranberry color with an off-white small and persistent head with a little bit of lacing. Nice aroma of yeast, a citrus tang and butterscotch. Sour but smooth taste. Citrus, cherries, buttery finish. You definitely cant tell this is 13%. Damn, 13%? Good night!

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2008 Pours a dark reddish brown with very light head (note - I didnt pour it very well). Cant smell much, still getting over sickness, but really wanted to drink this, so I am. Taste is sour cherries, oak/wood, berries, hint of citrus. This was waaaaaaaaaaaay different than I was expecting. I dont know why, but I expected something more like Brasserie des Rocs Grand Cru. I thought this tasted more like a beefed up, 13% version of Supplication.....and I love me some Supplication. Would never have guessed that this beer was 10+% ABV, hides the alcohol incredibly well. If I was rich, Id drink this on the regular. Paid $7/bottle. This is my first De Dolle beer and I am highly impressed.

Bottle.  Pours a deep ruby/brown color with a huge, lacy white head,  Aroma is red grape, coriander, vanilla, apple, and oak - one of the nicest, most enticing aromas I have ever experienced with a beer.  The taste is sour cherry up front, with vanilla, oak, red grapes, and coriander also noticeable among this unbelievably balanced offering.  If I didnt know this was 13% alcohol I would never have guessed it based on tasting the beer; its deceptively smooth.  This is just an absolutely amazing offering from the wonderful folks at De Dolle, and Im very glad to have tried it.

for my 100th rating i splurged.  this beer is absolutely wonderful, a true gift from my favorite belgian brewery.  pours an esteemed roasted brown color with a cumulus cloud head.  it smells of coriander, apples, and oak.  notes of vanilla, grapes, cherries and pears.  the aging in the bordeaux barrels does wonders to smooth out the alcohol dominance of regular oerbier.  i love it, wish i could afford it more often and will someday make a special pilgrimage to diksmuide.

bottle @ the map room

2006 Pours a dark brown with a thin head, nice lacing. Aroma of berries and oak. Very tart, slightly sweet, some bitterness at the end. It will be interesting to see how this ages. Alcohol is hidden very well.

Thick dark brown pour with a nice white head.  Fruity sour grape and citrus aroma...very intense.  Nice sour start with a spicy bitter yet almost candy like finish.  Not as sour as some other beers, but balanced really well.  Hides the alcohol really well.  Very good!

Bottle.  Ive waited quite a while to have this, so Im fairly excited.  Pour is a thing of beauty.  Dark brown body with streams of little bubbles going up the side of the glass and leaving a two finger tan head.  Aromas are tart and have a little bit of a vinegar feel to them and mix with earthy/woody scents.  First sip is interesting and complex.  Tart cherry flavors dominate and intertwine with wood, earth and vinous undercurrents.  Alcohol is detectable and at times comes through a little bit to strongly, but this is inconsistent and not on every sip.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Brewed in 2004, bottled in 2005.

This is the third time I have typed this fu@#king review! If my computer messes up again I might destroy it. 

Poured into a tulip, this beer is a clear amber. Almost an inch of head sits atop. The nose is of tart berries and oak. 

This tastes great! The sharp tartness that dominated the regular Oerbier has been muzzled, perhaps by the oak. The sour apples and berries, the yeast, and the oak are seemlessly woven together. This beer is huge. 

The mouthfeel is top-notch. It is full bodied, but not coating like the regular Oerbier. Although there is still a blanket of foam on the beer, the carbonation is very soft. This beer is ready to drink now, but I wonder what some age will do to it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-23-2005 03:21:36

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 9 5 8 4 17 [2006 Vintage] 11.2 oz bottle Enjoyed 2.19.08. Pours dark amber/orange with fine bubbles and a small fine frothy white head.  Aroma of wild yeast , brown sugar and ripe fruit.  Whoa! That is not what I was expecting.  Tart,  sour cherries, acidic, sweet and blue-cheese like bitterness.  Tons of wood.   Really interesting stuff.  Crisp, light, fine tingly bubbles, not sticky.  Alcohol starts to come out a little bit at times. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

[brewed in 07 bottled in 08, 13%]  Enjoyed 10.7.08.  Pours a murky orange muddy brown with a very smooth silky beige head.   Sweet and sour aroma, tart balsamic vinegar, sweet cherries, some blue-cheese, light brown sugar and barrel.  Soooo tasty, seems a bit more tart than I remember, sour cherries with an edgy aged-cheese bitter barrel finish.   Excellent, glad I decide to open this now freshly bottled, and I appreciate it so much more than when I first started to rate beer.     9  5 10 4 19 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 

[07 bottle] Enjoyed 7.10.09.  yup this is just about my favorite beer... candied stinky funky cheesy sour tart deliciousness.  So close to perfect.  This is absolutely as close as beer comes to the very finest of red wines.

10.5.10.5.20 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
[08 bottle enjoyed 11.17.09]  Pours a dark glowing red with an orange tint and a huge tall foamy pillowy head that just sticks around like a fluffy cloud.  Aroma is fantastic, I do think I like it a bit fresher because its still got a lot of the sweetness hanging around, bright sweet funky varnish, cherry, acidic, oooo so fantastic, very woody this year with less cheese, actually a bit of creamy vanilla like Still Nacht.  O... o o o man... that is good.... way more acidic this year around, still quite sweet and relatively young, vanish, woody, cheese, vanilla, alcohol, much more aggressive than previous vintages, uncharacteristically assertive... again... always best at exactly room temp (not cellar)  =p... why do I always figure this out when there are only a few sips left  . .  10.5.9.5.18
. . . . . . . .. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
[07 bottle rated 1.14.10] absolute perfect, Ive been drinking some of the most amazing beers this week from the best brewers... and this beer is basically perfection, perhaps the best of all the bottles Ive opened. With each bottle I open it makes go out and purchase 6 more to replace it.  Wow, simply wow, this is the fullest of the bottles Ive opened, sour and round, an oud bruin, gorgeous absolutely gorgeous looking, simply perfect, I cant spend the time here describing it because I need to drink it.  Please serve this at cellar temp and no colder.... 10.5.10.5.20... perfection . . . . . . . . . . . .[07 bottle, drinking it while it seems to be peaking, 3.31.10] The aroma is absolutely perfect, super sour cherries.  Its really amazing the amount this is starting to taste like cherries, perfect oak barrel flavor, very sour, just a touch of the medicinal cherry but mostly tart cherry.  Amazing.  . . . . . . . [had another 07 bottle that was just nasty metallic iron bloody brett, didnt age at all like the other bottles.]. . . . . . . . . [07 bottle rated 10.14.10]  Aroma is quite the same, maybe a little more oxidation showing on the malts, rounding them out a tad with a touch of red apple, seemingly a little more acetic and acidic, still that lovely blue cheese like woodiness mixed with the tart cherries.  Yea, I think it might be confirmed, maybe these 07s have peaked earlier this year, the malt oxidation is showing too much now, also just a bit of iron taste coming through.  Carbonation and body are still perfect.  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[2009 bottle, bottled feb 2010 opened 12.28.10]  Pours different than I remember...?  clear ruby red with a tall white sudsy sticky airy foamy head... big soda bubbles... slightly confused on this vintage.  Aroma smells right though, fantastic wood, cheese, sour, Bordeaux, candied sweetness, fantastic mix of acetic and brett, o so near perfect.  Flavor is certainly young, reminds me a bit of when I tried these too fresh, although, who knows if this will end up living up to the 07 and 08 bottles which became super sour,  bit tannic at this point, sour cherries but not super sour, certainly on the sweet side for a reserva, love the cheesy cherry barrel taste, just a little rough right now but the right elements are there... lets see where it goes from here 9.4.9.4.17.  O... I forgot what was also so special about this beer... its 13% hahaha no other sour even comes close... but it wouldnt matter if it were 5%, this is still an amazing beer.

The Dan Journal #155.  12oz bottle.  Tasted 1/28/08.  Brewed 2006.  Bottled June 2007.  Filtered with a lively body.  Amber hue.  Beige head.  Musty and fruity aromas.  Woody and apples.  Cinnamon apricot and raisins in the nose.  Absolutely wonderful aromas!  Full bodied with a multi layered palate.  Initially bready then a citrus yeasty character.  Touch toffee, then blam...the tart and very bitter bret flavor.  Woody warming flavor.  Citrus and so very tart.  Wonderful rolling of the palate til the lingering finish.  Deliciously sticky with big citrus flavors.  WOW!

Thanks hophead75.  The color was dark amber.  The head was creamy, off-white, and thin.  The aroma was that of a flemish sour ale.  There were also notes of sweet cherry.  The flavor was sour, alcohol, cherry, and dry.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was tart.

Thanks hophead75 for the extra. Ive been wanting to try this bad boy for sometime now. 2006 version. Pours a dark reddish brown with a two finger creamy sticky orange head. The aroma is sour, tart, spicy, sweet, fruity, tart,vinous, red graps. The flavor is very tart and sour, clove and spice, sweet, not very much alcohol present, definitely barrel aged, vinous, grapes. The palate was tart and acidic with a nice full carbonation. Very nice belgian strong ale.

2006 bottle. Pours a deep red/brown with some haze that isnt distracting. Nice head that is red in color. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of cherry, oak, pears and tartness that tingles the nose. The taste is dominated by tartness, cherry and oak character. The finish is sour and dry. A very pleasant flanders beer that doesnt seem high alcohol at at. Excellent beer!

2006 Bottle: Dark brown color with medium diminishing cream head and some lacing. Strong fruity, vinous aroma. Flavor is extremely tart and sour which is entirely too dominant. I dont see the complexity- all sour cherries and not much else, no malts, no hops. More of a sour ale than anything. High abv made this slightly tolerable towards the end. Alcohol was well hidden, but only because the sourness was is in your face.

Overrated.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2009 33 cl bottle: 2006 vintage: Brilliant and deep garnet color with thin off-white head. The aromas coming off this glass are simply dazzling! A wonderfully tart, red wine drenched malt dances around with cherries, and other dark fruits, on a musty oak dance floor. After waltzing around with the aroma for a while, its time for the flavor to take the lead. Imagine a red-wine soaked peach grilled in a pan, served with a red grape, black cherry and balsamico reduction. Nice and tart but with many layers of flavors coming in waves but always ending on the red wine. Very enjoyable experience!

Special 2001 Chateau Neuf de Pape barrel. Served by the brewer himself. Bigger wood notes and vinous grapeskins and appleskins. Spicy sweetness behind bold red wine. Nice lactic and brett notes. A little underattenuated when compared to the normal. 9 4 8 4- 18 : 4.3

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2016 2006 bottle. Rich aromas of reddish fruits. Mahogany color with a tan head that wasnt strong. It did lace a bit. Rather thin in body with creamy/fizzy carbonation. The flavor is like thin red wine aged in oak. The woodiness tends to dominate the rest. Cherries and cherrie pits are likely. Its rather dry, woody and tart. Very sophisitcated ale. The finish is astringent and oaky. Vinous sour cherries. Just an incredibly tasty drink. /2008 version seems even better.

Pours a flat chestnut color, with an unripe aroma of red grapes and roses. Tastes tart and less rich and malty than expected.  The most prominent flavors are peach, plum and cherry.  The finish is more full than the beginning, and the lingering taste on the tongue is sour but pleasing.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 (bottle, thanks OSLO) Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Very sour aroma of tart cherry, with some wood notes and wine as well.  The flavor is quite sour, tart, with light oak notes.  Medium mouthfeel that works quite well for the beer.  I was not expecting the taste or smell to be what it is, but it was good anyways. Another sampling.  Poured dark brown with white head that lasted.  Aroma is just pure red wine, tannic, oaky, salty, just amazing.  The taste was also strong and vinous with a lot of tannin, but also just a bit of sweetness that differentiates it a bit from wine.  Taste does possess some cracked pepper too.  This is simply an amazing beer.

I preferred this to the standard Oerbier.  Dark brown color, promising a sweet, malty beer.  Surprising however, is the sour flavor with vinegar, almost a sour ale really.  Some light cherry and more balsamic.  Kind of rough, or rustic, on the palate.  Very unusual and good.

Bottled, 2006 vintage. A cloudy dark amber beer with a good and near creamy light brown head. The aroma has a lovely sourness and notes of wood, fruits (cherry, plum) and wine. The flavor has medium sourness and maltiness, with some light hops. You can find notes of sour cherry, wood and a vinous sensation. The alcohol is exremely and I repeat extremely well hidden. Only medium body, lively carbonation, quite long dry aftertaste that is medium tart and fruity. Incredibly complex beer and unbelievable this is 13% ABV. A great beer.

MN Winter RB gathering.  Thanks OLSO for sharing.  POurs a nice rich reddish brown.  Lots of spice here.  Anise, brown sugar, ripe and dark fruits and a touch of tart apple.  FLavor echoes the nose with a nice tart finish.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: 2006 bottle shared by OSLO. Aroma of mint, black liquorice, candy canes and a woody tartness. Pours thick , viscous amber with no head. Flavor was slightly tart. Some cherry, wood, soy and caramel. Lively carbonation with a tart, woodsy finish.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2008 2006 bottle at Uber in Seattle. Deep garnet color with small head and sporadic lace. Intense nose of berry, hop, earth, and cake. Absolutely stunning. Flavors include sour, bitter mingling together in an interplay that remains pure and unadulterated--just when it borders on being strange it comes back to reality. Like drinking a blackberry/chocolate cake. I love this brewery!

Sampled at MN Ratebeer Winter Gathering in Maplewood, MN and supplied by Guerde and Oslo. From a 375 ml bottle pours a hazy dark amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a light ring. Aroma is complex of spiced brown sugar, caramel malt, some fruity character with a touch of tart berries. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with a tart fruit and caramel flavor. Finish has a tart fruit and yeast aftertaste with a little bit of alcohol warmth.
2006 vintage.  Mahogany in pour without any head.  Sweet fruits and maybe some burnt sugar on the nose.  Taste is all over the place.  Sweet flavors of wood and fruit.

MN Ratebeer Winter Gathering, January 12, 2008.  2006 Vintage.  Thanks to Gurede and Oslo for bringing in the De Dolle goodies!  Dark copper color with a thin head.  Aroma is very complex and hard to nail down.  Some spice and sweet malt.  Seemed almost like a bit of mint.  The taste is even trickier... A little tart apple, yeasty and strong malt.  Quite unique.

2002 bottle, poured murky brown, fruity aroma, very tart, fuity flavor, almost tasting like a sour ale. No alcohol flavor at all,very mellow, fruity and enjoyable. Thanks to Cquiroga for this bottle a year or three ago!
Dark purple appearance with little head formation noticeable.  The aroma is somewhat vinous, notably sour and funky.  The flavor is tart with plenty of earthy funk backing it up.  Very interesting.

Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle.  Burnt brandy appearance; thick.  Honey apple, brown sugar, lemon juice and saltwater in a pungent zing of an aroma; old pineapple and powdery red spice with vinegar toward the end.  Dry, and strongly fruity with a crisp apple peel and raspberry seed disposition; hints of banana, pistachios, tangerine.  Very tangy and bright, almost with an asian teriyaki quality.  Medium to full bodied, gorgeously attenuated, and full of deep malt flavor; dries out with a cedar and earth touch.  Quite nice; comfortably presented. Thanks for sharing, Alister!

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2011 Thanks to Gurede and Oslo for this treat.  Gold color with faint color.  Sweet sour body.  Very nice.  If I handt had a few rinses, I would have suspected a bad glass.  

Re rate. This is much better this time. The wine cask really shines through

2 reviews in one - small vertical of 2005 and 2006 vintages:  2006 was first - almost a kriek like sour fruit aroma - a bit funky and adventerous.  some notes of candy sugar.  color was a medium and very cloudy goldish brown.  very full body, medium tart - no where near a sour or dry lambic, but did have a very pleasing pucker to it.  some flavors of cherries throughout.  finished surprisingly crisp and clean.  one taster commented "a multi-layer funked edge".


2005 vintage - much darker pour than the 06.  flavors were more integrated - less tart, less fruity, but it still managed to be equally complex - just a bit more subtle.  Overall, I enjoyed the 06 a bit more, but both are very, very good beers from De Dolle.

2006 vintage courtesy of Brock_Landers. Wasnt wowed by this beer, and reading some of the other reviews, I guess I should have sat on this one for a while. Still, a very nice brew for the style. Its got kind of a funkhouse aroma to it, hinting of the sour notes that are sure to come (and which do not disappoint). I have to say that I love a lot of bordeaux wines, but I find their impression on this beer to be somewhat misplaced. The wine tannins contribute to the sourness of the beer, but the sour tannins of Bordeaux are the very things I try to overlook when tasting it. Anyway, good for the style, but I didnt fall out of my seat.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2009 Aroma is slightly funky, clean, and tannic wine characteristics.  
Taste is very wine-like in the dull, red grape and oak barrel taste.  Slightly bitter and dull finish.  
Starts funky and slightly sour, but quickly packs on the alcohol heat and funky fruitiness.  The barrel aging is definitely present, as is a grape-influenced fruitiness.  Finishes in a typically belgian yeasty, slightly hay and bitter fashion.  
Kind of strange.  I like it, but it has some "flaws".  
---
Re-rate---

Amazing. cherry, sour, lactic. Wow.
9494518
I learned.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 Three vintages sampled side-by-side on New Years Eve 2007. Most notably - as well as immediately evident - is the fact that the 2006 vintage that was released 6 months prior to sampling has yet to reach complex heights of development. This will surely change and is just one more of the many profound reasons to revisit all of these at multiple later dates. 
2004. 10/5/10/5/19

Pours heavily clouded deep orange with murky rust and wood tones. A mid-sized, creamy light beige head slowly recedes, never fully. Wispy arc lacing, minor. Brettanomyces is a sub-particle of a candied shell that is so relentless in its continual development that proper critical assessment would be a truly monumental feat. Highly sweet caramel and linear shoots of barnyard funk merge and correlate with bold and heavy leather. Candi sugar-soaked fruits laced with hallugenogenic alcohols swirl wildly out of control. Red wine with requisite tannic spice tickles cilia while vanilla oak notes play the role of immovable backbone and nuance separator. A truly phenomenal break from the ordinary. Brett tartness is full bore and as refreshing as can be while still retaining a funkiness that never seems anything less than novel when this brewery struts its stuff. Sweetness is high but not overdone, vinous flux is minimal as tannic grape and barrel fold into each sip with ease. Acidity is medium but stifled by a refreshing astringency and spice from tannins. Sourness is moderate and wavering. The finish is slowly drying, ultimately extremely dry, very winelike and moderately tart and funky. The mouthfeel has medium-high carbonation and is a silken joy to swirl around an eager tongue.



2005. 9/4/8/4/17

Pours a murky mahogany with crimson and blood-red/violet outlying hues. A small off-white head slowly diminishes, nearly fully, to wisps. Dotted sheet lacing, sparse and thin. Heavy funkiness and lively and acid-brimming tartness from Brettanomyces leads the propulsion of intensity from the most vivid and focused of the three vintages. Sweet port notes are syrupy, full and intelligently wrought. Earthiness is strong but creates a relaxing backdrop. Alcohol is moderate and well-integrated. Earhiness is substantial and never lets up, Brettanomyces and tartness downgraded to a mild to medium level. Barnyard funkiness and traces of characteristics of open fermentation and the transfer of the angels share are evident in retrained quantities. Sweetness is medium and when combined with a moderate acidity and low astringency leads to a smooth and mellow finish. Earth, light tartness and slow drying emerge in a transcendental finale. The mouthfeel is softly and moderately carbonated, creamy, medium bodied and lightly sticky and tannic. 


 
2006. 8/5/8/4/16

Pours a hazy dark amber, burned reds within. A mid-sized off-white/cream colored head slowly and mostly dissipates. Dot and arc lacing is miniscule. Tropical fruit streams from the vessel, a powerhouse that is awash with lively young funk that seems to have yet to reveal its true intentions. Vinous notes are lesser than older vintages and subdued by cream sensations. Alcohol is brash and unmanaged, yet to settle into a complacent complimentary role. A mustiness that must(no pun intended) fade into eloquence with a long slumber in this glass keepsake is a surprise upon first sip. Sweetness is low-medium to medium and fruitiness remains heavy but doesnt succeed in sugary aspirations. Acidity is chunky and fueled by light acetic quirks. Alcohol is signifigantly warming. The finish is semi-sweet and succinct, tannins finally revealing peppery spiciness. Woodiness is very forceful and certainly the most evident at this young age. The mouthfeel is moderately carbonated and medium bodied, agreeably smooth and certifiably younger than desirable for most enjoyable consumption.

Bottle shared by John Bryan (of Boulevard Brewing) at theistis Holiday Tasting 12/28/07. Pours a cloudy light brown with some chunky sediment and a thin, beige head. The nose is hugely woody and vinous with black pepper adding to the dominant notes, faint vanilla and fruit poking out from behind, in supporting roles. Medium-bodied and slick, it finishes extra dry. The flavor follows the nose: dry, vinous and woody. Even though my pour was from "the dregs" of the bottle, this was very tasty. Ill definitely need to find another bottle of this one. I have a feeling that theres a lot more to be discovered in this brew. Thanks again for sharing this with us, John!

Brewed 2006, bottled June 2007, 33cl bottle, with a big thanks to my man, john_adam2002 for this surprise!  Pours a clear dark brown iced tea color with burgundy highlights, and a large foamy tan head, minimal lacing.  Aroma is wood, spice, candied dark fruits, and some earthy yeast.  Flavor has a nice winey sweetness to it, with more spice and candied fruits present, wrapped in a gentle sourness.  Excitingly different than expected!

2006 vintage.  330 ml bottle shared by John Bryan (obtained at the brewery), enjoyed at my Holiday Mini Tasting.  Pour is ruby-brown with a thin khaki head.  Aroma of cloves, anise and all kinds of spiciness.  Some nutmeg in there as well.  Taste is big sour initially, settling into a really nice woody, cherry, sour, juniper and all of the spices previously mentioned.  A bunch going on in this one, this really refined.  Thanks for this one John!

A good Belgian strong, though perhaps overrated.  

I poured this dark ruby brown brew and could smell it from feet away, so I had no worries about it being weak in the nose.  Nose and flavors matched up well, and were both quite nice, though not amazing by any stretch.  Finish was medium to long, and warming.

330 ml bottle from Johns Marketplace shared by Enniskillen! Nose of caramel, raisins, spices, and light yeast! Hazy brown with a medium beige head; flavor fo dark fruit, yeast, caramel, spices, and very light tartness. Not near as good as Pannepot but pretty decent! Alcohol well covered!

Brown with a thick white head.  Aroma is oaky with some tartness, alcohol, earthy and caramel.  Taste is oaky with light wine showing, caramel, alcohol is wonderfully hidden.  Very well made beer.  Top Notch.

2006 bottle received from SS 07, holdenn.  Pours hazy ruby-amber with an average, frothy, light brown head, mostly lasting.  Aroma is average malt (cookie, caramel, straw), average hops (grass, lemon), average yeast (horse blanket, earth) with notes of light alcohol, plum and cherries.  Full bodied, gritty texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, heavy acidity and bitterness; wonderful sour tartness mixes well with the wood elements.

Hazy dark red brown with huge creamy head. Sweet malty aroma with flemmish sour characteristics. Sweet sour flavor with overripe fruits and berries. Vinious and complex. Not at all what I had expected....
Superb subtle integration of the barrel aging.  Beautiful mahogany color and persistent head.  Tart and funky and quite complex.

2006 Bottle.  Very nice wine aroma with a touch of caramel and green apple.  The flavor is a superb combination of caramel malt, red wine, and sourness.  It is extremely effervescent with little trace of the 13% alcohol (perhaps the smoothest I have tried at this ABV).  A terrific beer!
Vintage 2006, from the bottle @ Kerstbier Fest - Essen. Nose of oak, caramel and fruit. Tart, oaky caramel flavors. Barleywine like, but with a dry, sour finish. At 13%, alcohol was well hidden.

Ive never tasted a better marriage of spices, sweetness, complexity and maltyness in a beer. Many vinous notes throughout the entire beer, from nose to swallow. The alcohol presents itself as a beautiful flavour enhancer instead of a burning or warming character; it draws on the sourness. The beer drinks like a sour. Super crisp and super tart with the alcohol hidden underneath, pressing the flavours onto your tongue. Apples, sour cherries, corriander, nutmeg and more apples. Pours a wonderful ruby-gold that is muddy like thick apple cider, and it has tiny starlets of sediment floating throughout. I cant think of anything Ive had that came close to this flavour monster, and all the flavours are done to perfection. My new favorite (of course, since it costs $6 a bottle).

Rating #200 - 02 bottle shared with TChrome, thanks TAD.  Slightly cloudy deep brown with a large bubbly head that quickly fades to a scant covering.  Sweet, fruity nose with hints a caramel.  Light mouthfeel, tingly carbonation.  Flavor is very different than the nose.  Not sweet at all.  Very tart and astringent, but in a good way  almost lemonade-like.  Somewhat hot, alcohol finish.

Vintage 2005, 330mL bottle.  Poured in a Chimay Glass.  Pours deep dark brown.  Big creamy foam of the color of toasted oat cereal.  Lovely sweet aroma of deep rich molasses.  Large notes of rich barrel aged vinous Port Wine.  Date, cherry, and port.  Flavor has an immediate tartness to it.  Not a very strong acidity, but a medium tartness.  Heavy bodied malt character. Very well balanced.  Clean, smooth, tiny carbonation.  Great beer to just sit in a soft chair and sip, sip, sip away.  Finishes a bit woody.  Modest alcohol presence although the ABV is higher than average.   A+    (Rating #999)
Extremamente complexa! 13º de álcool, mas parece que tem, no máximo, uns 9º. Aroma e sabor de uvas tintas, madeira bem evidente e floral. Senti cortiça. Seca. Radical. Única. Ótima.

2006 bottle; poure a ruby-brown with an off white head.  Aroma was sour, oaky, dark fruit and cherry.  Initially the flavor was quite sour.  However, that dissipated throughout.  Very soft on the palate, almost watery.  Blend of dark fruit, cherry, oak, chocolate, and vanilla in the flavor.  Alcohol was noticable, but not overly strong, given that it is 13%.  I thought this was very good, but can see how others woul find it exceptional.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2009 A very special beer. My first time drinking it and Im blown away. So many flavours in the nose but not as complicated to drink. Strong, a real night finisher. A sipping beer, and so it should be. When I learn how to waffle bollocks so you know this is a special beer Ill be back to spread the word. I really need to drink this and rate it again. I had to register my thoughts so I can hunt this down. Very very good. Strong. Sips take their toll at this late hour. Everyone should like this. Should get young children off to sleep. Do not give it to teenagers. Itll be downed in one every time and before you know it, BAM new carpet. Watch your fucking kids Neal-o
2006 courtesy of vyvvy.  Brett?  Not sure if souness is from brett or oak.  Nice brew w/ a hint of soapy tang that detracts.  Good.

330. 06. Pours nearly black: cloudy dark brown with toffee-colored highlights when you hold it up to the light. Just hanging cumulus globs of grainy sediment knocking around in there at every stratum. Plenty of sheets and webs of sticky grayish moussy filmy lace. Thick creamy moussy head that falls to a good solid layer of light suds. Big sour nose--your stomach twitches just at the thought of the bugs even when the glass is at arms length. Vinegar, cherries, and moss on the nose. Medium, fizzy body that goes a bit watery. Sweet brown bread, strawberries, and a hint of semisweet chocolate on the mid-palate. Tart, acetic, acidulent vinegary finish. Quite puckery there at the end, almost champagne-like in a way. Interesting stuff.

Pours dark ruby with a finger of bubbly head.  Aroma of cherry, port, raisin, some maple malts.  Flavor is tart and tangy, with notes of cherry, grape and barnyard yeast.  Finishes dry with little to no alcohol present.  Very enjoyable brew.

From the bottle it pours a very hazy red with a 1 finger white head. Big aroma of cherry pits, cranberry and  alcohol. It is really reminiscent of alcoholic cough syrup but i mean that in a good way. Flavor is malty and tart with dry woody notes and cherry and especially cranberry. Some hints of red grape esters. Alcohol comes through on the flavor but not as much as i would think for 13%. Finishes dry and tart and slightly astringent.

11.2 oz bottle that I stumbled upon at Wine on the 9. Pours a medium brown that is slightly opaque with a big frothy eggshell color head that leaves tons of lace on my Ommegang 10th Anniversary glass. Funky aroma with notes of..well funkiness, wood, sour cherries that has an underlying sweetness about it if thatmakes any sense. Solid body with average to light carbonation that in no way reveals the 13% alcohol hiding in this beast. Flavor has notes of cherries, oak, wine and smoke. Wow what a suprise and from such a shitty store. Gonna stop back and pick up some more of this potent little monster.

11.2 brewed in 06 and bottled in 07. consumed 11/07. a beautifully formed thick cake-frosting like head emerges on top of this ale. it has a lovely off-white color and its a shame that it doesnt last longer. tawny, chestnut brown color. very hazy with more carbonation than expected. ripe aroma of cherry, oak, and vanilla beans. a touch of toasted coconut and chardonnay is also noted. thick dense lace is left behind as the cap shrinks. extremely tart, sour apple flavor jumps out in front. lots of oak and tannin. sour cherries and rustic wood characteristics. light smoke appears on the finish with no trace of the potent alcohol.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2008 Garrafa, em Bruges (BEL), em novembro de 2007. Não constava no cardápio... Vi um cara tomar no balcão e pedi uma igual. Coloração vermelha, com creme bege mediano. Sugestão de vinho tinto, uva, cortiça e madeira. Bem balanceada! Não se sente (nem um pouco) os 13%. Suave. Agradável. Aroma e bouquet fantásticos, riquíssimos. Frutas. Floraaaaaaaaaaaal... Carbonatação média. Amarga e seca, mas sem exagero. Levemente salgada. Ímpar! Personalidade. Cerveja amarga-seca-vinho com estilo!

In a word - amazing.  This was a beer I was expecting to be very good, but this just blew me away.  Pours very dark brown with a crimson hue and a small tan head with some nice retention.  The aroma has dark fruits overlaying a Flemish Sour aroma and lots of funk.  there is some richness and effervescence as well with pepper spice, vanilla, red grapes, oak and vinous traits.  There is some much going on here - just crazy complexity.  Medium body with a sticky, yet not cloying, feel that is offset by effervescent carbonation.  The flavor starts with sour red fruits, funky yeast, Flemish sour traits, dank musty maltiness, oak, sturdy citric notes, red wine and not much abv to be seen at this point.  The finish has more vinous traits, peppery spice and tannic dryness.  This is fantastic and excellent on every account.   It is a world class beer that excels at every aspect.  The alcohol is hidden on the taste.  I would have guess this was a well hidden 8% beer instead of a massive 13%.  However, the effects confirm it is in fact a 13% beer.  A very dangerous beer in that regards.  Monumental  thumbs up  for this work of art in the form of a beer.

Bottle at Chris. I Think it was Mes who brought this one. November 07. Spicy, vinegar aroma, deep and penetrating. Acrid, tart-sweet flavor, sharp and edgy flavor. Alcohol almost absent (13% you said??). Light to medium mouthfeel, complex with a long, spicy aftertaste. Enormous. Copper burgundy clear color with a middle white rim. Unbelivable complex strong ale.

[2005 bottle, the culmination of some major 2007 Thanksgiving drinking] 

Aroma is awesome-- right off the bat. Huge malty, sugary sweetness; fruity, with some acid, earthy vinegar and smooth, potent alcohol. Murky red-brown color, with some dense lacing. Flavors are massive-- like a flemish sour, hepped up big time. Dense candy sugar and malt flavors, with an incredible yeast presence. Fruity, vinous and acidic. Apple and sour cherry pie. The barrel contributes its character nicely, providing some musty funk and plenty of tannic acidity. Round, smooth flavors, with a very dry finish and some slight alcohol warmth. Full bodied. Overall, this beer is outstanding-- after a few years of age it seems to be in excellent condition.

What can I say, this has got to be hands down my favorite beer that I can actually get access to at least annually. This beer truly blurs the line between wine and ale. The 13% is brilliantly disguised. Aroma of red wine, vinegar,  cherries, candy sugar, and sweet malt. Excellent mouth feel, full bodied but far from cloying and rounded out by nice oak tannins. Taste is wonderful with dark fruits (cherries), red wine, oak, and candy. Again the tannins from the barrel and tartness from the yeast combined with the sweet malt provide an amazing combination of flavors!

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Pours hazy dark red with a frothy off-white head. Excellent lacing clings to my Chimay Trappist glass. Aromas of sweat dough, prunes, plums, and dates. Chocolate, plums, raisins, and hints of citrus all play out in the flavor. Acidic and salty with lively carbonation. Alcohol becomes more apparent as it warms. Its also seems to become slightly sweeter. Medium to full bodied with a dry texture. De Dolle does it again!!!

Label says brewed 06, cap says bottled June 07. Pours opaque amber brown with a small tan head. Strong earthy/herbal aroma tinged with mint and basil. Notes of chocolate mingled with orange peel, lots of yeast, and just a bit of alcohol are all present as well. Flavor is fairly tart/sour, with with soft but present acidity, a bit of grapefruit, a bit of cherry, light woody notes, and some reserved yeast driven spice. Palate is medium/full and somewhat tart, with a smooth creamy mouth-feel, and a decent finish.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2009 06 bottle from West Lakeview Liquors, CHicago.  Dark brown, almost opaque with brown tint, medium beige head.  Big belgium yeast aroma, chocolate malt semi-sweet, spicy.  Big yeast flavor, spice, sweet, orange, grapefruit, burned-malt, oaky, woody.  Medium to light body with light carb.  This beer has a lot going on in a very enjoyable way, very nice. 8 4 8 3 17 = 4

2007 Vintage.  Rerate during the First Annual Chicago Sour Tasting thanks to Gerrit.  Slighty cloudy red with small beige head and creamy.  Aroma is slightly sour, cherry, a little alc and yeast spice.  Flavor is cherry and earthy sour with a slight acidity, oaky, tannin, slight alc.  Medium and light carbonation.  Always good, I cant wait to try this vintage again in a few years.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 Tried from bottle(bottled JUL 07). It pours with a reddish burgundy color and burnt white head. The nose is quite complex with sharp and sour cherry, fruit oak spice, and buttered raisins. The bordeaux cask definately leaves it mark in the aroma. The flavor is a bit too sour for me, and I attribute this to the lack of ageing. This beer needs some time to settle down, and this is the reason I gave it a sub-4 rating. After decanting, the sourness was subdued and the tart fruit from the nose emerges with good balance. Decent now, but Id love to try some of the previous vintages NOW.

2005 bottle. This one poured a deep maroon almost brown color with a meidum sized tan head that held nicely. The aroma is very complex. It smells of dark sour fruits, oak, yeast, spices, and definitely has some funk in there. The flavor is even more pronouced than the smell. The dark sour fruits like cherries and lemons start to come through first with some malts and oak in the background. This bottle has definitely picked up some funk as well. The flavors all seem to blend together perfectly and mask the alcohol beautifully. I love all the dark sour flavors and funk this one has. This is one is full bodied and perfectly carbonated on the palate that finishes dry with a slight sour aftertaste. I am really glad I found one of these. This is one of my favorites from these guys. De Dolle never seems to disappoint.

2006. Poured dark red with good size off white head. Aroma of sour fruit (apples, cherries, and grapes) and some candy hints. Great sour fruit flavor to start with a sweeter malt/candy background. Great balance.

2005 bottle courtesy of footbalm (thanks!).  Poured slightly muddy dark brown with small tan head.  The aroma...my oh my, very sexy.  Red wine, cherries, apples, sour funk, oak.  I couldve kept my nose in there all night.  Taste came up slightly short of the aroma, but I sure didnt mind.  Apples at the forefront, followed by cherries and oak.  Moderately sour and ever so slightly boozy.  The palate was medium to light, which I must say came as a bit of a surprise for such a big beer.  Finished nice and dry though, which was a plus.  Very glad Ive got another 2 bottles.  Ill be seeing this one again in 2008...know that.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 Pours a clear brown with a small brown head. Sweet and quite sour. Fruity aromas of cherries. Also quite a bit of alcohol and wood. Hint of rye. Heavy bodied. Big thanks to bager for this rare treat.
Pours a deep brown. Massive sweet fuit on the nose. Tottally thrown off by the taste. Massive fruit, kind of sour. Oak is there but faint. Finish is tart and smooth. A little warm.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 Woah....This is beer paradise. I must grab some more before you are out. This is one of the best beers Ive had to date. Aroma of sour fruit and yeast. Pour was a delicious dark brown with a huge pillowy 3 finger white head. Taste was like a Flemish sour but with more of an alcohol kick. Strong wood, cherry and sour fruit flavor with a little alcohol burn. I was going to have one rating after this, but I have to end my October now. This is a whole nother level.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle 2006 from Dilly Deli.  Poured hazy brown color with a huge frothy light brown head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex dark fruit and yeasty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium dark fruity balanced flavor with a medium tart sweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2009 2006 bottle. Poured medium reddish brown with a moderate sized tan head.  Nice sour cherry aroma, with some oak, tannins, and pepper. Flavor is tart, dry and woody with some citrus and sour cherry. Some alcohol present in the finish. Low carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. 

2005 bottle, sampled 3/7/09 at Teresas next door basement blowout- chestnut pour with a small tan head. Beautiful aroma, tart cherry at the forefront, with mild oak and vinous notes. Flavor is not as exciting as the aroma; wood, dirt, mild lactic acid, sour cherry and mild citrus. The beer is still solid, but not as exciting as I remember

2002 vintage purchased from Bottleworks. Beautiful dark brown/red with creamy head. High carbonation. Aroma is a little like cherry cobbler. Taste is mellow sour fruit with a little bit of oak. Tingles the tongue. Dry finish. Fantastic. A wonderful dessert beer.
Thanx to Juiceisloose for sharing this.Pours brown with a small tan head.Floral, sweet fruit and some sourness on the nose.Citrus and tart on the flavor with a sweet finish.

Pours opaque brown with a medium brown head.  Plenty of alcohol fruit and floral in the aroma.  Mouth feel is medium with lively carbonation. Flavor doesnt really match the aroma, but it is tasty.  A nice fruity tartness is present with woody flavors and not a lot of sweetness. Very good, and different.

2005 bottle from The_Epeeist.  Thanks Chris!  Pours with a large 1 finger tan head that quickly dissipates to a continuously forming small bubble ring arond the edge.  A cloudy super dark red-brown color. Oak and wine from barrel aging is very evident and dominating the aroma. Fun to smell.  From this I want to describe the smell as vinous.  Smallest amount of dark yeast sediment in bottom of bottle.  Flavor is dry and a bit tart.  A bit reminiscent of champagne with its higher carbonation, dryness, and vinous taste/aroma, but much better than most champagnes as there is no skunkiness.  Lots of residual non-sweet fruity flavors of cherry.  I prefer brandy and bourbon barrel aging, and I prefer more sweetness in general, which brings down the rating to me, but I think the beer is very well done otherwise.  Add cheese and my rating might go up...maybe.

From a 33cL Bottle, 2005 Vintage.  Purchased at OBriens, 9/28/07.  Pours a dark cherry wood brown color with a huge layer of light meringue-like foam.  Dark red grape skins mingle with some leathery cherries and a woody dryness.  A subtle dash of peppery spice and toasted mace add further complexity.  Light bodied, heavily carbonated mouthfeel.  This is incredibly dry and light for 13% ABV, an amazing feat in and of itself.  Tons of dark cherries and black currants explode onto the palate, accompanied by a dry wine skin tannic pucker.  A light spice and dark woody notes come through mid-palate, lingering with the vinous fruit notes into the final smack.  Great balance; tart, mild acidity, and loads of fruit.  Never a disappointment; always a pleasure.

Strong aroma of sweet flowers, malt, and alcohol.  Nice fruitiness as well in the aroma, very complex.  Completely opaque dark reddish brown.  Head was yellow yet quickly dissipated.  Wow, great taste.  Hides the 13% extremely well.  Very fruity, heavy in the plum, some acidiy  Palate is clean and perfect.  Wonderful beer,

Bottle, 2006. Dark redish brown with a medium off-white head. Sour and fruity, wood tones. Chocolate, malt and fruit.
Full body with a sweetish finish.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 Name: Oerbier Reserva
Date: 11/28/2003
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Whole Foods Market, DC
Vintage: 2002

dark ruby, fine beige head, sweet vinious aroma with hints of plum, strong tart fruity flavor, slight bitter oaky finish
-------- />
Name: Oerbier Reserva
Date: 08/04/2005
Vintage: 2002

ditto, nice oak

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20

muddy brown, creamy beige head, drippy lace, nice oaky aroma on chocolate with tart cherry pits, creamy body, nice tart flavor, lots of wood, chocolate malt hiding under it all, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20

Name: Oerbier Reserva
Date: 05/10/2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Vintage: 2006

Appearance: clear dark brown, wispy dirty white head, 
Aroma: sweet and tart fruity malt aroma with a nice woody character in the tartness, 
Flavor: big tart woody flavor, nice fruity esters come in to balance the tartness, light spicyness, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: **+/4

RATING #100!! More thanks to Reklaw for his generosity. This brew pours 3 cm of white head on top of a beautiful amber body. Great lacing sticks all over the glass. My nose received hints of apple, spice, and coffee cake. The palate is bombarded with sour hay notes, raisin, grapes, more apple, roasted nuts, and a tiny amount of maple syrup. High carbonation is well-balanced with the huge body in this beer. Wonderful. A great beer for a 100th rating.

Dark, dry and oaky/sour.  I really enjoyed this beer because you had no idea wha to expect from the color. Stronger & drier than Oerbier, but in a positive way. The aroma was the best, with a sourish roasted smell.  Nice amount of alcohol, but very smooth. Nice, but not available that often.
Bottle 2006 version. By the smel of it you have already the idea that this is a bear with body. Splendid tast and good aftertaste. A really good beer
Bottle - thanks to Jannik - I want more of this. Unclear reddish - offwhite head. Wood, berries, light sweetness, tar, light dolle yeast sourness, light sharpness, light alcho-burn. Very very good !!

I expected this to be great, but I found it next to awful. It had surprisingly little aroma. For some reason it smelled like Sprite or 7Up: its like you could smell the heavy carbonation and the overall sourness. Taste was heavy sour apple, sour cherry, and nasty oak, rolling into unimaginably sour complexities. I like sour ales and lambics, but this stuff is horrific. The high rating shocks me.

Cloudy Dark Brown with Light Orange Hue and Off White Head. Sour Cherry and Oaked Aroma. Medium Body and Syrupy Mouthfeel.  Vinous Feel to it.  Fruity with Cherry Notes More Subtle on the Tongue Than the Nose...Light Spices...Dry Currant and Oak Notes.  Sweet, Peppery and Dry Finish. Very Smooth for 13% but Still Quite Evident That Youre Drinking a Strong Ale.  Very Well Balanced Compared From What I Remember of Other De Dolle Brews. Highly Recommend.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 7/6/07 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2005.  Dark woody brown with a brief tan head.  Sour cherries and lemon oil.  Earthy undertones.  Creamy mouthfeel becomes increasingly tart.  Subtle fruit elements heavy on peel, pit and pepper.  Vinous notes; white burgundy?  Dry oaky finish.  Interesting play of sour and bitter.  3/19/08 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2002.  Dark brown, but clear, with a light tan frosting.  Nose is wood, dried apricot, caramel, raisins and figs.  Lightly sour, intoxicatingly sweet.  Taste is among the most complex ive encountered.
