Drinks like a red wine with a bit of carb tingle.  Taste is vinous, sour caramel, hints of red fruit and cherry skins.  Oak adds smoothness.  Puckery finish, peppery lips.  Having tried two years of the Reserva i still prefer the regular. I added 2 for the aroma and a point overall.  7/9/09 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2004.  Murky brown with sparse beige foam.  Nose is sour cherry, wood and hints of caramel with subtle funk.  Medium light with fine carb.  Silky then tart.  Tastes like a red wine with a touch of madeira and wild mushroom.  Turns to sour crabapples, finishing with dried apricots.  As it warmed, opened up beautifully but missing that hint of sweetness in the regular version.  Same rating overall except for the aroma which i gave a 7.  6/23/10 - 11.2 oz bottle. 2006.  Cloudy brown with a creamy beige head.  Vinous nose with oak and cherry.  Medium body with a tang.  Taste is sour cherry, oak and apple.  A tad sweeter than other versions but still predominantly sour and woody.  Aroma lacks some complexity; revised to an 8.  4/20/11 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2007.  I seem to be trying these once a year.  Nose is that familiar oak, cherry and caramel with earthy hints of wild mushrooms and wet leaves.  Juicy medium body with a bracing sour tang.  Taste is tart cherry, red wine, oak and spice.  Still a 4.  10/1/11 - 11.2 oz bottle. 2009.  Nose is sour cherry, wood, mushrooms and toffee.  Thick, but more whipped up as opposed to syrupy, with foamy carb and a sharp tang.  Taste is huge and bright sour cherry, strawberry banana and oak finishing with key lime pie.  The earthy, funky notes ive seen in other vintages are present but this is by far the most vibrant of the lot.  9 for taste but only 7 for the aroma so keeping this at 4.  1/24/12 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2010.  I seem to age these a bit more, this one relatively fresh at a year+.  Nose is cherry preserves, toffee, oak, light funk and wine vinegar.  Wonderfully juicy and mouth watering with soft but lively carb.  Taste ranges from sweet to tart cherry, raspberry and cranberry, wood and red wine with cinnamon heat.  Id up the palate to a 4 for this one but will leave the overall rating at a 4.0.  Fresh seems to be the way to go with these.  1/8/13 - 11.2 oz bottle.  2008.  Omigod, the aroma on this vintage is through the roof.  Strawberry banana, funky caramel, burgundy, faint wood, pepper and vanilla.  Medium body with a dull sparkle, verging on flat.  Unfortunately the taste falls short on expectations from the nose.  Caramel, chianti and cinnamon stick.  Always a cool brew.  Maybe a 4.1 on this one.

Bottle. By fare the closest to a red wine experience that I have ever come across, without it being a red wine! Partly because this brew have been maturing in old red wine oak barrels, and that heavily shows in the overall impression of this remarkable beer. Large creamy light brown head that mostly lasted. Held up to a light source, the body was somewhat clear and sparkling. The color was light dark with a reddish glow. Aroma was bread, dust and grain, toasted notes, grape, prune, raspberry, very vinous with a mix of sour milk and acidic fruity notes as well. Full bodied with a light alcoholic and sticky texture and a soft carbonation. Flavor was mixed between moderated acidic and light to moderated sweet and hint of bitter notes as well. Finish was plastered everywhere in your mouth and lovely lasting feel that you dont want to let go off. Thank heaven for trying this lovely brew!!

Bottle shared with Jeppe (thanks) and Morten. Pours a nice cloudy deep amber colour with a good light brown mostly diminishing light brown head. The aroma is a bit sour and sweet with caramel and prunes. The flavour is quite sour with a pleasant sweetness,  toasty caramel and malt with some spices. Sour dry toasty finish. I do not believe this beer to have a whole 13% alc.

330ml bottle picked up last year. Pours a dark brown with a fluffy head. Aroma is sour and wine like. To taste this is extremely sour and powerful, lots of alcohol heat but still reasonably easy to drink and rather creamy. Very good.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a crispy light brown and quickly disappearing head. Raisin sweet aroma, with a citric note and a mild malt presence. Sweet then dry and finally sour flavoured. Vague malt base beneath. Dry sour long into the finish. Very nice.

2005 bottle.  Big thanks to boboski for this one.  Pours a murky dark chestnut brown with a thick white head.  Spicy anise, sour cherry oak aroma.  Taste is tart yet richly spicy and dry.  The tartness is with you through the finish, but never too intense.  A sour, earthy brew.  The 13% is well-hidden.
Aromas of sour cherries and a slightly acidic taste. Tastes of sour fruit, with a slight warming in the chest. Very good.
bottle shared with toncatcher.  Murky brownish beer with not much head.  Slightly tart aromas with much more sour on the flavor.  Slightly acidic.  Pretty good stuff.
12 oz bottle via trade with captaincougar.  Aroma of sour apple cider, white wine, and sour oak.  Taste of sour, tart fruit.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 2002 bottle from kulminator. Dark, deep ruby with thick creamy tan head. A great looking beer! I dont thnk Ive given a 5 before? Sweet aroma of malt, brown sugar and light berries. Taste is sweet and slightly tangy - dried dark fruits, malt and brown sugar. Light finish of berries. Not very harsh at all considering the abv.

2002 bottle shared by someone at DLD. Aroma was pretty sour and sweet both at the same time.  A lot of belgian yeast notes coming through. Pretty tastey but will have to be compared to by 2004 bottle.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 04 thanks to Sprinkle.  Pours a hazy deep orange color with a white head.  Aroma is woody, sour fruits.  Aroma is woody, sour tart fruits.
5/10/08
06  Pours a amber brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is brett, sweet oak character, caramel, and some funk.  Flavor is brett, oak, sweet vinous character, funk, and a dry tart finish.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2008 One of the best sour beers I have ever had.  Smelled sour and spicy.  Taste was much the same, some sour funk, light malt, spices, an apple/cider taste, and balancing dark fruit.  I liked this a ton better than the regular oerbier.

Re-rate: Really the same as I remembered before.  Great balance, apples throughout, nice touch of funk.  Great stuff.  No chance I would guess this is 13%

Bottle shared by sliffy. Orange-red pour with a yellowed white head. Aroma held a bit fo funk, light sour elements, some yeast and light oak. Falvors of oak, light sour, pale dry malts, spices and a tinge of funk. Medium-light body, lively carbonation with a dry/sour/sweet finish. Really nice.

2004; Color is dark amber with a small white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma has lots of tartness and a less pronounced plum and apple smell as well. Flavor is much the same, very "tarty" with apples plums and grapes and a slight bit of biscuit. Alcohol is very well hidden, medium to full body.

12 oz bottle - 2005.   I drank this beer at Stuffed Sandwich.   I ordered this thinking it was the regular Oerbier, and was caught by surprise by the sourness of this one.   Lots of sour fruits and an almost wine like quality throughout.  This beer kind of reminded me of a dark, robust temptation.   Pretty good.

2004 12oz bottle, sampled next to regular Oerbier. pours dark amber with small white head around the rim. nose has lots of tartness, red wine, very faint smokeness, red apples, grapes, and plums. really great aroma. flavor has lots of wonderful red wine notes, nice tartness, very fruity (red apples, grapes, and plums), wine tannics, and a very faint toasted biscuit. alcohol is extremely well hidden. mouthfeel is full. wow this is one heck of a beer. very winey and fruity. perhaps a little to tannic.  this is a great beer.

330 ml bottle.  2005 bottle.  Amber brown color with a nice white head.  Sour wonderful aroma, very lambic like with some dark fruits, brown sugar, and chocolate.  Tart flavors dark fruits, cherries, wine, chocoalte.

2005 Bottle courtesy of SoLan. Thanks, Alan. The aroma holds mashed ripe fruit, vinuous notes, overripe orange pulp and a mild funkyness. The body is a muddy brown and the head tries to keep it together, but loses the battle. Very tart, vinous tasting fore. Lightly oaky, but mostly the wine comes through. Fairly biting carbonation. Soury and funky on the back of the tongue. A sour tartness lingers long on the tongue compelling the mouth to smack and the tongue to caress its lips. This is a beer you ease into. It becomes simultaneously more nuanced and stronger in concentration as you sip. I was beginning to feel like I was tired of Belgian beers (a cardnial sin I know) but this has very much reminded me why I love their beers so much.

The aroma was fruity and complex with a strong vinous characteristic and oak presence. Alcohol tickled the nasal passages and was coupled with a light and interesting tart complexity that brought forth dark fruits of raisins and prunes. A Belgian yeast spice presence was also nice and notable. The beer poured into the Oerbier tulip deep amber brown with an off-white tight bubbled head which stood tall and laced the glass from top to bottom. The flavor was vinous and tart with a bready character and a light citrus characteristic of Brett. The flavor contained dark fruits, raisins and prunes, with some caramel and candy characteristics lurking in the background. The Belgian yeast spice presence was slight and well done. The tartness was strong, but added complexity and depth to the beer which also exhibited vinous characteristics and oak. The finish was dry with lasting citrusy and bready Brett character fading into the aftertaste. The body was above medium and was spritzy with a high level of carbonation. The alcohol warming after consumption was very high. A strong complex beer with lots going on! 330 ml bottle. Brewed in 2002.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 6, 2009 2005 vintage.  Brown ruby red highlights with persistant white lacing.   Sour aroma of cherries, oak, grape must.  Flavor is stunning: quick beginning with sour cherries, then an explosion of yeast, sour cherry, wine, balsamic vinegar.  Amazingly round and chewy.  Soft and fizzy, deep and haunting.  A strange and mystical brew; enjoyed from an 11.2oz botle.

Bottle.  Ruby-reddish borwn in color.  Cherry, cork, barleywine like ripe cheese scent.  Very dry and quick evaporation off the tongue.  Tangy residual lingers on the tongue 10-15 seconds after.  High alcohol content noticeable on the roof of my mouth.  Excellent cigar beer.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 2002 bottle courtesy of Kujo9. Nose is oaky and vinous, wood is more powerful than i smell in most wood aged beers. Bordeaux immediately evident. Also noted bits of candied sugar and figs. A little funky which I like. Flavor is fruity (red grapes, mainly) with alcohol, oak, and a sweet vinegar finish. Carbonation and mouthfeel is lively throughout, almost a little too lively at times. While the heavy does of alcohol is well noted, this is a very drinkable 13% beer and no doubt 5 years of aging in bordeaux casks and in the bottle have done it well.  Thrilled to enjoy this rare treat.  Big props to Mike for sending this my way!!


2005 bottle from cquiroga.  Thanks Chris.  This is just as yummy as before. Appearence is dead on perfect this time with a beautiful, cream colored lace atop a dark crimson body. Very oaky, tart, and tannic.  I love this beer. 

3-4 2008 Bottles over the last couple years, as well as few other vintages. The more I drink this, the more I fall in love.  My favorite De Dolle by far and definitely in my top 5 beers of all time.  Shame this is my last bottle of this vintage. Hope they will continue to release this. I need more.

2005 Bottle courtesy of Sprinle:  Pours a beautiful brown color with nice beige head.  Smell of dried fruit and sugar.  Tatse is very simular to  a red wine even with the dry aftertase.  There is a taste of malt dried fruit.  I too tast the reseamble of a flemish sour.  Kinda the same vinager aftertaste. I thought the alcohol was well hidden.    La toda madre cerveza.....  This beer is the Sh%t

2005 bottle. Oh6gdx kindly shared this delight with me on the day before my wedding. Thanks -- I needed that!
Very dark syrup-brown colour, with a small but dense, beige head.
Almost gueuze-like fermented aroma resembling red wine, with some alcohol and a hint of skunkiness and chocolate. Wow.
Sour, yeasty flavor with milk chocolate and grapes. Lovely cocoa aftertaste lingers after sourish bitter finish.
Quite complex altogether.
Dry, sticky mouthfeel, very full bodied, moderate carbonation. Niiice.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 A Mes rate: 33cl 2005 bottle from the Kulminator.Alcohol, brown sugar and sweet caramel nose with some apple, liquorice and honey and all rounded off with some incredible De Dolle Reserva sourness. Typically superb De Dolle looks. Sweet malts and obvious alcohol in the mouth. Finish has and almost Flemish sour character. Almost balsamic, wonderfully dry and a delicate sourness. Notes of bubblegum too. Superb mouthfeel, almost chewy. Perfectly balanced. Utterly fantastic.

It says 2004 on the label but the cap says bottl 2005 via trade with JCapriotti, thanks Jason.  Im going to be doing a rerate with the regular Oerbier after this one.  Pours a cloudy orange brown with a 1 1/2 finger light beige head.  Aroma of sour oak, sour cherries, sour grapes--this smells a lot like a lambic up front, something stale and vinous.  Flavor is again quite tart with a bit of raisins poking up with a pleasant alcohol warmth--not 13%, mind you.  I was afraid the sourness would attack me and be way too strong, and while it was full of flavor, I didnt feel assaulted.  There was also a bit of brown sugar that never had the chance to show any sweetness.  Bone dry finish with little bitterness.  Low to moderate carbonation with a medium body.  I dont rightfully remember how the regular Oerbier was (I do know I liked it), but I dont recall it being anything like this.  Good stuff.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 12 oz bottle via captaincougar (thanks!). She pours a dark brown with a massive chunky beige head. Nose is sour. Taste is sour too. Is this a brett yeast? Tastes like a cross between brett yeast and a Flemish sour Ale. Mostly taste sour cherries and a slight bit of woodiness. It has a tart finish but it is a smooth tart..or is that an oxymoron? Whatever..but it is smooth and tart at the same time. 13.5% abv? Seriously? It is very well-hidden as  i detect no heat at all. High carbonation. Medium Body.

2005 bottle. Poured a very dark red body with a generous, lopsided head. Aroma is of funk - sour, horseblanket, yeast. Flavor is slightly sweet, cherry, oak  and a touch of sourness to it. Left the mouth craving more (oh what is it about sour beers that make me sad when they are finished?). This was one great beer, glad I found it.
Bottle.33cl. Thanks to Beermouth, for this wonderfull beer, it has a faint hit of oak but that works for this beer, now i will shut up and enjoy this beer.

Bottled (13%, 2005 version). Thanks goes to GarethYoung for this bottle, which I decided to share with rsmeds on his marriageday. Dark cloudy syrupyish reddish/brown colour with huge beige creamy head. The aroma is grapes, alcohol and sour fruits. Flavour is quite the same, along with some grassy notes on the tip of the tongue. Also lots of cocoa to be found behind the sourness once it gets warmer. The burps you burp after this also taste like cocoa or milk chocolate. Overall an extremely complex beer, which probably ages well and might make it a bit smoother.

Had the 04 version.Light fruits and a nice sourness in the aroma.Pours a murky dark copper with a medium off white head.Got a smooth sourness and lots of oak in the flavors.Medium to full mouthfeel with a sour oak finish.

Wow, I didnt expect this to be so high powered.  Totally dont taste all that alcohol at all.  Very bitter and sour, reminds me more of a flemish sour or lambic type deal.  My pour is more on the brown side.  Cherry aromas, tart, bitter, fruity tastes.  Very interesting.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 12oz bottle, 2004 vintage, courtesy of HogTownHarry.  Thanks, Harry!  Pours a murky yellowish-brown appearance; off-white head with beautiful lacing at the edges.  Tart, complex aroma: cherries, oak, and vinous red fruits.  Pleasant level of sourness, in a full mouthfeel; so many things going on here: overripe sour cherries, woody and warm vanilla notes; medium acidity; levels upon levels of oak and cherries and barrel flavor.  Long, balanced, cherry and wood finish.

Multiple bottles since; within a year or two, tartness hasnt developed enough to reach its peak; 3-4 years seems ideal.

2002 bottle, heavily oxidized, lots of caramel and very little remaining tartness.  Disappointing, too old, and unrated.

Vintage 2005 - Pours dark reddish brown with a small, wispy light tan head. Aroma of tart cherries, horse blanket, cranberry, and fruity acids. Taste of tart apple, vinous oak, brett, cherry, and sweet acids. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, dry, with soft carbonation. Very nice, but perhaps an acquired taste, as the brett has certainly taken ahold of this one! Plenty of oak, cherry, and brett to hide the ABV.

2004 Bottle.  Upon opening, botle slowly fizzed out of the top.  Poured a cloudy dark orange probably from the sediment that got kicked up from the gushing.  Lots of carbonation but the head diminishes very fast.  Aroma is outstanding, acidic pineapple brett with freshly emptied red wine barrel.  Flavor has a somewhat sweet crystal malt base that quickly gets overrun by the acidity and the cask influence.  Slight horse blanket funk but very low levels.  More brett fruitiness combined with a light and fruity red wine and oak.  Also has flavors of apple cider.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden and is hard to think that this is 13%.  This beer is quite amazing.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 2004. 33cL bottle. Nice crisp horse blanket, pineapple and lychee aroma. Coconut juice rolls through. Brett, baby. Amber orange pour, with lacy soap of white. On the tongue, that sweet and sour Brett lactic presentation, followed by cursory sour apple skin and chestnut meat. This holds a dash of coarsely ground pink pepper. Smack rules. New fresh morphing flavors develop in the residuals that linger, some of sultry fatty-acid heft and some pineapple meat. Lots of pale grapes and their respective skins and juice, before closing with a crisp wheaty bite. This hid 13% alcohol? Incredible.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Major thanks to Solan at Knightly...2005 bottling.  Sour aroma blasts the senses, revealing hints of what is to come.  Wisps of oak and ripe berries.  On the palate, a nice oakiness shines through. balancing the sourness.  No hint that this beer has such an alcohol content.  Wonderful brew, too bad I have no more.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 thanks to the guys from Knightly....The nose is a little frighting, sour aroma mixed oak and alcohol.  Pours a dark brown.  Wow the flavor.....sour cherries, oak, with a hint of raspberries, although i smell a lot of alcohol, there is no sign of the 13% in the taste.  Very dangerous.  There is a little tingle that lingers but otherwise very clean finish.  Wow.

Pours a rich maroon with light tan head.  Smells of lemons and alcohol.  13% is detected in the smell.  Very tannic and sour in the taste, makes the lips pucker up.  i was expecting it, but for some reason wasnt ready for it, which I liked.  If you dont like sour beers, stay away from this one. I get heavy heavy lemons in this one.  I love me some sourness so it was quite enjoyable.  Actaully, the alcohol is masked quite nicely in the taste, as is typicla with alot of sour beers Ive tried.  Very nicely done, ive got a few bottles left and look forward to them.  ill let them sit for a while and see what happens.

Bottle. 2005. Chestnut color with a nice light tan head. Slight tart/oaky aroma with some malt. Tart/fruity flavor with backing malt and yeast. Medium body. Lingering oak/tartness. Can taste the wine influence. No alcohol - very well hidden. Duchess like, but smoother.

2005.  murky dark brown with a small tan head.  potent aroma of grapes, cherries, alcohol, wood, and red wine.  flavor is moderately sour, winey, and woody with a hint of smoke in the finish.  hints of chocolate.

2005 bottle. Dark brown unclear red with a fine thick lasting creamy white head. Aroma is  sweet , spicy, wood, vinous & cherries. Flavor is well balanced between sweet & sour. Oak & vinegar. Well hidden alcohol. Carbonation is fizzy but not as much as the regular Oerbier. Soft mouthfeel. Fine lacings on the side of the glass. Amazingly great!

Wonderful,teasing, fruity sour aroma,big working head,tastes like a port wine with lots of lactobacillus at firstsettles into a fruity tart cherry apple sourness, with a smooth yet tingle your nose finish. Awesome. Thanks to Chris at Murrays for pointing out the last one to me

eight six nine Vertical time 2002, 2004, 2005 get low, a get low.  Some interesting differences.  The 2002 still had plenty of power and ageability.  The maltiness came out most with tihs one, turned very biscuity, almost an English like malt flavor emerged.  The sourness was still there, very strong actually. The 2004 had a lot of fruitiness in its sourness, also more vinegar and more tartness than any other vintage.2005 was darker than the other two, a dark burgundy ruby red.  It was the least sour, milder in all aspects acttually.  Still had some sourness but lacked the acidity of the 04 and the maltiness of the 02.  
Overall, I would take the 02 over the rest.  The 04 was great if its sourness I strictly wanted and the 05 may need to sit a bit.  Also, no alcohol presence at all, I thought this was more like  5% brew, have no idea where all that alcohol came from.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 2008. More of an old bruin than years past...similar to the 2007 - less funk...


2007.  Same as 2005 except a little less funky....no blue cheese finish this time around...docking the flavor slightly..

2005. Pours deep mahogany/red into a tulip.  Tan micro head with good retention.  Sour cherry and funk aromas. Tart and full with sour oak and a lasting, puckering then blue cheese finish. Alcohol is entirely hidden. 9/4/10/4/18 = 4.5

2002. Sampled 6/10/08.  Slight cardboard and many dimished flavors.  Much sweeter than the more recent, fresh versions, but remains drinkable, but Id say finish these up if youve got em.

2005 bottle.  Reddish amber in color, with a small tan head. Huge aroma, of both sweet and sour cherries, malts, wood, acetic acid, and a touch alcohol.  Taste is cherries, oak, light notes of damp basement, a good amount of acetic acid (vinegar) but not overpowering.  Tart and vinous middle and finish, with notes of vinegar and spices.  A touch of alcohol warm too in the finish, but overall the alcohol is extremely well hidden.  I cant believe this is 13 %.

Oerbier Reserve 05-11.2oz bottle-pours a foamy tan head that laces with ruby red color with effervescence.  Aroma is dark fruit, dark/medium malt.  Taste is dark fruit-cherry, dark/medium malt-sweet, wood, yeast, faint hops.

2004 Bottle: The beer pours with a polished copper core with autumnal highlights.  The ABV warmth cradles the aroma - loaded with notes of cherries jubilee, wet firewood, balsamic vinegar and vanilla oak.  Over time, if the ether continues to recede, the nose would be perfect (9-->10).  The sofly carbed bottle is a great vehicle for the juicy tart body.  Loads of cherries and vinegar, sherry and oak.  The body lingers off into a nice dry finish.  Good stuff Jeff.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2008 Bottle, bought this as a present for my dad, but not his thing so I had it. Poured dark reddy/brown. Aroma is woody, yeasty and with some alcohol. Taste quite sharp which I hadnt expected, I had not even looked up this beer despite the high ratings, things mellowed after a while and there was a wonderful cherry tartness with the oakyness definately discernible, still I have to be honest and whilst I quite liked it I have to declare it to not really be my thing.   Had this at Mess 20-06-08  in the company of Mes, Ang and Loz, many thanks Mes for your generosity   Maybe my palate has changed as second time around I loved this and cant quite believe it only got a 3.5 from me before. There is a distinct musty fruitiness on the nose of this beer which pours almost chesnut in colour with an off-white soft bubbly head.  Dusty wood and leather some warm wet alcohol laden oaky flavours come through and then lovely sour cherries, the finish is a little dry, I think my palate has changed I love this beer, once again cheers Mes.   4.2 is the new rating for this

2004 bottle from John (jjpm74) Thanks.  Pours out a dark red color with a thick tan colored head on top.  Smell is sweet, fruity, with some cherries.  Possibly a little tartness in the smell too, perhaps this is brett fermented?  Taste is tart and smooth, and damn good.  This tastes nothing like their normal oerbier.  The cherry flavor comes out and it has a nice oaked flavor but not in anyway overpowering.  Great stuff.

Pours clear deep (very deep) red with a large coffee coloured head that soon fades to leave a thin lasting band. Aroma instantly reminded me of Orval -  all citrussy and fizzy. The taste is tart and fruity and 13% alcohol....totally masked, so glad i have others stashed away.

bottle 2005- pours a dark deep brown about black.  very interesting head as the carbonated bubbles form a pattern. good head retention and beautiful lacing.  smells of a tart, almost, cherry flavored.   It tastes like sour cherries, fruit and it has a wonderful mouth feel. great beer.

(Bottle 33 cl) Pours a clear, amber golden with a yellowish/brownish, creamy head. Incredibly complex aroma of wood, overripe fruit and then tartnes - like what you find in a Flemish Sour. Surprisingly - considering the 13% alcohol - the body only comes out as medium, that alcohol is really well hidden. Distinct flavours of wod and overripe fruit - some sherry perhaps - but distinctly sourish. Incredibly delicate and refined. 191206

Bottle 2005 @ Kerstbierfestival 2006 in Essen, BE. Hazy dark amber color with off-white head. Aroma is alcohol, yeast, fruit (apple) wood and some sourness. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a long duration. Very complex a nice ..

Bottle (2004). Lovely amber colour with a fine and creamy white head. Nice aroma of sourness, sweetness and some fruitness. Great sour and sweet flavour of wood, sourness, oak and acidity. Very well hidden alcohol. Ends up refreshing and with a warm feeling from the alcohol. Reminds me a lot of a flemish sour.

2005, from bottle at the Kerstbierfestival in Essen. This was the tastiest thing I had all day. Deep reddish-brown with aroma of sour cherries... which also come through beautifully in the flavor. Lemony notes. Hardly any alcohol flavor, despite the 13%. Sourness in superb moderation, leave the sugar tooth at home. Musty, mature finish. Excellent.
2005. Deep brown with reddish notes and a nice offwhite head. Grass, herbal, flowery and fruit. High acidity and still very balanced. Yum yum

***2002 Edition*** Pours a dark brown, with cranberry red, purple, and gray tinting. Head is toasted white bread, surprisingly large for being nearly 5 years old, but dissipating quickly, with widely spaced, rainbow bubbles. A tad of yeast falls onto the sparse sheet of bubbles that remain throughout the drink. More bubbles continually rise from the bottom of the glass. Aroma is vinous, with apple, pear, roasted spices and burnt sugars. Quite tantalizing. Taste is full luscious, fruit malt, grapes, apples, dates and an acidic sour that thinly coats and stings the  inside walls of the mouth. Taste is cherries, caramel, lemony hops, pepper, alcohol -- strong, but well held. Aftertaste is burnt mahogany, drying from the alcohol Interesting enough to keep tipping glass, strong enough to instill moderation. I just wish I had a case of these as opposed to my one. A wonderful choice for beer # 700, but perhaps I should have saved it for 1000.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2007 Bottle at Hopleaf.  Poured a a seemingly purplish hued brown with thick light brown head that laced the glass brilliantly.  Strong fruity aromas were sweet with a pungent aromatic spice to them and a veiled presence of alcohol.  Sour bitter flavor, grapefruity, acidic, very rich and hides the alcohol exceptionally.  Smooth and full a very nice beer.

Thanks to richlikebeer.  Best beer Ive had in some time.  2004 bottle.  Pours a hazy amber/copper color with no head.  Aroma of cherries, alcohol, wood...   Taste was complex-cherries, alcohol, wood, and yeast.  Excellent beer.!

02 Bottle at Toronado - SF: Shared this with my good buddy Aspidites. This is a great, great beer. An aroma of black cherries, a bit of light fruit and a slightly acidic/tartness coming thru. Flavors were an excellent combo of vinous, woody, dark and light fruit, and malts. This really reminded of a flemish sour with the dry finish. It didnt strip your mouth like a gueuze will, but it was an uplifting dryness. A fantastic beer.

12 oz bottles, 2002 and 2004 vintages side by side, 2004 bottle via footbalm.  Rating numbers are for the 2004 bottle, which I prefered much more.  Pours were similar, a rather murky looking reddish brown colored body under a light brown foamy head on the 2002, minimal to no head on the 2004.  2004 aroma is lightly tart with alot of woody notes, good amount of yeast, and very fruity, similar to a Flemish Sour.  The 2002 was very different, lots of sherry and port oxidation notes, minimal fruitiness that removed my association with Flemish Sours, and a stronger alcohol note.  Flavors followed the aromas almost step in step.  2004 was very fruity and much more tart, slightly acidic and almost completely hidden alcohol.  The 2002 was fairly oxidized, lending a very sherry like flavor to it.  The alcohol was alot more noticable as well.  I suppose the fruit fades but the alcohol stays.  Both vintages had a similar mouthfeel, but the 2002 was a bit thinner.  Similar moderately active carbonation.  Overall, I found the 2004 to be far superior even though Im a fan of aged beers.  It was alot more similar to the standard Oerbier at least and I guess Im basing it on that.  The 2002 would have rated somewhere in the neighborhood of a 3.9 total.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2008 2006 Vintage: Pours dark brown with red hues. More acidic and sour then I remember the last. The previous one had more barrel flavor to it, this tasted more like a flemish brown, with a bit more acidity. The previous bottle had more of a wild yeast funkiness, this didnt have that character as much. Still a nice beer, but the 2004 was better in my opinion, although this might pick up more character in time.

2004 Vintage: In the bottle at the Kulminator in Antwerp. Pours hazy copper with a big old rocky white head. The nose on the special reserva was amazing, very spicy with a woody, wild yeast, fruits, and sourness. The flavor was just incredible, changed a lot as you drank it and it warmed up. Very dry on the palate with a earthy and woody character. Citrus fruits, yeast, and spice mesh well, with a medium sour finish. This beer really never lets on that it is 13%.

2005 vintage -- Nice mahogony hue with a thin tan head, streaming carbonation.  Aroma is dark fruit, malts and yeast with a sour accent.  Taste is yeasty, and sour vinegar with initial earth tones.  Ending is dry and sour.
Hazy deep brown body with a small creamy light brown head. Sweet slightly sour fruit aroma. Light sour flavor, with some gentle fruit and light oak.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2007 A great beer. Red/brown, white foam, a lot af alcohol. Good balance between medium sourness and medium sweetness. Reminds me of af oud bruin - just much stronger. Clear hints from the oak barrels.
Smells nice but you can smell and taste the crazy amount of alcohol.  Its too much really; I think the regular is better by a little bit.

Aroma is really nice on this beer.  Almost "flemsih sour like".  The aroma is right on point with a great sour cherries that sat in alcohol, all the while extracting all sorts of good woodsy oak aromas from the barrel aging.  The aroma is really enjoyable on this one.  The appearence is a nice reddish brown, that has a very nice toffee colored head that is ever lasting, which came as a nice surprise for a 13% brew.  The flavors are really good on this brew.  A little bit of alcohol is present but wlecome.  There is a very nice showing of sour cherries and fruits, with some nice oak wood flavors coming through as well.  It is reminiscent of a nice red wine that was "soured over".  I really dont get a lot of belgian strong ale from this beer, but all the sa,e it is still a very good beer.  I think it would greatly benifit from some aging.  Im just no good at holding on to things for long time.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, very bubbly, dark reddish-orange with a lasting average size foamy tan head. Aroma of slightly sour fruit, oak, sweet malt, alcohol and some sugary sweetness to it -- very nice. Flavour of sour fruit, Belgian yeast, oak, sweet malt and alcohol with some bitterness in the finish -- if I had to nitpick Id say I wouldve liked it a little maltier. For this much alcohol its pretty well hidden. Medium bodied. Very good, I really enjoyed this.
Bottled. Yummy! Dark brownish in colour with a small tan head. This is really lovely and complex. Beautifull balance between sourness and sweetness.

2002 Bottle. This brown ale poured with  a sparse off-white head, eliciting a sour musky aroma. This is a "sour brown" style ale, but is more complex than most of the others, partially due to 4 years of aging. There are flavors of cherries, raisins, citrus, wood and alcohol, and a bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is slightly carbonated. It took half a bottle of adjustment before I started to appreciate the unusual characteristics of this brew, but I ended up liking it a lot.

Aroma is a gorgeous funky, fruity, sour, sweet symphony, clear ruby, tiny off-white head. Flavour is a highly fruited wonder, with some horseblanket notes as well.Medium bodied, sour, tart, dry and wonderfully refreshing. Magnificent!! Thank mds!

33 cl bottle, brewed and bottled in 2004. Eye: strongly veiled light mahogany on the reddish side, lively carbonation, very good head for such a strength. Nose: lactic fermentation, cherries, banana; hints of wood, nutmeg and bubblegum. Mouth: very much within the oud bruin frame, with sweet cherries, quite strong spicy notes and subdued but present alcohol. The finish is at first port-like, then long and spicy.

Bottle. 2004 vintage. Pours a murky brown body with a medium creamy brown-white head. The aroma is truly phenomenal - bitter orange citrus, yeasty fruit, bread, caramel, sugar, and alcohol. Quite dry - fruit, tangerine, apple, yeast in a saison/tripel way. Complex with a warming and slow sipper status due to the alcohol. Surprising level of tartness and a certain level of bitterness. Sharp carbonation. Very good.

Poured a dark brown color okay head lacing was okay.  Aroma was crazy busy spices raisins some malts and all kinds of other things.  Very carbonated.  Flavor was much the same but other things in there i couldnt pick out.  Good beer, high 4s i wasnt there but good.

2004 vintage.  Dark red-orange with a massive light tan head.  Mild doughy bread and muskiness in the aroma.  Plastic phenols and a ruddy tartness over woody malt and some raisin character.  Fruity tart finish with residual wet hay.  Mouthfeel is light, fairly dry.

11.2 oz bottle-This wasnt a bad beer & it will probbly suffer in comparrison due to the fact that I tasted it right after drinking their Stille Natch Special Reserve 2005. Poured murky dark brown/ruby red w/a moderste tan head. Had that distinctive "Belgian" aroma. Had a somewhat sour taste, kind of gamey & woodsy, not necessarily in a good way. Some oak, spicy, some what yeasty & doughy. Probibly drank this one before its time, may have been better w/a few years maturity. Long heavy tart finish.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 My girlfriend found a 2005 during her trip in Barcelona. (Im so lucky). Pours a beautiful deep brown/reddish with a thick tan head. The aroma is somewhat sour, with fruity notes and a pineyness. Its a very lively and rich beer with a tart bouquet/flavors of fresh plums, chocolate covered blackcherries, an oakeyness and a later subtle toffee like sweetness. Nice brew.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2007 Re-rate.  Beer 10 of the Bartzillas Death Metal Beer Tasting 1/12/2007, consumed with many great beer drinkers including Bartzilla, Naven, as well as Lee Chase.

This came out to be much more like a flemish sour then I had expected and damn it tasted good, different yes then the last 2 times Ive had it but shit it tasted really really great.  

Beer 26 Summer 2006 trip in Europe.  Drank on 7/3/06 bottled and purchased from the beer temple in brugge.  2005 Bottle.  This a fantastic brew, it is rich and extremely flavoral and quite potent in comparison to the regular oerbier.  Very very nice.

2004 bottle, nicely aged like a wine would be, with mellowed though present
souness.  Good foam and lace. Unique and worth having once.

Bottle, 2004, Oerbier tulip @ the Delirium café, Brussels. 
Slightly cloudy, ruddy brown body (barmaid gave it the heave-ho into the glass!), very finely carbonated but definitely well charged. Head erupted up the flue of the glass and receded back to form cobwebs of froth that daubed messy trails of lace down the sides. Intensely vinous, nose tickling aroma that glorifies its aged status, but to what effect. Alcohol is present, medicinal, as is some malt vinegar, burnt tight fruits and clean brandy, oak aged yeast extractions, tannins and vine clippings and just a little, little whiff of bitter chocolate to remind me of the beers namesake. As with HogTownHarry my notes read that the body is unbelievably and unremarkably light in the mouth. Almost too well attenuated, like it all got sucked up and spat out as alcohol and CO2 as the alcohol is aggressive and the carbonation makes it a little too harsh and prickly on the tongue. Deeply vinous, again showing the same traits as the aroma. Its got some tart, ripe aswell as aged fruits that give it a heavy puckering astringency that is also unexpected to the palate. Light showing of oak, fresh-chopped herbs, stinging nettles, grape tannins and a touch of Moselle that dries it out. Finish is a little harsh, unrefined yet it doesnt linger for too long aside from some woody notes and a little pepper and higher alcohols. Not all together impressed with this one. Sure it could get you arsed in half the time, but Ive tasted beers with half the alcohol that blow it out the water as far as overall complexity. Another couple of years and Id say it would be a high octane malt-vinegar so a younger one might be the go. On the positive, its certainly unique.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2006 Bottle (330ml - 2004 vintage).  Deep brownish ruby with a large, lasting, fluffy-creamy slightly off-white head.  Aroma is very much like a good Flemish sour, extra-strong alcohol - tart/sour - almost green - red currant, cherry, other berryfruit - yeast, wood resin and lemon zest; mildly vinous.  Taste is similar - reminds me oddly of Goudenband, heck, even Orval - spicy/yeasty, alcohol, sour fruit, dry citrus, even a hint of vinegar - I totally see jehoeys mentioning of a dry Spanish champagne.  The body is .. I guess a little light, hard to tell, its so continually fizzy and lively - medium acidity - I dont know what I was expecting, but this surprised me.  It grew on me a lot by the bottom of the bottle, very tart and funky.

33cl bottle that was brewed in 2002:  an interesting and very complex beer.  aroma of merlot wine, bourbon, and alcohol.  pours a murky dark brown much like Rochfort 8.  Has a small head that disipates quickly into a thin film.  Flavor is much like the aroma.  nots of plum, blackberry (very merlot like), but at the same time it tastes like a dry spainish champagne, and has the elements of a belgian ale, again like Rochfort 8.  The mouth feel is slightly syrupy and not very full or active.  not exactly what I expected in that regard, but this was still an awesome beer.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours  brown with a  beige head. Aroma of wood, citrus, and fruit. Flavor is wood, fruit, citurs, and a touch of caramel. 12% version. Great beer.

[Bottle]
Brownish colour. Sourish cherry nose with cheese notes. Fresh aroma. Kriek-like with berries most prominent and little almond paste. Dry-ish. Light body. Alcohol barely noticable.

(Sampled from bottle, thanks Marsiblursi) Red to brown color. Tan to brown head. Fruity a bit smoked Belgian ale scent. Sour cherry scent as well. Sour taste and aftertaste. The dominance of the kriek sour taste is almost overwhelming. Low to no bitterness. Spritzy mouthfeel. No alcohol taste, but a bit in the scent.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2007 (Bottle) Pours brown/red with a sandy coloured head. Aroma is kriekish with unripe cherries. Sour and woody. Green apples. Metal. Some cheese. Flavour of unripe green apples. A bit dry. No alcohol taste.

2004 Vintage.   Pours a murky, sepia/golden with obvious sediment hovering about. Upon swirling, a creamy, khaki head merges with sticky legs to slither gently back into the body like the ebb of a frothy tide. Fruity aroma with overwhelming alcohol precedes wine, then malts, then cheese... complex and attractive yet overpowered by esters. Tart flavor with a tingle and burn, vinous with funky yeastiness. Somewhat light bodied with a dry finish while the 13% hits like a hammer in the aftertaste. Definitely eyebrow-raising.
<font size=-4>Purchased some time ago from <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/chicag Wine & Spirits, Chicago, IL 60614<font size=-1>
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 bottle. red amber color. sweet and sour fruity aroma. malty. sweet and sour. spicy. carpy and yeasty.

04 i like the regular oerbier better. smells like banana peels vinegar but it isnt a strong aroma at all. cloudy ice tea looking. taste like orange peels. def. sour and bitter. the alcohol is hidden very well

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Bottled. (2005 vintage) Almost clear, reddish deep brown, with a dense, beige head. Sourness, dried fruits, some berries and spices in the aroma. Mostly sour flavor, with berries dominating. Lightly tart, medium body and a long, slightly astringent finish. Ok, its nice, but not that nice. My first beer at Kulminator this evening, so I wasnt drunk either. Rating: 7-5-7-3-15-3.7. 060715Bottle. A clear, dark golden beer with a dense, beige head, rather small. Vinous, slightly vinegary nose with roasted malts, alcohol and dried fruits. Sweet in the mouth with roasted malts, dried fruits, vinegar and bitterness. Quite vinous flavor too, with the alcohol pretty evident in a nice way. Warming, full-bodied and dry mouthfeel. Fine bitterness in the warming finish which feels sort of thin. A lovely, complex beer, but a bit on the vinegar side for a higher score. 090829

2002, rich and complex, this beer has it all. Big aroma of sour cherries, green applish sourdough bread, prunes soaked in brandy. Oaky notes in the nose and flavor, very sweet and fairly tart, with cherry pits and more prune/brandy. The nice carbonation keeps this moving across the palate and not overwhelming you. Easy, yeasty and spicy finish. Cloudy brownish color with a medium head. Awesome.

Smells huge, like a big dry red Bordeaux wine.  Notes of caramelly sweetness lurk underneath, and I cant wait to have a taste, here goes.  Ooof.  Strong, with champagne-like carbonation and slight tannin-like flavors.  An extremely nice sourness that I wish was more common in beer.  Not as sour as a lambic, seems to straddle the line nicely between outright lambic and a light Belgian. So complex, stimulates every part of the tongue, fantastic.

2004 bottle. I was incredibly psyched when I spotted this bottle on a shelf, as late as June 2006! It was gone a week later. Aroma of oak, cherry, raspberry, woody scotch, bubblegum, licorice. The scotch becomes pretty heavy; thankfully, it hardly shows up in the flavor. Taste starts with a sweet breadiness and descends into tart, cherry, rustic bourbon and brett, oaky love. Licorice shows up here, too. My notes for regular Oerbier and pretty skimpy, though I dont remember it tasting much like this beast at all. This is one killer beer. The flavor hits on so many levels, covering every tastebud and delighting every sense. World class.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 Wow, I cant believe I havent had this in 8 years!
Another 2002 (yes, 12 years old) Bottle, Purchased at Whole Foods, Vienna Virginia on 30-June-2006 for US$5.99, Received by Store or Distributor on 21-February-2004:
Sampled this as part of my 4500 Rating Celebration:
Muddy ruby brown coloured body with a non-existant tan head. Aroma of very sour grapes, cherries, raisins, figs, malt, earth, smoked peat and quite a bit of alcohol and cognac - very refreshing, intoxicating and complex. Medium to Full-bodied; Rich cherry flavour at first with a very earthy and nutty flavour and a cognac and whiskey flavour right afterwards, all ending with a lot of caramel and toffee sweetness and a hint of the sour grape flavour. Aftertaste ridiculously complex with the malts intertwined with scotch and brandy flavours, some apples and oak all touched up by the sweetness and finally a good sour twang that still persists in a beer twelve years old. Overall, a very nice and complex beer that shows its age very well. In reviewing my old rating, its definitely lost the effervescence (not sure where it went), and lost quite a bit of body - its almost thin now. However, the complexity seems to have expanded with more of a pit fruit flavour and a lot more caramel and dry oaky notes. Rating for this review: 9,3,9,5,16

<!-- b -->2002 Batch:<!-- /b --><!-- br -->Saved this bottle for quite a while - the first beer I cracked after just turning 25 and also the first beer ive rated in quite a long time! Fizzed incessantly when I popped the top, all over the counter...but most ended up in the glass. A few minutes later and im good to go. Nice dark brown coloured body with a strong ruby highlight when held to a light. Good slightly off-white head tops the beer at a half a centimetre thick. Complex aroma of sour grapes and apples, strong alcoholic scents, some vanilla and oak noticeable and finally some nuts in the finish - nice smell, all over the map. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong sour taste up front fading to a nice alcoholic kick all followed by a very noticeable vanilla and oak flavour. Sweet near the middle of the sample, then fading to a bitter end. Aftertaste shows all of the oaky tastes from this one, along with some grapeyness and even some nuts and malt. Overall, a very complex beer that was well worth waiting for! I sampled this 33 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Vienna, Virginia on 30-June-2006. This was a 2002 bottle, just to clarify.
Rating for Original Review (on 30-June-2006): 10,4,8,4,16

"I sampled the 2002 version of this brew, which I bought at Toronado in San Francisco. The pour was dark brown with red highlights and a nice beige head that stuck around awhile. The aroma was friuty and sweet, and you could tell that it had a sour factor to it as well--smelled a lot like a flemish sour. The taste was definitely sour, and fruity--with the wood flavors coming through in the end, and they were definitely present. This is a very complex tasting beer. The mouthfeel was nice, light and effervescent. A very good beer, that I enjoyed more and more as I comsumed it. "

2004. Pretty crazy beer.  Nothing at all like the regular Oerbier.  Lots of bret stank in the aroma.  A fair amount of bret sourness, nicely played against some woody wine flavor.  Only on the finish do you get any of that bready yeast flavor.  Pretty interesting and pretty good.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 Re-rate, 2006 Vintage in Jan 2010: Very fantastic. Well-done brew, glad I sat on this one for a while, especially since bret/oak/funky brews are the bomb now. Very well done, softly sour/tart cherries, brown malts, huge big body, well supported sour funky brew, mouthfeel was almost creamy, alcohol smooth as day. A residual sweetness was even present. My kind of brew. 2002 Vintage: Ok, I dont care, Ill do it. Sure, Ill be one of the low guys, a full standard deviation away from the mean (ie. in the bottom ~15 percentile of raters). Go ahead, flog me, deem me a heretic. Poured a murky brown color with a thin head that stuck well with the beer. Lacing decent, really good for a 12% ABV beer. The aroma was all vinous and grape-like with some raisins, light wood. The flavor was really vinous and somewhat harsh, again lots of grapes and apples there to attack the tongue, leaving behind oaky wood remnants. Raisins and caramel malts were very prominent in other sips. Tart and sour notes leave the tongue a bit acidic with each sip, although the warming temperatures brought back some sweet-sour imprints that I remember from the oerbier. This beer is really complex, Ill give it that. Still, this thing, for being a 2002 vintage, sure seemed rough and even a bit astringent for having come so far and being supposedly matured in barrels. The oak aging doesnt do it for me in all beer styles, and it clashed here for me.
De richlikebeer, bouteille 2004. Belle couleur cuivrée avec un très beau collet. Arome sucré dépice et de petit fruit. Goût de fruit sûr avec un arrière goût sec.

2004 - Most incredible red brown body with a huge creamy white head lasting through leaving very thick and beautiful laces; Not all that big a nose, but still very deep and complex, it has a certain yoghurt like sourness to it, some wood, not yet ripe pear, young red berries (strawberry); Medium ++ fill in the body with lots of balance; Into a quite sour very long finish, very complex and super interesting, lots of dry sherry aroma (without actually being dry at all), super fresh apple etc. Great beer, but it seems like it will get better in a few years.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 Bottle sampled with Beerded_one, picked up from State Line. Pours a cloudy bronze\brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of wood, citrus, fruit, yeast, and sweetness. Flavor is very smooth, citrus, wood, fruit, fermented cherries, and caramel. 02 version good body, great brew.
2004 version. Hazy reddish brown with reddish foam. Rich vinous aroma of fruit and oak. Pleasant creamy mouthfeel. Sour. Long aftertaste. This is really a flemish brown.

Big thanks to malachi for sharing.  Fruity, vinous aroma with a touch of oak, cherries, grapes, dried fruits, licorice, toffee, apple and vanilla...wow that is a lot of descripters.  Cloudy, amber-brown with a tall, off-white head.  Sharp flavor, sour cherries, caramel and toffee and then lots of drying oak and some vinous, dry red wine notes and some warming alcohol, but it is well hidden.  Lively body, very dry.  Complex and interesting.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2006 11.2 oz bottle shared with malachi and hezron

Thanks go to malachi for bringing this to a tasting.  It is the 2004 vintage, apparently acquired at Sams in Chicago.  There was a foamy one-finger head and faint carbonation.  A rich bouquet of honey, barnyard, oak cask, cherries, almonds and wheat combined to tempt me to take a sip.  An extremely compact combination of coriander, honey, oak, citrus, sour cherries all preceded a pleasing chocolate dipped raspberry finish.  The alcohol was so well masked that I never would have imagined it was 13% ABV.

2004 Vintage - 11.2oz bottle via trade with Dough77 - Thanks Tim! - Fair gush when I popped the cap on this one. Pours dark copper with a creamy tan head that stayed very well and laced the glass well.  Aroma is raisin, toffee, caramel, oak, and a touch of cherry.  Flavor is much more pronounced cherry, oak, yeast, some sweet toffee and caramel notes in the background though.  Quite complex.  Finish is quite sour with some vinegar notes.  This has all the characteristics of a Flemish Sour to me. No signs of the 13% alcohol..  Pretty interesting brew.

2004 vintage, 11.2 oz bottle via trade with The_Epeeist. Cloudy brown with a dense white head. Nose is rather complex - dark fruit, some rumlike notes, toffee, molasses, some woodiness. Flavor is more of the same, but with a sour bite. Tart cherry and yeast. Drier finish than the standard Oerbier. As it warms, the sourness recedes a bit and the oak and fruit come to the fore. Alcohol very well hidden. Im laying my other bottle down, cant wait to see how this one matures!

Thanks to Immy.  From bottle.  Pours a murky brown with hints of red and a tan head.  Nose of honey, grapes some sourness and woody undertones.  Flavor is sour, with vinegar mixed in.  Sweet grapes as well with a dry but sour/bitter lingering finish.  All the flavors nicely complement each other.  If someone had told me this was a Flemish sour, I would have had to believe them.  Very well hidden alcohol.

2004 bottle at Hopleaf.  This was one of those occasions where I just got completely lost in a beer...  Poured a deep, hazy, orangey-brown with a short cap of beige head.  Nose was ever-so-powerful with tart vinous notes, cellary yeast, black cherry, oaken vanilla, spicy malt, and woodsy hops... to name a few.  Flavor didnt skip a beat... it led with rich vinous malts and funky yeast... then came the perfectly-integrated woodwork (oak, vanilla, and Bordeaux), tart cherries and grapes... finished by balsamic vinegar, more tart dark fruits, and complementary alcohol.  Rich, tart, and heavier-bodied on the palate... flowed perfectly, and all of its components were expertly blended and balanced.  Warming and satisfying finish.  Phenominal!

Bottle, sapled at Kulminator. Dark red colour, low tan coloured head. Strong, vinous and really fruity aroma, mostly black cherries, grape stones with a balsamic undertone. Vinous full flavour of cherries, wet grass, fruitcake, red currant, wood and even some cinnamon somewhere. Smooth balsamic mouthfeel. Woody, balsamic finish, notes of grape stones, almond and tea. A masterpiece.

04...Pours a dark rosey orange with a soft and sticky earthy tan head...tight lacing.  Aroma is extraordinary (even at below cellar temp).  Soft sweet and sour yeast, syrupy red fruit, tart nectarines, candi sugar, lemons, and oaky alcohol (increasing with temp).  Flavor is...big.  Perfect sourness and alcohol warming combination...incredible.  Strong but subtle oak, vanilla, and sour cherries.  Slight bitterness and sweetness that dance along the tongue.  Mouthfeel is actually a bit numbing...form the alcohol.  This beer was seriously tasty.  I think the de dolle folks are the best brewers in belgian (though I havent had any westys).

2005 Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a medium foamy tan head that laced and retained.  Aroma is great...vinous, tart, dark fruits and some caramel hidden in there.  Really hard to put in words.  Flavor is tart...cherries, vinous the barrels really did a great wonders on this already great beer.  I had the regular version right before this one, loved that one and this one was awesome! Might have to snag another to let sit around.
Tart cherry (almost a lambic), sharp hit of alcohol with citrusy sweetness.  Very fizzy beer. The head dissolves quickly but never disappears.  Not to my taste, but I know many who would like it.

(bottle - 330 ml: 2004 vintage) Murky brown pour with about a half inch of tan head. Very fruity aroma with hints of caramel, alcohol, raisins, plums and yeast. Flavor begins with a very sweet and tart taste of fruits, yeast, raisins, cranberries and some alcohol. The middle is very sweet and malty with a nice and smooth finish that leaves a slightly sweet and tangy aftertaste on the palate. Very thick and chewy and all around tasty. 13%? Couldve fooled me.
[bottle from Kulminator] Big aroma, fruity - apples, plums, leather, acidic, woody, vinous. full body, tart finish.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Bottled. Dense, creamy and much bulky head, good persistence. Dark reddish color, hazy and dense one. Much complex and fruity scent; notes of sweet malt, candy, and withered cherry. Much racy and much prickly taste, unexpectedly scant alcoholic to the palate, much acidulous and sour one on the end with a dense and balanced body. Long end with bitterish and acidulous trains.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2006 Bottle at The Kulminator, Antwerp.  2004 bottle. Cloudy red copper beer with lasting beige head.  Some sourness and cereal on aroma.  In mouth sour and caramel.  Some sour finish.  Very warming.  As always well made.  Too carbonated for me.  Lemon fruit.  Just a tad harsh and I guess I was looking for something better 3.1/5

Re-rate.  2005 bottle care of Phil_L.  Having had the normal Oerbier on tap at the brewery, this is just so different.  Same colour though, a rich dark red with lasting beige head.  Belgian sour red ale aroma.  Lots of rich sour dark fruit.  Very carbonated.  Chocolate, then sourness in mouth.  Spritzey, carbonated sour finish.  Alcohol is strong.  Amazing fruit though.

An 02 bottle.  Aroma very strong apple and slight pear.  Pour was a dark amber with an off white head.  Flavor was same as the aroma but it had an astringent quality to it as well. Palate was ok stardard for a strong.  Overall it was ok I suppose I need to get a regular bottle of Oerbier to evaluate fuller.

Beer pours a hazy, medium, strawberry-amber color with a large, creamy, off-white, quickly diminishing and mostly lasting head. The aroma is dead sexy: Moderately yeasty with a note of creamy, blue-veined cheese; Heavily vinous; complex miscellaneous notes of cherry, brown sugar, light notes of copper, ketchup, mustard, cinnamon, cumin, balsamic vinegar and a trace of rhubarb. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic and moderately bitter with a long, moderately-to-heavily bitter, lightly sweet, lightly acidic finish. Alcohol is well tucked away. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is watery and the carbonation is assertive. This ones a total tail-wagger.

2002 bottle.  Reddish brown with nice head and lacing.  The aroma has a nice sourness, along with some caramel.  The alcohol is fairly well hidden but the cask flavors are prevalent.  It really rounds out as it warms.  This definitely tastes better than it did a year ago.  Great beer.

2004 bottle, thank you Grapes of Mirth, good store. Anyhow, Dark red amber pour, bit off white head. Aroma was oak, some wine notes, fruity, and a bit of alcohol. Very complex taste, difficult to describe after all the other beer I had tonight. But I know I liked it, a lot.Similar to the aroma however.

Bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar.Shit nose is massively complex with oaky cognac,portlike fruitiness and some sour toffee. Wow,more like flemish sour.This is close to Panil as it is has woody stuff going on with a major hit of soured fruit.Thanks Tom.

Pours reddish amber with a thick tan head.  Aromas of oak, cherry, white wine, apple, toffee and hints of chocolate.  Taste was sour with the sugars working very well.  The vanilla and oak comes in nicely. Palate burns because of the alcohol.  Overall this is awesome but not something I would drink regularly because of the strength.

2004 Bottle. Orange on the pour with an interesting sour aroma, mixed with some notes of fruit. The carbonation was quite active and actually made noise when I put my ear to the glass. Taste is very complex, similiar to a good flemish sour but with a bit more of a kick and complexity with some notes of cherries and a touch of oack here or there. This is one hell of a beer. Would like to find this one again

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2009 2004. Brown/very dark bronze when held to light. Multitude of carbonation columns. Thick, creamy, light tan head. Aroma- mildly sour and spicy yeast, oak, madeira, alcohol, rich malt, lightly fruity(dark-cherries), candi sugar. Complex. Taste is like an imperial flemish sour with some belgian strong and a touch of dark dessert wine. Oaky sour cherries, a bit spicy yeast, rich malt, vineous- somewhere between a bordeaux and madeira, candi sugar. Alcohol acts as an accent to the flavors, livens things up without any burn. Rich, full body, perfectly carbonated. Dry, sour, roasty aftertaste. Outstanding. I want more.
Turbid brown pour with 1-finger off-white head.  Aroma of huge oaky cherries, malt, some bourbon.  The flavor is of malty kriek, tart cherries, oaky honey.  Very complex palate.  This beer is great.

this is quite a brew....dark red body with small white head...aroma is massive of  tart cherry, vinegar, citrus, spice, and molasses....flavor is a bit weaker than its corresponding aroma, but is strong in dark berries, red wine, vinegar, and is very flemish in nature....has some sort of a tonic water backbone....nice palate, and is an amazing beer

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Pours out a deep dark mahogany-amber with a large off-white foamy head.  Cherry aroma.  Flavor is tart but very complex, with the Bordeaux cask aging evident in the rich red wine notes.  Well balanced flavor.  Medium bodied with good carbonation evident on the tongue, and a long finish of oak, vanilla, and red wine.  Very nice...as my fifth beer tonight this is starting to get me drunk towards the end.  Overall interesting and good.

Bottle: Poured a dark reddish color ale with a medium light brown foamy head with pretty good retention. Aroma of cherries with some detectable tartness and sourness. Taste is an incredible mix between sour cherries, tart, oak with some real wine quality to it. Extremely complex but very well balance at the same time with no alcohol showing in this beer even though it is up to 13%. Probably one of the best Flemish sour I had the luck to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2006 2004 bottle - Damp wood aroma, thick mahogany body, and steady thin head.    At 13% ABV this ale went right to my Bubblegoose.     Drank in honor of my #900 and last RB.com rating of 2005.     Mad props to my Secret Santa for hittin me up wit a bottle from De Dolle Brouwizzle dizzzle Brewery.

2004 vintage bottle. Burnished copper color with a thick, off-white head. Foam dots and the beer clings to the glass when swirled. Served at 52° in a Duvel tulip. Winey, tart cherries, some red wine vinegar flavors. There is also vanilla and, to a lesser extent, yeast. Bright aroma. The initial taste is mildly sour, mildly tart cherries, raspberries, red wine vinegar, some sweetness. The finish is a burst of tart fruits, oak, and vanilla. The aftertaste is mildly astringent. The understated alcohol in the finish belies the 13% strength. I love De Dolle beers.

2004 vintage.  Poured an effervescent dark mahogany with a large semi-frothy off-white head.  Aroma of cinnamon, tart cherries, alcohol.  Taste is mildly acidic cherries and citrus with a dry yeasty grainy charcter.  Long yeasty dry finish.  Aggressive carbonation.  Flavor was a shock at first but got better as the glass emptied.
2002.  Pours brownish with slight mahogony tint.  Nose is very woosdy with candi sugar and maltiness.  Slightly vinous.  Full bodied, acidic with character of Flemish red/brown.  Sipping beer.

Thanks a lot for sharing this interesting 2004 vintage concoction, Duane. This was more tart than I expected. The body was medium copper with a slightly off white creamy head. The aroma was funky molasses with some some flowers. There was also balsamic vinegar and leather. I expected a sweeter aroma. The taste was funky tart lemons and leather. There was also molasses and cherries. A very interesting brew.

330ml bottle from richlikebeer in a trade.  superb aroma of yeast, bubblegum and sweet aromatic cedar.  color is a dark amber with a fast fading tan head.  the first sip or 2 is very sour or tart, but after the 3rd sip everything smooths out.  finish is quite dry.  Ive never had a Flemish sour, but I think this could have fit into this category perfectly.  nice beer, thanks Rich.

2002 bottle.  Clear amber color with a thin biege head that fell to a long lasting whisp.  Nose started out as all cedar wood and sweet, but the alcohol came out as it warmed.  Lots of wood, red wine tannin, pit fruit and something tangy in the back of my mouth.  I am not a big sour beer fan, but this has a well balance acidity to it that I enjoy.

Amazing bold maroon color with large beige head leaving huge amounts of lace.  Held up to the light a tornado like stream of carbonation rises from the center of the glass and continues to populate the head.  It looks like a plume of smoke rising from a fire at twlight.  The aroma is fruit and vinegar.  Sharp earthy and with a spice.  The flavor is strikingly acidic and sour.  Cherries and vinegar take residence at the back of the mouth and tongue and mellow.  Another sip refreshes the tangy zing with a vinegar and wine flavor.  Really an amazing beer.  The huge initial sourness is large but does not offend the palate.  As more sips are taken it develops a huge velved smooth character.  This is an amazing beer.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2005 2004 bottle. Clear brownish red body (lighter) with a nice head. Aroma is more like a Flemish Sour. Dark cherries and vinegar dominate. Other usual Belgian characteristics like candy sugar and yeast are muted but still there. After a few sips to get used to it this became a great beer.

2004 bottle. Hazy dark amber in colour. Small off white head. A little woody aroma and some fruityness. A little sour flavour and also a little woody. Notes from the alchohol asweel. The aftertaste is a little sour. But a very nice sourness.

2004 vintage bottle.   Pours transparent brown.  Settles nicely with splotchy yeast on the surface.  Nose is dominated by sour grapes and raisins.    Very different brew with the wood infused into the middle of the taste.  Finish is extremely sour with raspberry elements to it.

Bottle - 2004 batch  After pouring out a sourish, cherry, wooden aroma fills the air, without sniffing. The body is deep amber and quite clear.  Lightly brown, rocky head, but mostly diminishing.  The aroma is woow: fruits, sherry, white port,  woods, white wine, like entering a wine cellar at the wine farmer.  Moderately acidic, lightly bitter initial flavour.  Heavily acidic, lightly bitter finish.  Very good balanced.  Fully bodied, fizzy carbonation.  Very nice strong sour ale, which isnt dominated by alcohol.  Ill think Ill buy some other for my cellar.

Pours a hazy yellow color with a small off white head. Aroma is a litte woddy and there is definitly some fruit aroma. Flavor is very sour with a little bit of would in it. In general this is alright however not worth the money.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2012 2004 bottle, consumed Nov 2005. Pours dark brown/amber with an off-white head that fades to layer of fizz. Aroma is dark fruit, candi sugar with strong woody notes. Flavor is sour with wood, candi sugar and plums underneath. 6/27/06. Rerate. 2004 bottle. Pours a hazy brown with a big, pillowy, beige head. The aroma is vanilla, vinegar, sour cherries, light pineapple and horseblanket. The flavor is moderately sour, acetic and some lactic, overflowing with sour cherries, lightly vinous, lots of oak, heavy tannins. The mouthfeel is light and lively, suprisingly dry, with a very dry and tannic finish. Holy shit, good stuff!

Pours a hazy mahohany amber colour with a thin head. Aromas of sour cherries or prunes, spices and yeast. Port-like taste and mouthfeel with a slight sourness and woody overtones. Quite different from the other De Dolls Ive had

Bottle purchased at Torrence Liquors near Chicago. 04 Vintage. Wow this is funky stuff. The Belgian yeasts provide some great sourness here, and notes of banana, orange peel, and lemon come across on the palate. Lots of spice in the nose. Great stuff, and refreshingly sour. Wish I had more to age.
22SEP05  Bottle bought at New Beer Distributors. Cloudy, brown, small off-white head that dissipates quickly. Spicy aroma. Didnt find any of the tastes the others have described  just SOUR!

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 No#86.(2004) Now this is the last beer from the trip i am sure of it. I could nose a beer like this till there was no beer left. Intence fruity, balanced sourness, malty, the oerbier, but better. Taste is similar with a great sourness, is it all about the sourness these days i wonder?
I hope i can get this over the net or else ill have to go back to the kulminator for more. RERATING: 2005 BOTTLE. GarethYoungs 21st diner at his parents house. Outstading one of the best beers iv ever had, aroma is about 14 out of 10, taste is more than 10, the best belgiun non lambic ale iv had from Belgium this year i think.

(2004) Aroma is quite fruity, some oak in it. Like a flemish sour ale. Alcohol present. Hazy, brown coloured with a thin, lasting, off-white head. Taste initially sweet, balanced and more sour towards the finish. Malty, fruity. Alcohol clearly present. Dry brew. Balance is okay, but I expected more complexity.

Bottle at LCRBM, inside the Kulminator. vintage 2004. great beer thought very different from the original one. aroma: woody, bit burnt, sherry, sweetish and sourrish. taste:sour, raisins and other dark fruit, woody. finishes sourrish bitterish. full, not much co2. different and nice. would have guest it a flemish sour ale.
Murky orange/ reddish beer with a dense beige head. Fruity, light tart aroma with a dusty note. Lovely fruity / tart flavor with a very nice cherry note and some yeastyness. Dry, light earthy finish.

Dark brown color, medium head. Aroma of sour and tart cherry, oak, massive alcohol, port-like. Taste is like a flemish sour ale, but with a lot of alcohol, with some roasted malt added. I didnt expect it to be this way.

2004 version. Orange red brown color, like old wine. Glorious vinous aroma with wood, apple and cherry. Upcoming sourness. Very fruity and vinous. Aple, grapes, wood, rosted malt, caramel, cherry. Obvious alcohol. Very complex, with the greatness of Oerbier 15 years or so ago, but more alcoholic. A big beer in all senses of the word.

Bottled 2004 vintage (Kulminator, Antwerp). Brown appearance, lots of carbonation. Aroma and flavour of of a Flemish Sour, fruit and oak, but with loads of alcohol. I concur with jbrus, the high alcohol percentage doesnt really match with the flavour.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 Bottled at Kulminator, 2004 vintage. Seems like an attempt to create a high alcoholic version of a flemish red. They succeeded in the alcohol, but that unbalanced the beer as a whole. And there isnt very much complexity in the beer as well. Sourish, light sweet, light bitter, raisin, tart. Ok, its all there but not overwhelming or suprisingly flowing from one flavor into another.

2004 Vintage.  Vinous, slightly sour pear-like aroma.  There are some sweet candy sugar notes and a bit of maltiness present in the nose as well.  Vanilla and floral bouquets are also present.  Slightly peppery aroma that has a lot going on.  Mildly hazy gorgeous garnet-ruby color with a soft, light tan/yellow head.  Fruity, to start with pears, grapes.  These barrel characteristics seem to add an astringency to this beer that is somewhat sour and puckering in the middle.  Sweet middle with alochol burn to finish.  Lots of woodsy oak notes to finish.  The astringency to this is somewhat unsettling and over the top.  I am a bit disappointed by this beer.

Pours auburn with a big fizzy white head. Aroma is nutty and yeasty. Taste is sweet, dark fruit, red wine, and nutty undertones.  Tart aftertaste. Way better than the regular oerbier in my opinion. Medium body.

2004 bottle - Horizontal with "normal" Oerbier.  Poured exactly like the other oerbier:  Dark ruby with a small but lingering head.  Stronger aroma than the Oerbier with a lot of bakers chocolate and a ton of dark fruit.  Where the Oerbier is sweet and malty, the Reserva is dry and tart.  I find it hard to believe that these are pretty much the same beer.  Very dry and vinous, like a red wine.  Sour and tart mouthfeel, more like a saison or Flemish sour than the regular Oerbier.  Flavor consisted of grape, prune and other tart, dark fruit and a little bit of barnyard and leather,  Very complex taste, but theres something about it that doesnt come together right.  Maybe a few years of aging will do this well.  For now, I prefer the regular Oerbier over this one.  Thanks to Terry Boyd at Mountview in Naugatuck for saving a few bottles of this of this one.

(2002 bottle purchased @ toronado)the reserva poured a beautiful reddish/brown body with a nice thick,and creamy head.as the head simmered it left thick webbing on the chimay glass.my nose gathered aromas of cherries,tart citrus,oak,and sweet malts.the flavor was much of the same with a bit of smoke thrown in at the end of the palate.this is pretty tastey and very different.

I need to start out my rating by saying "just because it is a reserve and a limited edition, does not make it good."  With the context set, lets move on.  Very beautiful red color with a lightly oxidized brown color that creates even more depth and richness and is unobtainable through malt alone.  The head is pale tan color, rocky, and honey-combed in structure at the bottom.  Aroma is bubblegum, slight sourness from acetobacters not unlike a flemish red/brown ale, a chocolate-caramel maltiness, and overripe bananas.  Flavor is dissappointing.  All the aroma components are in the flavor but are muddledinto one disorganized, unfortunate mess.  It is not a tapestry of flavor where you pick out the subtle complexities nor is it layered with flavor where one flavor rolls into the next then into the next.  Not done trashing this yet.  Instead of the aged, soft, complex flavor of balsamic vinegar, this one has the burning, unsubtle flavor of $0.99/gallon, distilled, white vinegar.  This is not De Dolle best offering.

33cl - bottled 2005 - Aroma is sweet, yeasty, plum, and a touch of red wine.  Pours a cloudy red-tinted brown with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor is a yeasty red wine with the alcohol showing trough.  Palate is clean, sweet, tart, and a little fizzy.  Interesting, I have not have the regular Oerbier so I cant compare yet.

Aroma: malt, alcohol, figs and a tiny bit of pineapple. Appearance: muddy red/brown with a just off white head and sudsy lacing. Flavour: sour, sweet and malty? Palate: medium mouthfeel with a finishing sourness & malt. Overall tastes different to what I imagined from the aroma.

Pours a deep hazy amber with a nice fluffy light beige head and good lace.  Aroma is red wine-like with sour hints.  Perhaps some lactic and pedio bacteria in the aroma as well.  Almost lambic-like as well as having some sweet caramel malt aromas.  Flavor was not as sweet as I expected but was slightly sour, farmhouse like, with a drier more acidic body.  Moderate to high corabonation make for just an ok mouthfeel.  Finish is very dry, acidic, tart, and astringent.

Semi-murky yet translucent at other angles.  Deep safire brown color, audible fizzles and graying bubble cloisters for the head.  Aroma leaps out of the glass.  Shiraz-cabernet, plums, cherry juice, freshly thawed cranberries, cinnamon apples, rose petals and raspberry syrup.  Whew.  Flavor produces a portly offshoot.  Oak barrel smoothness permeates the reach around with brandy and mint julep flavor extremities.  Braeburn apple tartness is matched with a red grape sourness.  Slick, diffusing yet vinous palate feel.  Nice ample carbonation and tone, finishing like cranapples and brandy.  Numerous sour ale complexities.

2004 Bottle. Clear glowing mahogany with a thick, off-white head. Aroma of yeast, sour cherries, wood and alcohol. Flavor has notes of tart fruitiness, sourness, some vinegar, pear, acidity, plum/raisin, champagne/white wine and some wood. Pretty vinuous. Alcohol content very well-hidden. Finishes dry. Medium to thin texture, but not watery - subtle, soft-bead carbonation. Pretty complex.

From a 330ml bottle purchased at Torrence Liquors, Calumet City IL.
Cidery, acetic aroma and not much else. Nice cloudy auburn color. Not much head, but what little head is produced stays right to the last sip, leaving spots of lace here and there on the sides of the glass. Flavor starts out quite sour, almost unpleasantly so, but sweetens as it sits on the tongue. Moderate hop bitterness shows up at the end. Never would have guessed this was 13% ABV -- alcohol is well-hidden. Highly tingly and effervescent palate -- this is one fun beer to swallow from a tactile standpoint. Hard to go wrong with De Dolle.
Sweet aroma, nicely carbonated with steadfast head, tart winey flavor--cherries?/plum?? not sure. Very tsately though...
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: 2004: Lovely ruby orange colour, with a lasting off white head. Nice lace too. Woody oak aroma with notes of apple, berries and spice. Slightly acidic in the nose too, along with a bit of alcohol. Lovely sweet malts with distinct red wine flavours. Nice berry notes, and subdued tannins. Very oaky, and alcohol suprisingly well disguised in flavour. Really tasty stuff.
2002 Bottle.  Beautiful Belgian aroma wiht a nice bubble yan head over a light brown ale.  Bitter almost sour taste.  Warm finish, almost fruity.

A bit on the light side......... This would be my favourite beer if only it wasnt so damm expensive... I migth have to start my own brewery and buy som wine-produciton-leftovers and just start up something like that, cause it is good like hell.... (red: read this with the danish sarcasm in mention. Ass it would bee way too dificult!)

Pours a dark (and slightly cloudy) amber color with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly woody and yeasty.  The flavor has strong vinous notes and wood and hints of oak.  I enjoyed the smoothness of the beer complimented by the slightly dry alcohol taste in the finish!
Muddy brown. Salty, yeasty nose. Sour-ish in flavour with some hints of red berries. Acidic finish.

This should be a treat.  Pour is a nice dark red haze with a thick cream head on top.  You can smell the wine and the wood present here.  It comes off as somewhat acidic to the smell, with a backing of oak.  The flavor is quite unique because it mirrors the wine aspects.  It has this grassy, sugary and yeast flavor  here, but also comes across as wine like.  Very interesting.  Palate is oily and bittering, it sticks in the mouth with a dry acidic feeling.  Not exactly my cup of tea, but a good beer regardless.
Nice amber color with nominal head. Aroma is vinous with black cherries,tart,and lively. Reminded me somewhat of Fantome Black Ghost of a few years ago.
Bottle. Red-brown with small beige head. Malty, tart, tannins, wood, alcohol, vinous. Very nice... 13% though...

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2006 Brewed in 2004. Deep amber colour with a creamy head that gives a good lacing. The aroma is dominated by oaky vanilla and alcohol with sour notes. Flavour is sweet and sour, developing into a dry finish. Warming alcohol. A beer for special occasions.

Tasted the 2005 bottle at Kulminator. in Sep 2006 (8-5-8-5-17, 4.3) Colour was almost black, and I think licorice was more prominent in the nose as well as for the taste compared to the 2004 brew.
