Moderately dry finish with lingering medicine and a late brett charge along with some  lightly toasted malt husks. I foresee a deep slumber in a dark cellar unearthing sheer perfection.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Poured a ruby red, some brown as well in the color with a tan head and nice lacing.  Vinous, tart aroma of white grapes.  Sweet taste also included notes of wood, oak, some sour grapes and even alittle alcohol.  Very lively mouthfeel.  I feel this would benefit from a little while in the cellar.
Brown-reddish coloured beer with a small head. Vinous, woody and light sour aroma and taste. Dry bitter tannin aftertaste. This is probably a beer that will just get better and better with age.

Dark amber to brown color with a smaller head of tan bubbles. Heavy aromas of mild cherries, raisins, single malt, watermelon wine and beaujolais. Aroma becomes softer and more wine like as it warms. Starts with a tannin like bite that leads to a light malt sweetness and rich fruit flavor. Quite spritzy on the palate. This is one to challenge the fine wines. This does have some of the finest balance in a brew that I have had in some time. Tart, sweet, sour, bitter, dry, soft, wow! The finish is a bit like chewing on apple skin, but other things considered...

Aroma is very Flemish Sour like.  Definitely notes of wet wood and sour/tartness.  Quite attractive in the glass, color is light orange brown.  Beer pours with a very big head that is fully retained.  Lots of lacing.  Flavor is quite large.  The big ABV is there, but a lot of other stuff is happening also.  Taste is initally tart, albeit very pleasantly so, the alcohol is also tasted, but this too is a nice sensation.  Also, a faint hint of what I suppose must be the bordeaux wine.  This is very delicious.

Hazy dark red color,Large head that lasted for quite some time but i was patient since it was a little colder then it should be.Fruity sweet aroma with more smells here then i can put my finger on.The taste was fantastic,Fruit a plenty,berries and possibly apple and pear light malt and a sweet and sour sort of taste.Very nice brew and much better then i was expecting,the brew managed to stay tasty and interesting right to the end where it seemed to go a bit dry and sour,with the fruit still lingering on the pallate.This really makes for a nice trade from Iwantalambic Bud you out did yourself by sending this fine brew Now,can i have another.

Thanks to Slob for this unexpected Xmas gift. Appears brown and cloudy at first but with light behind looks a beautiful glowing red color. Head is thick and creamy with good lacing. Aroma is a full one of fruit and malt with raspberries and a sourness also. Alcohol is slightly noticible in the aroma. Mouthfeel is highly charged at first with a crisp and steady carbonation. This mellowed a bit as it warmed some more. This ale covers the glass with a thick lace of foam. The high abv is barely noticable in the flavor. Flavor is quite sour like sour fruit. Interesting and almost like a lambic or gueze. Has a puckering dryness at the finish. Overall enjoyable, I wasn't expecting the sourness but does not detract.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: I notice the aroma when pouring, very fruity and malty.  Maybe a scent of overripe apples or cider in the background.  The tan colored head was big and made of big bubbles that stayed to the end.  The liquid was a deep red.  Held to the light, it almost looked like a transparent cabernet wine.  The first sip brought a creamy feel, oak and cherry taste, followed by a nice warming feeling. This must come from the 12% abv, which is well hidden.  The finish is a little bitter or sour, which adds to its complexity.  Certainly a beer to drink slowly.

Murky,red/light brown. Fizzy,fat,head,just like every other De Dolle beer I've had. Thick,patchy lacework. Killer aroma! Very fruity,distinct winey/grape aromas,with wood,and some malt. Mouthfeel is creamy as hell. Texture is silky as can be.Up front bready malt,peppery yeast flavors. Quickly following is sour fruit,vinous flavors. The sourness really hit before the finish with wet wood. Finish is fairly malty,slightly sour and vinous. The malt,sour,vinous,flavors mesh together perfectly. Excellent beer!

Hazy dark amber color, light brown head, fair amount of lace. Big aroma, could smell while pouring. Big mix of sweet and sour, malt cherry, plum, alcohol, chocolate, wood, and some yeast. Flavor is initially sweet and fruity, plum and raisin, with quite a bit of Flemish sour flavors emerging in the middle. Finish was earthy and woody with some alcohol warming, but not much for the 12% abv. Alcohol mellowed as the beer reached room temp and some more grapey and vinous flavors came out. Full body, quite smooth, and decadent. Was rediculously drinkable. Excellent.

Hazy light copper w/ a lasting light beige head.  Very rich dark fruit aromas with raisins and currants with a light sourness; bready, yeasty, spicy pepper, faint malt whiskey aroma.  I'm guessing it smells that way due to some higher alcohols that give it a solventy, acetone aroma, and for being conditioned on oak, I only detect a hint of raw oak.  Maybe my sniffer's off, but I just don't get much.  Sweetly malty at the start and sour at the middle and finish.  Dark fruits (raisin, currants) w/ some clove spice yeast flavor;  seems balanced to sour, not sweet or bitter, and there is some fruitiness from alcohol along with some malt flavor;  aftertaste is malt with a faint hop flavor.  Some light astringency in the mouthfeel, highly carbonated probably making the body lighter than actual (feels medium bodied), also has a more than warming but not hot alcohol.  I have mixed feelings about this beer. I like the complexity, but I'm not sure I like that character of it.  It might improve with some age, but I guess I was expecting something less sour.  It's not Flanders Red or Sour Brown sour, but I'm not a big fan of sour beers.  I have a few more bottles that I'll keep around for a while to see how they do.

A dense tightly packed head sits atop a murky reddish brown brew. Nose is yeasty with hints of strawberries. The flavor has berry and granny smith apples notes with the finish bringing the wine and all that.Slightly tart at first but seems to mellow as it sits with the oak really becoming a huge aspect of the flavor.

This pours a hazy copper, with red highlights along with a thick tan head. The flavor started making me think that this was a Flemish sour ale, it quickly changed into a fruit explosion. Yes, it has tart overtones, but the flavor and nose are very vinuous. It's silky smooth and a pleasure to drink. Take your time and sip this one.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2005 2004: Plum, apple, sour taste.  Spiced Rum.  Alcohol.  Some mild malt and bread flavors.

2002: Thick huge apple spice flavors.  A type of dry white wine palate and flavor.  Tartish and candy like.  A bit sour but nothing really detracting or harsh.  Interesting balance of flavors.

When I poured this into the glass, my first impression was dull medium brown. After I poured, the color seemed to change from that dull and boring brown to rubies on worn leather. The head is a dense, small-bubbled foam, like melted french vanilla icecream. It also showed no signs of fading. The wine aroma in this one is stronger than I remember the wine being in the Stille Nacht Reserva. Underneath that is a very estery beer. The flavor is sweet, with the wine still dominating. The very vinuous character is reinforced by the tartness in the finish. Melon, green apples dipped in caramel. Extremely tasty. I really wish I had access to regular Oerbier now to see how different this is. The only problem is that I wonder if the wine may have overwhelmed the beer a bit. Then again, many Belgian strong ales are very winey to start with, in which case the bordeaux casks would have only enhanced what is already there. Regardless, all the flavors work very well together and the tartness gives it a bit of a refreshing quality that makes it that much easier to drink.

Large tan head with a good lace. Murky brown color. Fruity nose, plums, raisins, cherries, wood and some alcohol. Medium body, medium sourness.Oakey, mildly acidic, cherry and alcohol flavors also.As it warms more alcohol comes through balancing out the acidity and fruityness, some how. Finish is dry, kinda thin.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2008 2006 vintage, sampled on 3/31/08: Pours a hazy dark amber ruby with a large, frothy and well-lacing light tan head.  Aroma of tart cherries and vinous oak with a subtle hint of dark caramel malt.  Body starts fairly full and mostly tart with a good complexity of bordeaux oak and vinous flavor.  Still a bit fresh, but should age pretty well.

2002 vintage, rerate on 1/26/07: Murky orange brown pour has a large, airy cream-colored head with thin lacing.  Has a complex oaky, slightly earthy aged malty aroma along with some fruity notes.  Body has lost some of its sweetness and taken on a little more tartness, but is still very flavorful and balanced.  Id say this has aged quite well and should continue to do so for a few more years.

2002 vintage originally sampled on 11/30/03: Copper brown hued with a thick lacey off-white head.  Rich complex aroma of red wine, caramel malt and sour fruits. Body has a good thickness and nice malty, sour oak complexity.  Tart puckering oak finish has a warming effect on the body, but hides the alcohol from the taste buds.  Very nicely aged and quite enjoyable.  Another great beer from De Dolle.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2004 Re-rate 9/26/2004 Murky ruby-copper body, nice tan headthat produces big sheets of lacing. The aroma is oak, wine, plum, and other vinous qualties. Flavor-wise it is brilliant. The red wine characteristics are here, slighlty spicy, very earthy with some almost gueze like notes. Some light hoppiness kicks just before teh swallow, then some alcohol wamrth. Speaking of the alcohol, you would never know this one clocks in at 12%!  As it warms it starts to develop some English barley wine flavors as well as those previously mentioned. Dry palate and a very wine-like finish. I stand by my previous numerical assement. A great beer that is aging like a champ.  11/28/2003 8/4/10/5/18 - 4.5 Wow what a beer! Slightly hazy copper body with a rocky off-white head. The elacing is very nice. Big cherry-oak nose. THe first taste is of the wood casks that this beer was aged in, then a more complex sour winey flavor develops. The body is medium and smooth. The finish is very dry like a red wine. Truly an outstanding beer!

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 Rating #1000... Bottle... Tasted while tailgating with Lubiere, MaiBockAddict, Capflu (#1000 for him as well) & Lori, mkobes and scraff. Upper slope Tailgate Party at GBOA 2003 in Lake Harmony, PA... This beer rocks! ... Cloudy, copper-colored ale with a small, creamy, white head. The nose is pungent and tangy with well-blended notes of dry, white sherry, cherries, caramel, whiskey and oak. The flavor is Flemish, sour, acetic and woodsy with a light bourbon note. Decently balanced. The high ABV is not at all evident to me. Medium-bodied with a very dry, fizzy mouthfeel and lengthy, bone-dry finish. Excellent beer!

This is really a special beer - I like it far more than the Stille Nacht Reserva of last year. This has almost no sweetness; it's tart cherry and alcohol and oak - all the things people here have mentioned. It is indeed silky smooth and like it's non-barrel-aged brother, has a living breathing head atop a lovely, perfect copper body. Some pepper on the lips and in the nose.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Rating #1000 - (Bottle) Upper slope tailgate party at GBAF 2003. Bottle was courtesy of MaiBockAddict. On this very special occasion - Hopscotch and I celebrated our #1000 with Lori, Lubière, MaiBockAddict, MKobes, Matt, Scraff and Hopscotch. Perfect beer for a fine weekend with friends. Pours a cloudy, copper body and a thin, white head. Nose of geuze, sour cherries. Malt intertwines with the tart cherry flavour. Excellent beer. I'd love to do it all again!

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2003 Wow, I talked to beer rep today that I have a great deal of respect for, and he said the bottle he had was far to sour, and thought he had a bad bottle.  I think he might have too!  This is excellent.  I sort of misses as a Belgian Strong ale, reminds me more of their Speciaal 20, wood aged(flemish  sour).  Aroma was fruity sweet(cherry) and tart.  Flavor is well balance between sweet & sour.  Dry finish.  All by itself, this beer would be the ultimate steak marinate, but it would seem a shame to use it in that fashion.  Excellent Beer though!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2003 Oh well - guess marinaro said the most of this fine beer. We got it Saturday at our Pre-Thanksgiving dinner in NJ and it is great. Sour raison nose. Wondeful red-brown brew nice medium foamy head. Fizzy carbonation. Brussels laces on the glass. Warm malty, peppery and rasions taste. Strong alcohol, kind of nutty with sour puckering tones. Wonderful accomplishment to the Turkey!

Nose of green apples, mohagany colr, tight bubbled head with lace. Sweet sugary malt body with a spicy finish - tart and gritty like an apple peel. Apricots in the middle? Incredible body, very sophisticated, and everything is boosted by the alcohol.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2004 I was lucky enough to purchase a case of this stuff! It comes in a soft wooden crate with the big Oerbier character stamped into the side, very cool cellering vessel!  The beer poured a solid Burnt Sienna brown, maybe a few shades darker with a red tint, there is no seeing through this beer!  A thin, but very active off-white head sizzles on top. The nose is an amazing array of sweet, sour and saltiness, big aroma of oak, some cherry, raspberry, vanilla, smaller hints of horseblanket, orange liquor, and chocolate.  Thin first sip is tangy and acidic, blast of fruity flavors, mostly citric, some sour cherry note and then an incredible woody dryness.  Dryness left over on the front of the tongue is tingly and acidic and alcoholic. This is a massive beer.  As it warms, a grapey, winey flavor is left in place of the burning alcohol.  Every part of the mouth has a part in enjoying this. It's complexities have complexities.   Truly one of the best beers I have ever  enjoyed.  At the end of the glass,  the Flemish Sour attributes are strongest, with only tiny hints of oak or alcohol (how at 12% is this possible??).  Several minutes after I have finished, a very grapey belch reminds me that it was no "normal" beer, and I'm a very lucky man...

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 2004 Bottle - Dark mahogany and amber, thin off white fizzy head.  Nose held intense notes of sour cherry, oak, and lemon, with lighter vinous and apple-like tones.  Flavor was all about sour & tart cherry, lemon and wood, lightly astringent, with again more vinous undertones.  Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, sour, woody, vinous finish.  Stuff rocks!
Drank with a group of people after a beer festival. Golden in color. Not a bad beer. Whiskey barrel cask aged, and that really made a difference with it. Very enjoyable. Malty.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 Drank with Lubiere, Capflu, Mkobes, Scraff, and Hopscotch under a crisp starry sky on a ski slope outside Split Rock Resort. Funky Gueze aroma. Golden color. Rather surprising Gueze flavor, with the notes of the cask aging. The big maltiness of the beer blends well with the sourness rather well. A cherry sourness is present in both the flavor and aroma. Wonderfully complex. An overall enjoyable experience had by all.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: This one is hard to pin down.  Tastes unlike any other beer that I have ever tried.  The oak barrel aging is very evident.  Strongly alcoholic that is tempered by the oak.  Almost like a whiskey or something but with less bite and a nice, sour apple finish.  Just when you think you've tasted it all, something different comes along..

UPDATED: APR 26, 2008 2005 Vintage Deep dark brown, hazy with huge yellow-brownish head. 4/5 Grapes, Pineau des Charentes, vinous, old wood, woodstainer, preserved dark fruit & oranges. 9/10  Dry woodstainer, vinous, grapes & raisins, special kind of brandy with complex flavours: more dark fruit, slight fruity acidity. 9/10 Full bodied, burning & alcoholic, syrupy in an "ethanolly" way. 5/5 A superb brew, even better than the 2002. 18/20
 2002 Vintage 
Very dark brown-amber with a red shine, slight haze; thick creamy head. Nose of fresh, ripe brambles, or the same on sherry; thick bramble- or raspberryjam, homemade and covered with white brandy. Intensely fruity. Sour-sweetish taste in the best traditional West-Flemish style. Phenolic, very estery. Fruity, but more like plums or raisins - with a dash of lactic acid. Tart, non-viscous fruit yoghurt? Immensely thick & warming sensation. Very highly saturated (for a barreled beer), alcohol obvious. Just superb - a return to the past, both for DDB as for West-Flemish ales. Kris H. tells me this has been end-fermented with Brettanomyces. I can well believe him, relying on the taste.

 New points for 2006 Vintage
THE BRETTS ARE BACK!!  The nose tells it: last year Brettanomyces was there - but one knew once one was told. Now theres no mistaking any longer. It smells like a super Russian River beer. The taste is just WOOOWW!! The Bretts are back in force, with a musty, mushroom, old wine or port with a gueuze tang; dusty, but juice-bursting deep dark grapes. This vintage is the best so far!

2006 vintage,  special bottling Châteauneuf-du-Pape barrels 
Hazy-brown with orange highlights. Overwhelming nose with wood, vanilla, brandy, dried fruits (as figs, mango, apricots), vinous and cake. Woody, wine, red berries, pineapple with a sweet-sour perfect balance. Viscuous, near chewy, fiery alcoholic and - great. Wow. An exotic version of  Reserva 

9/4/9/5/18
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2005 This is a good Belgian Strong ale.  Tart, sweet, and wine flavors.  Finishes rich, tart, and warming.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2015 Bottle (2013 vintage, bottled April 2015).

Head is initially small, fizzy/frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy medium to dark reddish-amber, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (caramel), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of dried cherry, wood, alcohol, red licorice, allspice.

Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Rather underwhelming in the mouth, but the aroma is quite nice.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2005 Had this at an impromptu beer tasting at Bon Vivant Market in Smithfield VA on 11-8-03. Thanks to Mike from Bon Vivant and Andrew from Specialty Distributors. Pours a nice copper with a deep red hue. The nose is wonderful! Malt whisky, strong alcohol notes, wood and a hint of vanilla. The taste is much different than I expected. Tart with dominant citrus. Light malt, white grapes and more wood coming through. Tart finish also but somewhat smooth mouthfeel considering this fact. The best part was after my glass was empty. It smelled like fresh cut wood mixed with vanilla. Incredible! Awesome stuff!

Bottle. 2004 vintage. Pours hazed ruby with a fluffy tan head. Nose is awesome! Tart fruits, light wood, wine, yeast, alcohol, light funkiness - pretty much like a Flemish Sour. Taste is very much the same as well. Tart fruits (some citric acidity along with it), wine, grapes, wood notes, big yeast flavors, alcohol, candied fruitiness underneath and an almost Sour Patch Kid-like flavor as well. Body is spritzy and tart with a mild dryness and acidity. Finishes  very well indeed. Lingering alcohol and a sour grape and raspberry note with wood, and cady notes. Very nice. This one should age impeccably!
